Game is super buggy. Co-op, my partner builds on to the raft we built, he can see it, i cannot. I craft items, it tells me i have no room in my inventory and to place it on the ground, but it is just gone, as are the resources used to craft it. Game needs works before I can recommend it

This game starts off fun. And the its gets boring very quickly. I have to play on a mac so this is one of the few multiplayer games I can actually play. This combined with the fact I played it with a friend was the only reason I got so many hour in. 

The combat (sharks and bosses) is somewhat a highlight but thats about it. Building is tedious and pointless, progression is shallow and hits a practical limit very quickly. Adding the custom islands makes exploring somewhat fun again and actually give exploration meaning. The ending is VERY bad considering how grindy the game is. 

There is fun to be had don't get me wrong but I'd not recommend this game. And if you do get the game, look online for the custom ilands and the game might at least be somewhat exiting otherwise exploring becomes boring.

Actually played for over 2 days (96 days in-game) but Steam didn't pick it up. Anyway, the short of it is that the game is good and quite challenging. The ending was very dissatisfying after all that work, though.
Good survival game.  Learning curve is steep at beginning but once you figure it out it's great.
lot of bugs in multiplayer. no tutorial and questline, dont recommend

poop

It IS basic, and does have the occasional have-to-reload bug, but it's also attractive for it's simplicity - it's RELAXING. You don't have to think too hard and only have to make basic strategies to stay alive, and while things will kill you if you aren't careful it's not overly difficult, and the scenery is enjoyable. 

Only real downside is that you do have to adjust to the mechanics, and I found I did have to look things up to figure out how you did certain things - build certain items etc. But it's a game anyone could play, from very young folk to new gamers who have never played before. 

I really enjoyed the relaxation aspects: swimming around, catching fish and crabs, cooking things over a fire as the sun went down - well it's a lot cheaper than a holiday on a tropical island doing the same thing. 

Not perfect, but perfectly playable, and good value for money.
A very fun, immersive game.
I got my ass bitten by a shark , amazing experience to get yr ass eating clean3. 10/10

Gameplay is very smooth and immersive.  While the interface and mechanics are not always intuitive, they are clean and easy to use once learned.  There are only two aspects that in my opinion need improvement.  First is a known issue with not being able to deconstruct your raft base.  Second is that there is no auto-save feature.  You are required to manually save at a shelter.  This makes real-life interruptions extremely costly as I have been pulled away abruptly many times and come back to character death and the loss of hours worth of work.

Meh.  It's kinda like the Forest but with no story whatsoever.  The gameplay loop is so basic and simple.  You're just out finding supplies to build a [spoiler]plane[/spoiler] to escape.  There's no need to build a large shelter other than to see it from a distance so you know which island is your mainbase but you can avoid that by simply using the cartographer in the main menu.  

As far as survival craft games go this pales in comparison to Green Hell and The Long Dark.  Those games are 10/10, this is a 5/10.

i would highly advise getting this game only a few negatives i see about it one the multiplayer mode is so glitchy and only allows 2 players if those could be added or fixed then this game would be an amazing game so yes i recommend this very much
Great game, but it still has some bugs with the animals clipping into the floor and running on the air.

I love this game purely for the survival challenge and beauty... however... there are MANY things that could be fixed. First, it is not explained how to consume items or view the watch. Second, learning how to do everything with switching between all the menus is really difficult. Third, the inability to build on the raft very much disappointed me as you have to travel so many times between the islands to get enough materials without destroying your home island. Love the game, but it needs more refining.

This game is the biggest trash i have ever seen. How could this game be on steam ? I dont know.... Many many bugs, i can lift gyrocopter with my bare hands and coop mode is so so bad.... when i build something my friend cannot see it.. NOT RECOMMENDING !! 
My advise: fix the game or rename to PRE-ALPHA

I've been casually playing this game and watching it's progress since it's Early Access..which I'm pretty sure was something like 2014-2020. This game has gone from a simple survival game to a very nicely detailed game with fairly advanced style survival mechanics. The creators have even added in great easter eggs and terrifying monsters to fight.

Now...this game has changed IMMENSELY since it's original introduction around 2014 (or whenever it was). It was originally dubbed the "Castaway Simulator" (i.e. the movie, Castaway). It has indeed changed over the many years...and many players complained when things changed and eventually called the game "unrecognizable" from the original version. Well...that's the idea. I think that these guys have lovingly worked on this game for about a decade or so. Sure, things have been added and taken out...but it's still essentially the same game to me. Just better. Added Co-Op, Map and Island builders, customized game modes...it's all nice to me.

To be honest, this was the very first survival type game that I really enjoyed. It has a very chill setting and tone. It's wonderful to play casually or in-depth (no pun). I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants a fun and interesting tropical-style survival game. With the new features these days and the extra things to find, it's a very cool adventure.

[b]A very solid 7.5/10[/b]

A very brutal game with almost no documentation. It will kill you a hundred times, and never tell you why.

For example, consider the Poisoned condition. How does it happen? How dangerous is it? How can you fix it? You should be able to figure out the answers to these questions through gameplay (or the manual, if the game had one), but the only actual way to figure them out is by reading spoiler material.
kinda boring

This game can be very, very relaxing and yet is still pretty intense. A survival simulator where you play a marooned plane wreck survivor. Choose male or female, start in world with a compass and that's about it.  It's up to you to find resources and craft things out of them to hunt for food, find new resources with tools, defend yourself from predators, you can even collect parts to a vehicle, though I haven't figured out what it goes to yet. All in all, enjoyable for at least a day or two, with procedural generation and multiplayer, albeit the mutliplayer lobby seems dead. You could invite a friend though, so its still possible. Even systems with very low requirements can play, the laptop I play on is basically a notebook.
game d
A-fucking-pproved. It's fun. I like the whole survival aspect, and the underwater is beautiful af. Very good

I've spent some time, many months apart and this game hasn't come along in any meaningful way... yes, there is more content, in terms of a few boss elements, but that's it. 

The idea is great and enthrals me... the idea of diving out past the ridge line and starring off into the abyss definitely freaks me out. Sharks lurking all over is another suspenseful element... but its the execution that sucks... 

The issues are still plentiful - sharks that can swim onto land to some degree, physics that creates way too much issues with your raft/boat getting stuck, no real reason why you boat floats well one moment then semi submerges the next so as to allow the now more aggressive sharks to snap you right off... for me Sunkenland seems to be making better progress...

Definitely not ready for release. There's pigs walking through the air, islands disappear, trees rise from their stumps as you cut them down... Lots of glaring bugs that should've been fixed before release. Don't touch it. Not even on discount. Try Raft instead.

As of now the issues still aren't fixed.

Very pretty game, although if you were looking for story, this isn't where you're going to find it.

It's very mixed, I wish there was a "meh" rating. It feels half-baked, it's not great and also not bad. I have played about 7h so far. You have crafting, base building and survival elements and combat with wildlife. Animations of attacking wildlife are jittery but acceptable, although the boar is especially janky.

Playing the game in co-op and it's pretty rough with a bunch of disconnects and it takes about 5-10min to rejoin while both are just waiting for a loading screen to go away. There's objects that "vibrates" a lot, like you usually see in multiplayer when desync is happening, sometimes the raft throws a tantrum and launches you like a catapult.

 There's a lack of information about how the game works and I randomly died while having 50% health and breath underwater whilst being poisoned. It was also unclear whether I died or not the first time, the UI just vanishes and you're stuck only being able to rotate the camera, scratching your head.

The UI and crafting is rough, needlessly clunky even though I'm starting to get a bit more used to it. We figured out you could get to a specific category of crafting depending on what tool you have in hand. I would rather have an overview of all categories at least instead of the system they have now where you gotta click several times until you hopefully see what you want.  

You have a hotbar showing tools/weapons that arent necessarily there, gotta check the "wheel inventory" if it's actually there or not. Many small negatives adding up and large gaps between game updates is the reason why I decided to not recommend it.

If you are really interested in the game, I would recommend checking out gameplay before deciding.

Edit: 

I decided to try multiplayer mode (MP) a second time after a QoL update, but sadly we still had the same issues with crashes and desyncs. So I decided to play the game in single player mode (SP) instead.  The game is much more playable in SP and haven't encountered any crashes. 

Summary still remains essentially the same although the game is decent, if the game was SP only I might've given it a recommendation. However, since MP is broken, I can't recommend it as the feature is not fully functioning.

This is a qualified yes. The game isn't bad but some elements are a bit clunky and take some getting use to. На Українській:

"Stranded Deep" - гра, яку наразі граю з другом. Я ще не закінчив цю гру, але вона вже вразила мене своєю механікою! Ми з другом вирішили грати, не дивлячись жодних відео-проходжень перед тим, щоб було цікавіше, і це вже дало нам багато емоцій. Завдяки нашому рішенню я досі дивуюся механіці розпалювання вогню. Ми зрозуміли, як розпалити вогонь, тільки подивившись це відео (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wPGjJyULhU4). Дякую автору за надання посилання на підказку. Щоб не спойлерити текстом, я впевнений, що це також вас вразить. Також раджу вам не втрачати перший пліт, оскільки подорожувати на плоту, а не плаваючи, як ми почали спочатку, заощадить вам багато часу та нервів, а також зробить ваші подорожі по океану безпечнішими. Це поки що всі поради, які я можу дати новачкам. Свій другий відгук я залишу, коли завершимо гру; зараз у нас 12-й день виживання. Залиште свою реакцію лайком і діліться своїми порадами для мене та інших читачів у коментарях. Приємної гри! Дякую за увагу!

На Русском:

"Stranded Deep" - игра, которую на данный момент прохожу с другом. Я не прошёл эту игру ещё до конца, но она меня уже успела поразить своей механикой! Мы с другом решили проходить, предварительно не посмотрев прохождение, чтобы это было интереснее, и не зря она подарила нам много эмоций. Благодаря нашему решению я поражаюсь ещё до сих пор механике развода огня. Мы додумались, как развести его, только посмотрев это видео (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wPGjJyULhU4). Спасибо автору, приложил ссылку на гайд. Чтобы не спойлерить текстом, я уверен, вас это тоже поразит. Также советую вам не терять первый плот, поскольку передвижение на плоту, а не вплавь, как мы это делали с другом сначала, сэкономит кучу времени и нервов, а также обезопасит ваше передвижение по океану. Это пока что все советы, которые я могу дать новичкам. Свой второй отзыв оставлю, когда пройду игру, сейчас у нас 12 день выживания. Свою реакцию можете оставить лайком, пишите свои советы мне и другим читателям на будущее в комментариях. Хорошей игры! Спасибо за внимание!

On English:

"Stranded Deep" - a game I'm currently playing with a friend. I haven't finished this game yet, but it has already impressed me with its mechanics! My friend and I decided to play without watching any walkthroughs beforehand to make it more interesting, and it has already given us a lot of emotions. Thanks to our decision, I am still amazed by the fire-making mechanics. We figured out how to start a fire only by watching this video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wPGjJyULhU4). Thanks to the author for providing the guide. Without spoiling anything, I'm sure it will impress you too. I also advise you not to lose your first raft, as traveling on a raft instead of swimming, like we did initially, will save you a lot of time and nerves, as well as make your ocean travel safer. Those are all the tips I can give to newcomers for now. I'll leave my second review when we finish the game; right now, we're on day 12 of survival. Feel free to leave your reaction with a like and share your tips for me and other readers in the comments. Have a great game! Thanks for your attention!

Definitely not perfect, but close enough. 
For a cheap price this little gem holds a whole lot of hours of gameplay. 
I got a motorboat, a gyrocopter, and all the food and water I could wish for. 
The people rating this low, did not spend enough time getting to know the game mechanics. 
I'm fighting sharks, catching lionfishs, living the life!

Stranded Deep is not a game; it is a pile of assets strung together so that they look like a video game.

Controls are completely wonky. Nothing is communicated. Players have invisible stats that increase randomly. Crafting is bottlenecked massively at high difficulty. Movement and models are janky.

Somehow we've entered an era where someone can design and sell a game without ever seeming to have played one. Refunded after 67 minutes.
This is a solid game, I finished it several times and each time it was fun. Highly recommend if this is a genre you like.
Mostly chill survival game...until the sharks come! It's great to relax with after a long day.

This game just isnt for me.

first of all, I get the feeling that the devs were not given enough time to make this game feature-complete and refine some aspects of the game.

I will go into detail with things I didnt like and there might be some mild spoilers ahead. You've been warned.

_______________________________________________________________________

Tutorial:
basically useless.
I had to figure stuff out myself.
This would have been fine, but if you put a tutorial in a game, please try to make it actually helpful.

I strongly dislike the combat in this game:
the AI is dumb af. Either they are running away from you, or they will just headon fight you to the death.
The bossfights are very annoying and take ages, because they are bulletsponges, even with high skills and the best weapons. (possibly several ingame days).
Of cause you could call this "challanging", but its clearly not the way I would want it from a game.

Ressources:
I dont understand a lot of the logic behind the ressources in this game.
The only fully grown trees you can cut down are palms. Other big trees you simply can not interact with, wich does not make sense to me.
Trees will not regrow, which is fine, bot neither will flowers you picked and I dont get why this is, because you can clearly plant them in a farmplot. Just so you actually have to use the farmplot?
big BS if you ask me, especially because the remnants of those flowers will stay there for every, like a grave saying "this used to be the home of an innocent flower UNTIL A BARBARIC MONSTER CAME AND RIPPED THEM OUT!"
Another thing I dont get is, why cou can not pick up certain items. I can carrie a fully loaded chest with 5 logs in them. why cant I carry one empty oil-barrel? Yes, you can drag them, but not put them in your inventory.

Story:
If you can call it that... At some point you have to fill up a container with food, but this container does not give a single soletary flying f*** abut what food you give them or if it is even prepared and that just doesnt make any sense to me.

Building a raft:
This could not be more static.
I understand that this is not meant to be a game where you only leave your raft to gather ressources, since this is not "raft"(the game), but it is not very fullfilling to see how limited the options are when it comes to building yoiur raft and especially to build stuff on top of it.
Building doesnt feel very polished either.

Game-map:
you get a map even before you start the game, but I dont understand why there is no option to have a map in game. The only orientation you get are the ocean current, the sun and a compass. Not what I would expect from a game like this. but thats just me being salty I guess.

I really liked the concept of the game, but the way it was made in the end, completely destroyed the fun for me and I got more frustrated with every day that passed.
I'll rather go back to raft and put a couple of hundred hours into that.

If you made it to this point, thank you for taking the time to actually read it.
I hope it helps to figure out if this game is for you.
Anyway very harm to survive

11 days in, island full of crates, build a shelter on another island, saved, closed the game. Came back to continue playing, head back to main island to drop off all my loot. No crates, they all despawned, google the issue, been a thing since 2020. GG

Mechanics are terrible, you have almost no inventory space, and there are limited instructions on gameplay that lead to constant death due to confusion.  How am I supposed to do the simplest of crafting when I have almost no inventory space?  Then, the game has you facing challenges before you've even learned how to craft the necessary items to combat them.  I really enjoy survival games but this one was a combination of Raft and the Forest with only the most annoying elements retained.  I tried to climb down a ladder and since I didn't hit the space button, my character took a gainer off the platform and broke his leg.  When I restarted after death, I tried the same ladder and pressed space this time to avoid the broken leg.  When I pressed down to climb down the ladder, he slid at a high rate of speed and broke his leg once again.  Come on.  When a person goes to climb down a ladder, it shouldn't require multiple tries to learn how to do it safely as any normal human would have done it with ease.  Don't waste your money on this game.
Oddly calming, and somehow tense  at the same time.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I got this game for my boyfriend and I, but the multiplayer is so buggy it made the game pretty much impossible to play. I wouldn't recommend this game if you plan on playing it with someone else via online co-op.
very fun, been watching people play this since i was very young, i remember this one youtuber that would always talk about his life and he would sing "baby dong hurt me no more" good time.

Get a paper and a pencil in real life. Get a compass in the game. Now take off your island on a boat-float-swimming,etc.  Sketch the NSEW points and try to triangulate your positions, arrive on a new island and repeat. This makes the game WAYYY more enjoyable that it already is. This will give you a sense of you truly discovering islands and to have the capability of returning to specific islands that have specific resources. Also having the map made by yourself, with added notes, gives you a sensation of not being a stranded joe dying lost by the water or worse, getting eating by a great white. Ouch.

Good game and really enjoyed learning the skills and exploring the islands in the early stages, but be prepared for lots of glitches when playing multiplayer.  I experienced countless disconnections when close to a created island and huge base we created.  Started building a cliff base on a single player game but due to having to have a floor below (as otherwise you can't build above) proved impossible so shelved that idea.  Maybe if you created an island you would have more joy with this.

Would have loved to have missions to complete like in Raft but once you've built your base, visited islands and killed 3 bosses theres no challenge anymore.  The game sets you up nicely to play other survival games.

I'm a big fan of The Long Dark and Survival: Fountain of Youth, but Stranded Deep just doesn't make the cut. On the first tutorial island, when walking forward when up and over a bush as though it were a hill, I stopped and sent it back.

The inventory system was a bit clunky and, while the crafting menu layout was nice (not blocking the screen), the ingredients were difficult to visually distinguish from one another.

If you do decide to try it out anyway, I strongly recommend going into the settings and turning "smoothing" completely off for movement. Otherwise, you'll get motion sick REAL fast (this is on land; I understand the reasoning behind the motion queasiness on the boat and am fine with it).
fun but keeps you on your seat.

Played this game on my PS4 before PC and I love the PC version much better. There's a few things different, but I still prefer to play on PC. The game is not difficult and is singleplayer. It's a very large map and you can spawn new maps or even create your own, though I wouldn't recommend it, it's very difficult to make it look nice. There is a passive mode! Where you still need food, water, shelter, etc. but the wildlife will not attack you! I always play in this mode because I'm a complete coward! XD but it's great! I'm terrified of the ocean, but I find this game beautiful and stunning! A few small things are troublesome, like you have to hold the button to keep up the inventory menu, or that you have to hold an object to put it down. But that's not that bad compared to everything else. I recommend it for people who live survival, building. Passive mode is Minecraft Peaceful mode with hunger and water and stuff. There's also a creative mode if you don't want that at all!

I literally bought this because I thought that the world was infinite and based on generative game methodology. You can check my game stats possibly but I've spent a lot of time playing this game and I don't have much to say about it other than the fact that it robbed me of my time. Acredito que seja difícil de avaliar quem seja o público-alvo do jogo, pelos seguintes motivos:
[spoiler]
- Você constrói base em uma ilha (mas 99% do jogo, você estará em outra ilha e é muito fácil se perder)
- Caso queira navegar por mapa (o mapa só é acessível pelo menu do jogo, não tem um mapa durante a gameplay)

- Não tem uma linha narrativa, nem ao menos nada para explorar nas ilhas que seja interessante
- Tem muita ilha para pouca variedade (não tem cavernas, todas as ilhas tem quase o mesmo tamanho/fauna/flora/recursos)
[/spoiler]
Em resumo é um jogo que tem potencial, mas você fica com gosto de que falta algo

Interesting survival game with nice mechanics, sadly game isn´t being updated and the sickness system is stupid because it is almost imposible to find any antibiotics in game to cure a single sting

EDIT: Somehow the devs managed to fix the game, at least 90% of it, now it plays and runs way better in many aspects (gameplay, interface. crafting, mechanics, and even graphics). The devs also added a co-op mode in which you can play with friends, truly a huge improvement over the old Stranded Deep which seemed abandoned by its devs.

EDIT 2: After finishing the game I have to say this. Stranded Deep is a pretty clunky game, but it exceeds on atmosphere and survival mechanics. Exploration is this game biggest flaw, dozens of virtually exact islands all over the map with nothing that differentiates them, (apart from the 2 abandoned survivor camps I found in my whole game, one of them containing Cast Away's Wilson). I had to install a map mod since this game provides virtually no map or way to make exploration bearable. Ships and even the gyrocopter go extremely slow and exploration gets tedious after 4-5 islands. Apart from that Stranded Deep is worth the grind and provides a great survival experience, plus the ending is interesting and makes up for the boring mechanics. Crafting could also be improved as well as animations, but like I said before, the atmosphere of a sunset over the Pacific islands and the interesting progression (need to kill 3 bosses to progress to the end) manage to make up for it. Would recommend playing co-op since it would make the game faster and more fun. Overall I recommend Stranded Deep.

Stranded Deep is not a bad game but there are other games that do the exact same thing only much better. Throughout 24 hours of play I couldn't help but constantly compare it to Raft and Green Hell. As best I can tell, this game is an attempt at merging the aesthetics and mechanics of Green Hell with the setting of Raft but failing to attain either. I'll try to break it down to several categories and compare.

Story. I know it's not a priority for many survival games but there is essentially no story, whereas Green Hell has an amazing story that I highly recommend. Raft doesn't have a narrative per se but it does have a lot of world building through out the "story locations" that are fun to find. 

Building and Crafting. In short they are not very fleshed out and often are poorly designed or just plain buggy. You can build a raft, but you basically can't build anything on it meaning that you can't use it as your base. In Raft, your raft IS your base and you can build everything required to survive on it. You can also build a base on land however the building mechanics themselves are quite poor and trying to place items will seemingly randomly decide whether they want to snap together or not. The base itself serves no real function apart from storing crafting appliances, which can be built on the bare ground anyway. Having said that, the whole point of the game is to island hop so trying to drop down roots somewhere is kind of pointless anyway, it's like the devs couldn't decide if they wanted you to have a home or be a nomad, so just didn't really give you the tools to do either in any meaningful way.

Progression of (crafting/skill? not sure what to call it). It's boring. You do the thing and you get xp, then you can do more of the thing. Both Raft and Green Hell gate your crafting recipes through progression in the game/story so there's an actual sense of reward or development. Stranded deep just has you grind for them.

A bare bones survival game with limited items available for crafting and building. The game wants you to build a raft and go from island to island draining the few resources on each. You cannot carry anything with you on your raft however. After visiting island after island you will upgrade your raft 1 section at a time before you realize there is absolutely no point. IT cannot do anything in the game. You cannot build on it and you cannot store items on it. 1 piece raft is good enough to transport your body over the seas. Bases are useless because most of the time you will be slowly sailing to another island and you will not want to return to that island that has no resources (Most items do not respawn). Every island looks incredibly similar. The shipwrecks, the empty red containers (Every single one I have ever opened has been empty). It can be fun to survive day to day but I don't feel any reason to doing the survival part other than to reach the end game, In other games it is fun to personalize your base and just play the game, but there's such limited areas of interaction in Stranded Deep and no benefit or enjoyment gained. Boring?

I have almost 50 hours now. This game has some potential but the negatives far outweigh what could have been a good game. Where should I start...

Building mechanics make absolutely no sense. There is literally no gameplay difference between building a twig shack and a brick fortress (apart from costing you significantly more). Not only that, there is zero incentive to build *anything* at all, as buildings won't protect you against rain, wind and cold - they simply do not exist in the game apart from visuals/sound fx. Animals pass through walls so no point in building a base, apart from trying to RP which in this game gets boring fast.

Same applies for rafts - different materials used to build the raft hardly matter at all. Do not read what is written as information - I can barely notice any difference in the way the raft behaves if it is built using different materials. So why you need level 4 crafting to build the barrel raft when a twig one can do as much is beyond me. Or, why do you need to put an expensive brick floor on top of the raft base when you can go around with planks of wood. Also, bricks as a raft floor - are you serious? And if you are trying to haul barrels - no matter how big your raft is, you can barely load a barrel or maybe two (if you are lucky) before the raft starts sinking or going awry in circles. In my game, I managed to transport a couple of barrels using the starting dinghy - so the only reason to build a raft is speed and to be able to haul crates on a shelf. You cannot even build some sort of a half-wall to prevent stuff like tyres and barrels from falling off.

Resources are also bland and far not enough. Sure, the basics are there but oh my god, the crafting menu and UI is abhorrent. It is all over the place, you cannot favourite certain items, only pin what you will need to gather before crafting it but not actually craft it unless you go again through all the menus. Horrible. Variety is bad, soon you will end up with dozens of label makers, compasses, underwater torches, vehicle parts which are fairly useless if you already have 1 of each (or a few in the case of vehicle parts). Inventory is disorganised and honestly this is the only game where your empty hands count as a part of the inventory. On top of that, you can easily stack everything in boxes and then pick the boxes with the items inside, game seems to not care. But as soon as you have all the slots occupied and have - lets say 2 axes, you suddenly cannot equip neither as the game tries to split them into two slots - without any logic whatsoever. A total mess.

AI is also incredibly poor for a game this new. Animals get stuck on everything, combat is incredibly clunky and lacking anything interesting. Sound effects are lacking, soundtrack is nice but very short and easily becomes very repetitive as everything else in this game. And why the hell do the tiger sharks make a growling noise when biting?! They are sharks, not tigers. What's next? Horse flies that neigh??? Graphics can either be good or bad - some aspects are nice but they still feel very outdated.

All that being said, there are some good features. Procedural generation offers some replayability so long you are not incredibly bored by the time you finished the game the first time. The map itself is not infinite as the devs would like you believe, rather it consists of a few dozens small islets but scattered around differently every game. 

There is also an option to create custom maps and islands but the map editor is so frustratingly terrible to navigate, this options is borderline useless. Trying to build a simple island, raise tool actually lowers the land, the other tools are buggy as hell, did not stay there for more than 5 minutes, it was THAT buggy.

Overall, you will like the idea of this game, but not the game itself. There are way better games in the same category out there.
If you are still willing to buy, do not buy at full price. This game does not deserve to be priced that high.

EDIT: typos.

Let me start by saying that me and my friend have 18 hours on this game in the span of 2 days.

It has huge potential and I'm genuinely sad and disappointed by the current state of it, given that it has been a while since its release.

Unfortunately it has game-breaking bugs like:
-Icons of items disappear from inventory so you need to restart to fix it
-Getting stuck on building mode so you have to restart to fix it
-Not being able to destroy part of your raft so you lose on a a lot of resources
-Save doesn't work sometimes
-Client randomly crashes for my friend so if it happens on a trip I have to go find a way to make a tent to save before he joins back in.

!!!But the most annoying of all is the time it takes to sync on Co-op!!! 
Every time you want to play with a friend, it has to sync the world. At the start it took like 2-3 mins. As we progressed it took more and more. And because of the bugs we had to restart a few times per session and it became extremely frustrating.

TLDR: It has potential but its not playable yet until they fix some of the issues.

[h1]Nota Geral: 6.5[/h1]

[h3]Resumo:[/h3]
Stranded Deep me proporcionou uma verdadeira experiência de sobrevivência em um cenário isolado, com um ambiente visualmente atraente e mecânicas de crafting sólidas.

[h3]Pontos Positivos:[/h3]
Experiência imersiva de sobrevivência
Mecânicas de crafting bem desenvolvidas
Cenário visualmente atraente

[h3]Pontos Negativos:[/h3]
Interface do usuário às vezes desajeitada
Problemas de bugs e falta de recursos 

[h3]Considerações Finais:[/h3]
Embora Stranded Deep tenha seus desafios, como uma interface ocasionalmente frustrante, sua capacidade de engajar o jogador em um mundo de sobrevivência e exploração é indiscutível. É uma pena que alguns aspectos técnicos não estejam à altura, pois o jogo tem um grande potencial. No geral, oferece uma experiência divertida, especialmente para fãs do gênero de sobrevivência​​​​​​​​​​.

I know I have barely any time on this game but let me tell you everything I experienced before I requested a refund.  First, you're on a plane.  No dialogue, no narration, nothing and suddenly it crashes.  It tells you to exit the plane by swimming and get to the life boat.  Once there, it will tell you to press and hold E to paddle.  What it doesn't tell you is that the paddle is attached to the raft and you have to look at it, pick it up, and then press and hold E to paddle and control the life boat.  That's odd and annoying but I have eyes so it's fine.  Okay, let's get to the island.  Done.  Pick resources up on the island and open your backpack is the next objective.  Okay, let's assume E is the button to pick stuff up since that's what I used to paddle.  Oh, it is! BUT The item you picked up will stay in your hand and there is no button to put it down.  E doesn't work.  Left and right mouse button doesn't work.  Weird.  Will it work if I pick something else up with E? Nope.  Those items will go into the backpack.  Then there are Items that are highlighted with a name but I can't pick those up either.  That's fine, maybe I need a tool but I still have a rock in my hand!  And this is all while the controls are clunky as all heck.  The sensitivity is awful.  They want $20 for that?  And I bought this on sale for $10 and it's not even worth that if the controls are this bad with bad mechanics.  I don't recommend this game at all.

You play an hour just to die outta nowhere, all progress lost because you didn't save your game every time you blinked. Don't waste your money, just get The Forest.

A top notch survival game which focuses on the core elements of surviving a mass of islands with different resources. Many natural hazard/enemy's to defeat to survive, hunger & building of all kinds of things from rafts to buildings and it's as simple or complex as you'd like it to be. Players have "escaped" in 20ish hours, however I've leisurely going through at 31 hours and able to "escape" I just don't want to yet!

The game play is not too bad, although I've played enough to see there's not a ton of content or progression here. For example, most tools have one level (crude). A couple (knife, axe?) have a refined level. That's it. The different islands have nearly all the same resources. It feels like only the first quarter of this game was implemented.

My negative review is due primarily to the inventory system. There are way too many long hold button actions. Want to drop something from your inventory? Hold tab to go into inventory, long hold right mouse, wait, drop. Want to drop 10 things from your inventory? Do that 10 times in a row. Picking up things is nearly as bad. Chop some wood and you get to click pick up 4 times in row. You need to long hold a button to feed materials into the water still. Why? You have to have the material in your hand to do it (which also sucks), so it's not like you are going to accidentally feed it those materials.

Storage containers are just as bad. Removing 10 rocks from a container will take 12+ clicks/button presses.

Piloting a raft? Need to turn around to face the rudder, long hold a button to stop and then turn back around to long hold on the mast to pull the sails. Can't pull the sails while running the rudder. Can't look at your watch either, or hold a compass.

No auto pickup, no group/bundle drop.

This game managed to be incredibly boring nearly immediately. The inventory management is frustrating, the boating mechanics are awful, and it is possible to soft-lock the tutorial on the starting island resulting in the need to move islands at much too early of a time. I ended up restarting my game due to this and played until I had a the small shelter built (which is a requirement to save the game, regardless of difficulty selected, as far as I'm aware). 

At this point the game did not present me with any other options besides to construct a water purifier, which the starting island lacked materials to complete. This is in spite of the fact that I was extremely conservative with my materials as I had restarted my game due to the issues I had on my first go around. I ended up stopping my game as I was nearing the two hour cutoff for refunds and looked more into the future game play and it appears as though you simply paddle between islands gathering materials with no real purpose or progress.

The game is kinda fun if you turn off animal aggression, otherwise rage from taking damage from unknown sources will build up too quickly.

Pros:
- looting sunken ships
- coral reefs
- kinda like summer vacation for those who hasn't had a vacation in years
- objects can be tossed really far using dragging mechanism

Cons:
- everything is trying to kill you - animals and environment - and they are doing a great job
- why can't potatoes be baked?
- if the driver falls off the raft, the raft will leave. The chanses of catching it by swimming are very slim and only in the first 5 seconds. If you didn't swim at full speed with maximum physical points - it's GONE. Use your latest save
- super modest backpack space and stacking limits of 1 and 4 are just unfair
- drinking or eating more than 2 coconuts in a row will give the character diarrhea. I mean, sure, coconuts are fatty, but it's the only source of water on new islands
- tutorial will help understand controls but nothing indicates that there's a story or bosses (yea, there's cartographer, but it's not a traditional map and it's for some reason only accessible from main game menu - you gotta save and quit to see the map)
- islands are extremely alike and it's very easy to get lost even with a compass
- some controls are ridiculous - to use hobo stove one must equip meat (to hold it), drop it on the floor and use dragging control to drag each piece on the stove surface
- handling coconuts and other food is equally unnecessarily complex. Equip coconut, drop it on the floor, equip a knife or an axe, hit the coconut until it's peeled, pick it up, equip it, click left mouse button to drink. To skin fish it must also be dropped on the floor and then hold E to skin it one at a time
- tool belt is useless. You might think: it will free up space in my backpack since it has slots and [i] literally has a pouch on an icon [/i]. But no, you can assign some tool to the hotkey, but the tool is still taking space, and if you remove this tool from the backpack (maybe you don't need a building hammer when looting ships), it unbinds from the key so it's useless
- ammo you used on bosses sinks with the boss so you can consider yourself lucky if you pick 3 arrows out of 50

Amended my review after creating a few of my own islands in the editor for our online co-op play through, including a large "home island" with plenty of rocks, trees, shrubs, planks, game, etc. The game was much more fun for survival than the grind on standard, where resources are far too few (especially for more than 1 player) and resource respawn is too slow. 

That being added, it turned out to be fun co-op survival game. We've played through and completed many (The Raft, Green Hell, The Forest, etc.) and while this doesn't rank with the deepest, it's price is right for what it gives: good bang for your buck for a $20 game (even better if on Steam Sale), but not quite enough pow to justify a $30 game. The crafting and survival is deep for a $20 game, yet they don't overstep their vision. Nice game. And smart to include and island editor.

It costs just as much as Valheim and Valheim is better in every single way. Even on special I don't think it's worth it for solo play.

I primarily played this split-screen co-op (which Valheim does not have) and as I bought it on special I feel like I have my moneys worth as a group activity.

However the more I have played, the more I want to play Valheim. To start, the biggest let down has been the building; if there is a collision (even with a rock formation) you can't build there. Building stairs has to be over a platform not from the edge. Placing structures is buggy as heck. Building a raft is cool but placing structures on it sucks (they can only snap to the middle of a raft platform).

Farming heh, feels half finished; some things rot and spoil where others don't. Meat/cooked meat will spoil but if you leave it on the fire it wont. a bunch of the plants you can pick don't have a purpose.

Cutting trees leaves stumps you can't get rid of, half the shubbery you can't even get rid of which made a fantastic looking community island, horrible.

Base game islands are boring, community islands are mostly from older versions so have items with no use and floaty objects. Modding community is very small.

Sailing is ok the waves are nice. Diving around your island to explore sunken ships cool, but 20 meters away from an island there is just a drop to a bottomless ocean, no ocean exploring.

Animals will run around up in the air, clip through terrain. My character has shoes on, but stepping on a spiky starfish will poison me. Bumping a snake or lion-fish also poison.

This is far from a complete game, videos/screenshots make it look much better than what it is. Graphics are meh especially for the FPS you get.

If you are specifically looking for split-screen survival, buying on special is ok. Most of the cool mods appear to only work for player 1 tho.

This is one of those games where steams binary yes or no review score really makes it hard to provide a review as this is a great game at heart but it has a large number of issues which make it hard to give a binary recommend.

If you want to know what this game is like, it is essentially Raft with better graphics and you make your home on an island rather than your raft being your home. This is a classic case of a better looking game (graphics wise) does not equate to a better game (gameplay wise) and i have spent a reasonable amount of my time playing this game debating/pining to play Raft instead as while it is not as advanced it actually works.

I initially found this game as one of the games included in the playstation subscription. I spent 15-20 hours getting into it and noticed it was also on PC with the PC version having a much larger world, downloadable maps and mods so i then bought it on steam and started over.

Now i am glad i started over on the PC version as the world is much bigger and the main fun from this game (for me) is the exploration and building side but i immediately noticed a few differences between the two versions where the PS version was actually better than the PC version, such as when loading into the game each time you can choose if the enemies will be passive or aggressive which you can't do on PC although you can go into the save file and change it if you wish.

This leads us to the first issue i found. I started the game (on PC) with it set to passive as i was still getting into it but the first time i reloaded it i discovered the game had reset to aggressive. As there is no option to change it (like on the PS version) i searched to see how i could change it and found out this was a long standing issue and found out how to change it in the save file.

Without going into every single issue, throughout my time playing the game there have been numerous issues like this with a variety of 'workarounds' employed by the community and also suggested in official dev replies, some which work and some which don't. This is not uncommon with games and part of the reason i often prefer PC vs console is that there are often options available to fix issues with the game but what concerns me and dissapoints me about these issues is that when i search for sollutions i often find posts from as much as 5 years ago asking for advice on the issue, considering the game was only 'released' last year. The fact that many of the workarounds often don't work and you are stuck with the issue or as per my lastest issue where i returned to my home island to find a number of my storage crates had just dissappeared (finding posts mentioning this issue from at least 2019) means there can be no solution and you just have to suck it up.

For those reasons alone i cannot in all faith choose recommend and thus i have given it a thumbs down.

If this was still in early access i would have given this game a definite recommendation in the expectation that many of the games issues would eventually be fixed but instead of fixing these issues it seems time is being spent on 'improving' the game by taking away useful features like being able to interact the the sail/anchor while steering with the rudder...you probably won't fully understand how stupid that decision seems until you actually play the game...luckily there is a mod to revert that decision.

Having said that i would not flatly right off the game as i have had and am still having and plan to have many hours of fun exploring the game but that is solely because of the numerous creators of amazing islands that you can add to the game, not because of the base game itself which if nothing else the standard islands available in the game are very small, generic and quite bland as well as the small number of mods available for the game which make the game (reasonably) playable.

This is my personal oppinion but if you do play the game i wouldn't bother with having the world as aggressive, especially if you don't start on a modded island as even with experience and optimisation it can be impossible to actually get off the first island and start exploring depending if you actually have the basic materials on the first island to make a raft fast enough to avoid any sharks, which may or may not be around your island or islands you wish to explore initially and that sharks will constantly tip your raft over if they catch you. 

I started turning on passive purely because in my initial learnig starts it was impossible to get off my starting island in agressive mode and also as the game gives you zero information i was constantly getting poisoned and hurt without knowing why and while most dangers can be avoided or countered certain dangers cannot such as the unkillable poisonous sea snakes. If nothing else, most real animals, even dangerous ones will generally only attack humans if aggravated or provoked rather than automatically attack on sight and sharks only attack boats in the movies.

I wouldn't mind this so much if it wasn't for the fact that the main source of counters to being hurt is coconuts which don't respawn are are in very limited supply, especially if you don't play on modded islands. I understand that the premise of the game is to escape home rather than make a new life here but i feel that is one of the aspects where the dev hasn't understood who is likely to play the game and how they will enjoy playing it.


Overall i would say if you like this style of game, it is on sale, you have spare cash to burn, don't mind having to 'workaround' numerous issues and reasonably technically competent (are happy finding game files/manually installing mods in games etc) then give it a go. Be very prepared to be annoyed, frustrated and dissapointed by the various issues while playing the game though.

Stranded Deep is a very strange case of nostalgia rot.
I used to play this years ago when it was very early in dev stage, with a setup that struggled to keep it up running on a steady 12 FPS on lowest settings, and strangely enough, I sunk hours in it still.

Years have passed and here I am, starting it afresh, and low and behold, what is this broken mess? I can run the game more than fine now, on highest settings, and while the game looks amazing, the broken mess I have encountered was another thing, crazy how this time around the game felt more broken than years ago when it barely had a working set of feature to call it a game.

You can still get some fun out of it though, however, this is by no mean a finished game, or anything close to it. I thought COOP would make up all the fun, my and my friend couldn't bear it for than 30 minutes.

If you are looking to buy this game to play with your friend - DON'T.

I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone thinking of buying this co-op. The amount of absolutely jarring bugs, glitches and absolute garbage you'll have to deal with just isn't worth it. 

Before I go any further, I will say that solo is fine - you can probably play the game solo and you'll have a good time - if you're into games like this. 

But co-op... 

It feels like a solo game with co-op mode patched onto it right from the very moment you attempt to play together: 

* the exact same character (only choice being male/female)
* inability to set a fixed password
* inability to send a Steam invite to your friend (especially fun if your friend uses a Steam Deck)
* painfully excruciating loading time whenever you start the game... Oh my Gaben, I wanted to pull my hair out every time we tried playing/crashed/glitched/had to restart. 
* the glitches: flying pigs (just your normal game), stuck blueprints when trying to craft rendering you unable to do anything at all (forcing a restart of lobby which takes 2 years), LSD trips underwater with the inability to do anything (forcing a restart of the lobby which takes forever), being INVISIBLE to your friend (which is hilarious if you want to maroon them on an island but will probably force you to restart a lobby which takes an endless amount of time), among anything else I am too PTSD to remember. 

Now we did have some fun, admittedly. Certain elements of the game (like navigation and getting your bearings) are somewhat unique until you realise there is a map... OUTSIDE of the game and in the menu which, yep - forces you to restart your lobby which will take a millennium to sync back up. 

Just... no. Don't buy this if you are looking to play with a friend. It could have been so much better but you can just feel it's been done half-arsedly and it shows. 

If you're looking for a more enjoyable co-op experience - try Sunkenland. Game is still in Alpha as of me speaking and yet 10x more fun co-op than whatever this forever-loading, glitchy mess is.

I'm a huge fan of survival crafting games and this one fits in well in that genre, feeling like a mix of Subnautica, Raft, and The Forest. Single-player is fun, if a tad bit more intimidating. The "story" is vague and feels more like "something to do" rather than a directed story line, and I think this game feels in the best place as a sandbox game (no pun intended) over something like Subnautica that has a direct and progressive story. 

The problem with this game is it's co-op multiplayer. First off, the game is limited to 2-player co-op, which was not expected or easy to find out. Other similar games like Raft or Valheim put this paltry 2-player to shame if you want to play with friends. Second off, the multiplayer feels unfinished, the tutorial is disabled in multiplayer, meaning if you (like me and my partner did) jump right into multiplayer you are given no idea of how to work anything, and the menu does not give much help at all, forcing you to scour the internet for help. Then on top of that, the sync of both player's games is shoddy at best. Recently, after playing together for several hours we loaded in the next day and found that on my screen our house, raft, etc. were in their rightful place whereas for my partner the house was on the opposite side of the island and the raft embedded into it. She could no longer interact with objects I could see and I could watch her float above the ground as she climbed the invisible house. We were unable to remedy this problem.

So overall, I'd recommend this game for single player only, for players who enjoyed Subnautica or Raft on their own but I strongly warn against people hoping for a multiplayer experience like Raft, Valheim, or The Forest.

The game is fun and worth $20 or less.

However, if you are like me, and solely purchased this for co-op gameplay. Know you will have issues.

This game has had a multiplayer mode for apparently a few years now and is still facing the same constant crashing, disconnects and sync issues that it was in 2021.

On top of that, this game has no replay value and resources such as rocks are finite, which means you are on a time limit to beat the game.

A lot can be said about this game. Highly realistic and graphically beautiful. Definitely not made for lax gamers. It's hard, but really addicting. If you aren't one to push the limits of your comfort-zone, this game isn't made for you. I find that to progress in any way, you gotta get your butt in the water and face some sharks. And time management is key. I have restarted the game a few times just to get a hang of it before I started progressing. 

I definitely recommend playing with a friend if you are looking for an easier playthrough, though, it is a bit buggy. I do have issues every once in a while trying to connect to the lobby with a friend, but eventually it works and we have a lot of fun together. 

I really enjoy that you can make custom islands and make your own map. I've spent far too long just building a custom island.

If you have the patience to work with/through the bugs you come across every now and again, I highly recommend.

What it does well is get you used to surviving, exploring and making you want to gather resources; however after you've killed your upteenth shark and made a decent raft out of barrels there isn't much content left.

If you enjoy a more "realistic" survival game compared to the very arcade-y Sunkenland, or the very cartoon-y Raft, I highly recommend giving this a try.

One major con:
The multiplayer is honestly *horrible*, it sync's the world data to everyone as a loading screen when they join a game, and it takes around 5 minutes on a locally-switched network with sub-100ms latency. I can't imagine how long it would take for people living in different states or countries. If anyone get's DC'ed, *everyone* has to re-sync when they rejoin. Additionally, the islands seem to be balanced for 1 person, in terms of resources. It was tough with even just 2 players to get enough food and water. Stick to singleplayer.

This game has been in development since 2015, and despite years of excruciatingly slow development this game still feels unfinished and broken. In the short time Sunkenland has been out, they've managed to not only recreate all that this game had to offer (which wasn't much), but they did it better. Don't waste your money on this.

Ok, so after completing the game with all achievements I decided to share my thoughts. Stranded deep is a very good survival game, with lots of tool crafting, base building, cooking and hunting. Raw materials such as wood or stone are very limited and finite. You must explore lots of islands other than the first in order to proceed. I would say it is of moderate difficulty overall. The thing I disliked the most is how slow is your raft and how difficult it is to create a good portion of fuel. My main playthroguh lasted about 50 hours and got me 35/37 of achievements. The last 2 I got from a second playthrought in creative mode, without playing, by just running the game over night, when i slept. I did this for 5 nights. Texture quality is very high in my opinion and I find the game very beautiful. I encountered some bugs while playing, though not something that affected much my gameplay. Definetely recommending it ,especially to those who like similar games (Green hell, the forest, and others.)

I'm really starting to enjoy this genre thanks to this game. There is a lot of things that keep me hooked but a lot of things that don't. I just love the atmosphere of it all, the raft-building aspect, the animals, the graphics. Just nice but given all this, there's also a lot of things that could make this game so much better.

I find myself going from island to island with no actual purpose other than gathering loot, the mystery fades very quickly especially with the lack of variety of ships, buildings and island types - there's about 3 different looking islands, 5 different ship types and I feel that they could have really really added some mystery and variety here.

I love raft building, something about taking your entire "house" with you is something ive always loved but I'd wish they'd extend on this concept, like being able to add more to the raft than the default items, maybe like adding a bed or being able to build walls and roofs.

A lot of interaction and graphical glitches plague this game, graphical glitches especially getting too close to (sea) animals make it sort of frustrating approaching any of them; you get dragged by a shark and when you turn around it vanished into deep sea, what. The fact that this game has controller support amazes me, it works well within the gameplay but not at all within the cartographer or map builder, you have to go as far as disconnecting the controller & restarting the game to use the thing with a keyboard again. 

As for graphics, the game looks like a super modern RTX looking demo yet at the same time like they took a default unity starter template but in a good way.

TL;DR: Add more variety & mystery and extend on the raft building aspect.

EDIT: The new co-op is not good. Kicks one of you out every 20 mins and takes 10 mins or so to re-load the world.

This is more of a "meh" than a "yes", but still, overall, it's positive.
The whole idea of the game is pretty unrealistic, and so is the game, but that's not a bad thing, it keeps things simple. Open world and being able to do anything the world allows is nice, but it doesn't allow for too much.

The major general drawback of the game is the "slightly" wonky physics which sometimes causes things to go horribly wrong, so do yourself a favour and save often. Luckily, although the game disallows saving all the time and does not offer autosave, you can carry around the item which allows you to save almost everywhere and anytime (which makes the decision to require an item to save the game a really weird one).

There are only two things in this game which I would call "bad".
1. The raft seems to have no issues carrying a lot of wooden boxes and doesn't even sway much with you walking around on it. But putting an animal on it (like a [spoiler]"huge pig"[/spoiler]) or a [spoiler]Hammerhead shark[/spoiler] puts such a weight burden on it that the raft is barely keeping floated. Even a big raft does not help much there. The physics model of that behaviour is just too simple. It kills the fun. And I don't even start speaking about the weight of the [spoiler]barrels[/spoiler].
2. Hitboxes for animals - both you attacking them and other way around. It's impossible to ascertain why something happened. [spoiler]Snakes[/spoiler] half a meter away hit you without moving, you're stepping on [spoiler]Starfishes[/spoiler] which are half a meter away, [spoiler]Poisonous fishes[/spoiler] sometimes hit you half a meter through stones. [spoiler]Sharks and pigs[/spoiler] attack you and run "through" you, but you can't hit them with your weapon when they do.

Those two things make the game really take a downturn. I'd really love to have them fixed.

There are a few more minor issues, which should be fixed as well, like, you stand on the raft with something in your hand, move it down to where the raft is, and the raft gets displaced by stuff in your hand, making it spin, dip or accelerate without any reason, or the issue that stuff simply disappears into the floor or assets, mainly it's stones and clay which do that.

The "normal" difficulty is way too little of a challenge regarding food and water.

The game needs a few more prominent pointers of dangerous situations like dehydration, famine, low health, air, and especially it needs them *persistent* and not as a popup which is visible for like 3 seconds.

The issue that you can not use your second hand while steering the raft, not even looking at your watch for stats or holding a compass, despite the second hand being displayed idle and not in use all the time, is nervewrecking and infuriating.

There is literally almost no reason to build something on the island, except that you can't build something like a "cabin" on the raft. But actually there is no reason to build one except roleplaying, the house is not even rainproof.

I picked this game up because I was choosing between this and Fountain of Youth.  I really like Green Hell, and this game looks closer to that.  The one thing Green Hell is missing is crafting canoes, rafts, riverboats, etc., so I figured this game would do that.  And it does.

The UI is not as intuitive as GH, and the items have fewer uses.  For example, spoiled meat having no purpose, not even as bait for scavengers and fish, is nonsensical.  I also don't like not being able to use coconut halves as bowls to either cook with or collect rainwater.  

But overall, it's a pretty close analogue, and if you liked GH, then you'll probably like this too.

I really want to love this game but it keep pushing me back. Story is lame but who cares? It's a sandbox survival game and we just want to craft stuff and not starve. I like that you have to change island for resources and once you get a decent raft with a sail it's not a problem at all. Navigation is also quite easy. But there are little details that really annoys me like:
- Poison: It's omnipresent in the game and you get poisoned quite often by snakes, purple sea creature lying on the coast and fish. To get an antitode you have gather this pipi plant that should be present on most islands but it is a nightmare to find because it's a weak yellow over a green grass that it's everywhere. I spent the last 10 minutes looking for one and this is what I call bad gameplay. Once you start to farm, it become easier to have access to multiple of it but till you get there is a pain to find it.
- Bad UI: getting used to how to craft, select items, drop them, rotate, etc is a pain. Even when you get used to it you just have one question. Why?
- Mobs: I like a challenge when it comes to monsters but what I don't like is when the AI path finding is so bad that they keep doing zig zag all over the place or even flying! Yes, I was trying to shot a damn flying pig that was killing me.

You can get over a lot of stuff in the game but at times it feels like a chore without reward. Maybe I will give it a try a second time with a friend and see if I change my mind.

A Deep Dive into Disappointment: A Review of Stranded Deep

Stranded Deep, a game that promised an immersive survival experience, has unfortunately left me stranded in a sea of disappointment. The concept of the game, which seemed incredibly enticing, was overshadowed by a myriad of bugs, issues, and graphical problems that made the overall experience unplayable.

My partner and I set aside an hour to delve into the world of Stranded Deep, eager to explore its unique survival mechanics. However, our excitement was short-lived as we were met with a series of glitches that not only disrupted our gameplay but also necessitated complete restarts, erasing all our hard-earned progress.

One of the most glaring issues we encountered was visibility problems. There were instances where we couldn't see each other's characters, which significantly hampered our cooperative gameplay. This was further compounded by incessant beeping from our in-game watches, which served as a constant distraction, despite there being no apparent issues to warrant such alerts.

Crafting, a crucial aspect of any survival game, was also fraught with problems. Crafted items would often remain stuck on our screens, obstructing our view and making them uncollectable. This issue, in particular, was a significant hindrance to our gameplay, as it prevented us from fully utilizing the game's crafting system.

The game's concept, while intriguing, was unfortunately overshadowed by these bugs and issues. It was particularly disappointing as the co-op mode, the primary reason for our purchase, was rendered virtually unplayable. The potential for a unique and engaging survival experience was there, but the execution fell short.

In conclusion, Stranded Deep, while promising on the surface, was a deep dive into disappointment. The game's numerous bugs and issues, coupled with its graphical problems, made for an overall unplayable experience. As a result, I found myself compelled to request a refund, a decision I made with a heavy heart given the game's potential. I hope the developers address these issues in future updates, as the concept of Stranded Deep is one that deserves to be fully realized.

Hate to leave a bad review, sounds like the game is great on single player. 

Unfortunately, co-op is really the only way I play most survival games. From inventory bugging out so my slots were unusable to us not being able to see each other's items or built structures, not to mention having to drop something every time I wanted to use something already in my inventory because it for some reason wants to move the single stacked item to take up another slot for me to use it, just too many bugs to list. The game has so much potential if they can just fix the multiplayer. Unsure when/if that will be, as the last update was in December. :(

EDIT: We decided to give it another go after I left my initial review. Despite the bugs still being ever-present, we did manage to make a bit more progress than our first few attempts, so it's incredibly hit-or-miss as to what kind of experience you'll have with co-op. 

I just can't recommend the game in its current multiplayer state, especially not for a 1.0 release. We might keep struggling along with it, but I would suggest others wait for a big sale on this to buy it. Full price is too much, especially if you're like us and really only want to play it with people. The bugs make it feel like it's still in very early access, though I will say the graphics are lovely. 

If all you're in it for is single player, go for it, sounds like you'll have a good time.

I WANT to like this game. It's been out a short awhile, had a sale, bought copy and for a friend.

WARNING: Co-OP is Broken..  
--Now, newer game, maybe new crew, awesome. Learning & creating a game is great. so they get plenty of lee-way on this, plus they have to compete with other similar games (Like Raft) and they start with what i wanted to try in that game, the base building part. Nice world creation idea to.

The part I must WARN people who are looking for co-op or any multiplayer, the game forces host, and all other players to 'sync' up, pulls out all the players into a new load screen, which may or may not actually connect.  (black screen with loading word on it) so you can't even play while others attempt to connect, (if it was seconds, or maybe 1 min game freeze, doable) but sitting 4-10 minutes to have it connect, not feasible. (which, while doing this, put us over the "time played" to not qualify for refund)

Until they get this fixed, it really made the whole interest of doing this with friends and exploring the world of this game strictly unplayable.  

Disclaimer: besides attempting to join/create other sessions online, I have NOT explored the single player experience, as a general review of other reviews, the amount of bugs and play for a single player does not appeal to me nor do i have confidence that it's been polished enough to be tolerable play for a full-release game.    I 100% have the feeling of this is/should be a beta/public test/alpha state of development of this game.

I've had this game since around 2016, since then I have been on and off the game, but as the years went on the game stayed the same. SD was MUCH better back in the day when the broken things were getting fixed, the game was being actively developed. I recommend this game BUT not for:

1. Co-op, its broken
2. A complete gaming experience, there are bugs galore, save issues and other things that could be fixed if devs were active or the project was sold to a new team
3. Its worth about $8.99 max with what the future holds for SD, and with each year that price goes WAY down.


But this game still holds more challenge and replay value than 65% of AAA+ titles... 


I would 120,000% change to DOES RECOMMEND if the devs were active or the project gets pickedup by a new team.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Stranded Deep is a survival game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Your plane crashes in the ocean and you have to get to the lifeboat and survive.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game starts off with you in the plane  as it goes down and then you must leave the plane and board the lifeboat and paddle to a nearby island. My main issue with the game is there is no real winning. You go from tiny island to tiny island. In a dozen hours I never found an island I couldn't stand in the middle of and see the ocean on all sides. The islands don't have sufficient supplies to establish a base and there is no point in setting down roots on an island to live from one boring day to the next.

Crafting leaves a lot to be desired. It starts off with having to create a Water Still. You need to create a coconut flask, an item that is not in your crafting list. You can eventually find one, but if you have a raw coconut and lashing you can craft one. Once you get poisoned you might as well just lay down and die because you won't be able to find the items required to create an antidote and death is the only other option. But, you don't even know what to look for as it isn't in the crafting recipes you have. Having all of the items required for a Boat Motor in my inventory, and it still doesn't come up as a crafting option until you equip your hammer. So, I try to craft the motor, but can't find a way to attacch it to the lifeboat. So all of those cool vehicles you see on the store page, you're going to need to search the web for how to get them, because they aren't in your crafting book. 

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
The game has promise, but is hamstrung by its crafting, small islands, and no clear goals.

[h1]System Specs[/h1]
Intel i7-8086K Coffee Lake 6-Core 4.00GHz CPU
Crucial Ballistix Sport AT 2666 MHz DDR4 RAM (16GB x 2)
ASUS GeForce RTX 2080 Overclocked 8G GDDR6

TL/DR - This is the greatest unplayable game in my library.

Stranded deep is a fantastic game. The survival aspects are difficult without being dark souls, the crafting system is the right level of wonk and sense that you need for a fun but not tedious survivalcraft, the controls are simple to understand without being press-button-to-win, the enemies are balanced enough that there's going to be a bit of strategy on new islands even into the late game, without being unfair at low levels.

Unfortunately, the physics engine is a mess, and multiplayer has frequent game-breaking glitches. The game will decide that taking certain items (like logs or tree heads) into your hands means that the chest you were about to put it in needs to be yeeted into the distance, sometimes putting items into a secured chest on a raft will result in the item both having physics where it was in your hands while also being inside the chest, resulting in a tipped raft...meat isn't separated into cooked and uncooked, so if you eat too fast you might get poisoned by raw meat even if you had enough cooked meat in the same stack...

And when you get to the multiplayer, sometimes the game will decide that only the host needs to be able to interact with items, resulting in the other players needing to disconnect and reconnect (which temporarily boots the host to a 5 minute loading screen) in order to eat/drink what's in their hand.

This isn't even halfway through all the glitches I encountered, and my review is already too long. This game is glorious and has a heck of a lot of promise, but the frequency of the glitches mean it's not really playable in its current state.

If you intend on playing co op do not buy this until devs have resolved the bugs and glitches. Almost 20 hours spent on this game each between my partner and I and while the mechanics and UI is fun and interesting (actually makes you think and look at guides rather than being dead simple) the bugs are the lowlight here. 

We had rafts fly out from under us while sailing because my partner was holding a log, rafts flipping over as I was dragging a shark to shore, coming back to our island and realizing 5 containers have suddenly gone missing (setting us back a considerable amount of time as we had lost all our tools and rare items). Not being able to interact with items/containers that one of us had dropped and the list goes on. While the game is fun, I'm not sure we would continue playing in the state that it is in currently as our progress could suddenly be lost for no apparent reason. 

On a last note, imo if a game makes you look at guides and tutorials, the devs did not do a good job on showing the basics and tutorials. Eg. the fuel still should have a prompt to say that it requires potatoes to make fuel, regular enemies in the game should have some sort of visible health bar and they shouldnt be able to glitch out of the island, running into the ether.

Pretty fun and challenging game. Doesn't make my pc explode (im on a laptop btw). Not too challenging to make me wanna quite the game, but still difficult enough to force me to think ahead and be careful while using rare resources. Most enemies are relatively simple to fight, but do have some nuances that make them interesting. For instance, the giant crab is weaker than the hog in terms of health, but if you shoot it with and arrow or throw your spear at it, your projectile breaks, so it forces you into melee. The limited resources initially felt burdensome and grindy, but when I realized that you're supposed to overcome this by exploring, it became a lot more fun and interesting. There is one really annoying bug that I have encountered where pressing the mouse buttons no longer does anything, which can be frustrating, Luckily reloading your save does fix the issue, but you can only save at shelters so you may lose a lot of progress which can really suck. Hope this review helped.

The game is intriguing and a fun take on the survivalists experience. It has a really fun looting and crafting system with a skill tree and leveling aspect to it. These are traits to making a fun, lasting experience. I rate the game 2 / 5 stars, and not 5 due to the subsequent reasons.

The only caveat which caused my friends and I to stop playing a couple hours in was the total lack of probably the most important resource: fiber. 

Everything seems to need fiber, and your small island has a very small amount. You need fiber to do practically everything, even going to a new island that to find more fiber. You can plant the fiber trees, but it's level locked and to unlock it you need to craft a multitude of items that all need fiber. The plant plot also needs a bunch of fiber. 

The main issue with all this is it doesn't respawn, and you'll find at best 8 fiber pieces on your island. It baffles me seeing the store page images showing all that progression because I know for us it was impossible to progress due to lacking basic resources every playthrough.

Do you like Castaway? Do you like The Bermuda Triangle and it's mysteries? Do you enjoy having a diet that consists purely of seafood and coconuts? If yes, then Stranded Deep is for you. 
This game is janky sometimes, lets be honest, and multiplayer NEEDS voice chat or label makers to work but the game has come so far since launch it's incredible. From crafting your own seafaring vessel to taking on the skies in a handcrafted gyrocopter, Stranded Deep's exploration and crafting never ceases to be an absolute blast. Getting bored of the standard archipelago you spawn in by default? Try surviving in a random gen world full of new places to explore or check out the countless community made maps. All in all it is a very strong survival experience full of places to explore and secrets to uncover, Happy exploring, and mind the Sharks!
