If this was labelled as "Early Access" I might have been able to recommend it. The game does some things good, hence why I've played it plenty of hours. But if I knew about all the bad things I'll list below, I'd choose something else to buy.

• Very bad view distance, even on highest settings. Strange because this is about being out on the ocean looking out for islands and different objectives. Game even has binoculars.
• A ton of fish you can't hurt or interact with.
• Some thing that look very dangerous are completely harmless and no interaction (same as above).
• Some trees you can chop down, some you can't.
• Several items that are pretty much useless that you can gather several stacks of but you can only craft 1-2 things with, that you only need to craft once. And the game makes you think you'll unlock a lot more things to craft as you level up.
• Quite little raft options.
• Lots of inconsistencies.
• Zero feedback if you do something incorrect with the wrong tool or so.
• Fruit and vegetables never respawning so they can completely go extinct in your world. And they seem to be able to de-spawn as well if you get close to them, not see them and walk away. This can make it impossible to complete the story.
• Extremely minimal guiding + random generated world layout = You might end up like me who basically unlocked everything, built everything, maxed my skills, found 90% of islands before finding any story progression/bosses.
• Flying pigs, erratic animal movements, weird melee hitboxes.
• Bosses can re-spawn while you are fighting them.
• A useful world map in the main menu that you can't access is in the actual game while playing.
• Bad story (almost no story).
• Useless furnitures that could easily have added features.
• Got pretty grindy and repetitive quickly due to lack of content and story elements.
• Why are there not metal tools but you can build metal houses? And why is there an achievement to build 10 metal furnitures, but the only metal furniture to build are 1 table and 1 shelf (both purely cosmetic lul).
• Sucky keybinding system for binding tools to hotkeys (I ended up not using it at all).

OK. It basically feels unpolished and not fully complete. I still enjoyed the little progression there was; building my first own raft, getting strong enough to repeatedly kill sharks and try to get some achievements.

I guess since this has been in early access since 2015(?) and fully released 2021 I don't have any hope to fix any of this. Fingers crossed though ^^ I think there are more recently developed games that are better.
If you look for a survival game which can be CO-OP as a benefit. That's it. Islands are small so expedition is kind of boring and repetative but inside the ocean is scarry. 7/10 buy on sale

So! Dev peeps, This section is just for you oooor I guess for anyone who wants to read it, idc. The chance a dev even reads this is slim to none, but! here we go. Building in this game could be so much more fun with three little changes; 
  - Plantable, growable trees to replenish wood supplies.
  - Relaxing the overzealous "cannot build here" thing because you're a pixel too close to something, sometimes it's something not even visible.
  - Bringing walls and stairs down about a brick to prevent the huge gaps for buildings more than one level tall before a roof section. This doesn't seem like a big deal until you want to build a lighthouse!

There is a 4th which would be pretty easy to implement I think, (and this one's more for weirdos like me) give the garden plots an option with a key press or when selecting to build them to auto-level instead of matching terrain. That way players could plant their plants flat if they chose, or simply place one to level out a dip or something. Anyway, hope to see this game get better in the future!

I wake up in an inflatable yellow survival raft with no idea what to do. I see a shark swimming around me and it bumps my raft. I panic and grab my oar and start paddling to a visible distant island. Once on the island I pull my raft on the sandy beach and cheer. My stomach growls and I realize how hungry and thirsty I am. I see a coconut in a tree and climb the tree. I see a rock and make it into a sharp tool. I smash the coconut open. Sweet delicious food! I eat the whole coconut and start to feel sick. I hear a noise and turn around. A GIANT CRAB starts chasing me!! I see a big wild boar and think I'll let it and the crab fight each other so I can run away. The boar smashes into me and flings me into the air a few times before killing me. 

I wake up in an inflatable yellow survival raft with no idea what to do...

What I can say is take your time to learn the ins and outs. Using a quick press and a long hold of "C" to craft items that you pick up is your best friend. And "Tab is your Backback" Make a Coconut flask, a Water still, and a food smoker as fast as you can. If you can do these and then spear hunt fish you should be golden and good to go to work your way up. Also, the raft has emergency supplies if you need them.

Just be careful of Purple pokey starfish, sharks, crabs, snakes, boars, and you will be the best castaway survivor out there.

Stranded Deep promises a thrilling and immersive experience as you struggle to survive on wild deserted islands. Unfortunately, this shipwreck of a game fails to deliver on its enticing premise, leaving players stranded in a sea of frustration and disappointment, especially after coming to it after playing Raft and Valheim. 
First and foremost, the game's visuals are lackluster and fail to impress. While the tropical island setting initially seems appealing, the graphics quickly reveal their outdated nature. The textures are dull and muddy, lacking the level of detail one would expect from a game released in this era. The lack of visual polish severely hampers the immersion and fails to capture the awe-inspiring beauty of a tropical paradise.
Stranded Deep's gameplay mechanics are equally underwhelming. Multiplayer is an insult – after restarting several times, the game crashed on the third island when I tried to build a roof for my shack. The survival elements, which should be the core focus of the game, feel shallow and tedious. Gathering resources quickly becomes a monotonous chore, as the game lacks depth in its okay-ish crafting system. Building a simple structure in this game is a test of patience and will and it feels as satisfying as befriending an angry eel. 
Furthermore, the game's AI is a constant source of frustration. Whether it's the erratic behavior of wildlife or the clumsy movements of enemy creatures, the lack of consistency and realism in their actions is glaring. These shortcomings break any semblance of immersion, making it difficult to suspend disbelief and truly engage with the game world.
Another major flaw is the lack of meaningful objectives and progression. While survival games often rely on the thrill of exploration and the sense of accomplishment that comes from overcoming challenges, Stranded Deep fails to provide satisfying goals or a compelling narrative. As a result, the gameplay quickly becomes a repetitive loop of mundane tasks without any sense of purpose or direction.
Moreover, the game suffers from a number of technical issues and glitches. From frequent crashes and save file corruptions to problematic collision detection, these technical hiccups further undermine the already disappointing experience. It's frustrating to invest time and effort into a game, only to have it hindered by an abundance of technical difficulties.
Lastly, the developers' lackluster support and minimal updates add insult to injury. Despite the game's numerous issues, it seems that the developers have largely abandoned it, leaving players stranded with their frustrations. The lack of meaningful updates and communication with the player community suggests a lack of commitment and care, further exacerbating the game's overall disappointment.
In conclusion, Stranded Deep fails to live up to its promising concept and falls flat in almost every aspect. Lackluster visuals, shallow gameplay mechanics, frustrating AI, absence of meaningful objectives, technical issues, and a lack of developer support all contribute to a deeply unsatisfying experience. It's difficult to recommend Stranded Deep when there are far superior survival games available on the market that provide a more engaging and polished experience.
IT WAS THE DEFFINITION OF GOOD

First off, like most survival sims, I bought this for the multiplayer.

Initial impressions were pretty good, the water grind was a little bit rough, but the game seemed fine enough as far as survival sims go, then came the first disconnect/desync of what ended up being many.

Every time you reconnect to a server on this game, you and everyone attached to the server have to "sync world", a process that takes a good few minutes, even when everyone you know has a great connection, almost no ping and relatively beefy rigs.

Reconnecting wouldn't be an issue if the server was stable, unfortunately it's just not, we probably lost connection a good 5-6 times over our roughly 2 hours of owning the game.   A few minutes every time this happens means we basically wasted 15-20 minutes just waiting for multiplayer to connect, however the final nail in coffin was the world desyncs.

Stuff you build, objects you harvest and even enemies sometimes wont show up for everyone.   Half the time, what you build simply refuses to function, the prompt may be there but nothing happens when you use said object, also, getting attacked by a boar/shark only you can see, or getting poisoned by something invisible is incredibly frustrating.

After dealing with all the disconnects and then this, I just cant imagine dealing with these issues over a period of time lasting longer than a couple hours, making this the second game I've ever refunded on Steam.

This game's been out since April 2020 man, issues like this should be fixed by now, or so you'd think; I'd honestly still be playing it if so.

There are some nice ideas and the graphics and core gameplay loop are serviceable BUT (a) survival isn't that challenging, in the beginning you mostly need to ration rocks (b) the interface is awful. Some of it is due to being designed for both PC and console, which on the one hand does increase the userbase and thus developer ressources. On the other, you still end up with a poorly designed PC interface which should mean worse reviews and lower PC sales. Either way, I ended up fighting the interface much more than the environment for no discernible reason. The radial inventories are merely wasteful, the biggest issue is that you can't carry big stuff with both hands (at, for instance, the price of losing access to the rest of your inventory while you do so) but have to drag everything awkwardly holding right mouse button. This extends to smaller stuff as well, you can place meat in the smoker, but have to drop it on the floor and then right mouse fling it onto the hobo stove. There is a skill levelling system but it's no barrier to crafting (which is good) but also doesn't for instance allow you to bypass annoying animations at higher levels so not sure what it is needed for.
The loot is weird, lots of compasses and motor parts, very few stones and most importantly, little in the way of dual use. You either have the part you need or you don't. You practically never end up regretting a particular crafting decision because later finds open up different opportunities, it's very simple and linear in that respect. Still, if the interface was good, this wouldn't matter much.

I first played this back in 2015 during the survival/crafting crazy.
It had potential but it was mostly a janky, grind to try and keep your bars up long enough to explore.
It mostly seemed to lean into the worst of the mid 2010's survival game trope.

8 years later I decided to give it another shot.
It looks marginally prettier now, but it's still not worth you money.
Even if you like survival/crafting games, this game is not fun.
Your food and water bars deplete ridiculously fast, but eating or drinking too much will make you shit yourself, depleting both of them even more.
Its set in the tropics, but you have an 'SPF' bar than basically makes you stand and do nothing in the shade while it takes minutes to refill, thats when the game actually registers you being in shade.
Movement is janky, your stamina and oxygen bars for running and swimming are gone in about 10 seconds and theres even bars for how good you are at
[checks notes]
pulling leaves off of bushes.

Basically go play The Forest or literally anything else. This game is so lazy I'm shocked it didnt become abandonware when the survival/crafting crazy died out.

MIXED REVIEW

1. More good to say than bad. Overall the aesthetics and atmosphere of the game is virtually unparalleled in my opinion. The excitement of exploring, the way the shipwrecks and coves make your imagination ponder not only the games story, but if there's places like this on Earth that still lay untouched (unlikely - but nice thought).

2. Upkeep is annoying. Having to refill fibre into water collectors takes enjoyment out of the game somewhat. I understand that this is a survival but it just feels unnecessary. 

3. Getting poisoned at the start of the game is possibly the most irritating thing ever. Either make antidote relatively easy to come across or remove altogether - such a silly mechanic in the early game.... ESPECIALLY for new players (makes you just want to stop playing).

4. BUGS/GLITCHES - my raft which I spent 7 hours working towards got stuck on some shipwreck and even in fly mode I couldn't budge it. Finally, after 20 minutes or so of faffing around, I got it loose but now it is unusable because I cant right click and move it????? HOW DOES THAT MAKE ANY SENSE? It made me extremely angry and I quit the game, when I revisit I will likely remake using the console but I would rather you just not put shallow level ships on every island which easily interfere with the raft. Make an invisible wall so you cant go near or something.

Lastly, I like the game a lot, exploring and playing feels both therapeutic and exciting.... BUT,  it genuinely feels unplayable at times due to BS issues. Please fix.

I rate positive because for £15.99 I would still have purchased and played this game.

EDIT: Several months later I tried playing the game, 7 hours in and a bug where I died shortly after saving meaning that I am stuck in a death loop when entering the game. Seriously guys? Several people have reported this issue over the years and you haven't done anything about it? Earliest report of this was 3 years ago....

First, this game is not for the "fast action" crowd, it's very slow and deliberate. Don't get me wrong, i do enjoy playing this game but i have been giving suggestions, for years, only to see NONE of them implemented so my thoughts are, "Why should i push a game with coders who don't listen?"

What finally caused me the "thumbs down" on this game: Lack of any "mapping" system or a mountable compass to (easily) keep up with your direction and places you've discovered. You have to give up stability (risk falling off the raft) to "anything" while sailing and, sometimes, you get glitched into the water and lose your craft. There should be a "mountable" area for your compass to aid you in sailing but isn't.

And, really, the premises of this game is a little underwhelming: Find the big ship and the parts to leave.

Title: Stranded Deep: A Thrilling Survival Experience

Rating: 4/5

Stranded Deep is a captivating survival game that thrusts players into an unforgiving world of deserted islands and treacherous waters. Developed by Beam Team Games, this title offers a unique blend of exploration, crafting, and survival mechanics, delivering an immersive and adrenaline-pumping experience.

One of the standout features of Stranded Deep is its atmospheric setting. As you find yourself marooned on a remote island in the Pacific Ocean, the game's stunning visuals and attention to detail immediately draw you into its world. From the shimmering blue waters to the lush vegetation and diverse marine life, the game excels at creating a visually striking and believable environment.

The core gameplay revolves around the struggle for survival. You'll have to scavenge for resources, hunt for food, and build shelter to protect yourself from the elements. The crafting system is robust, allowing you to combine various materials and items to create tools, weapons, and even rafts to explore nearby islands. The sense of progression is satisfying as you gradually upgrade your gear and expand your survival capabilities.

What sets Stranded Deep apart from other survival games is its focus on realism. The game incorporates elements such as hunger, thirst, and injuries, adding a layer of complexity to the survival mechanics. You'll have to manage your limited resources wisely, making tough decisions about when to venture out for supplies and when to conserve energy. The threat of dangerous wildlife and environmental hazards keeps you on your toes, creating a constant sense of tension and excitement.

Exploration is a key aspect of the game, and Stranded Deep delivers in this regard. Each island you encounter holds its own mysteries and unique resources, encouraging you to venture further and discover hidden secrets. From underwater shipwrecks to ancient ruins, the game rewards curiosity and encourages you to fully explore its vast open world.

While Stranded Deep offers a thrilling and immersive survival experience, it does have a few shortcomings. The game can sometimes feel repetitive, especially in the early stages, as you follow similar routines to gather resources and survive. Additionally, the absence of a compelling narrative or long-term goals may disappoint those seeking a more story-driven experience.

Despite these minor drawbacks, Stranded Deep succeeds in delivering a captivating survival game that will keep you engaged for hours on end. Its stunning visuals, realistic mechanics, and sense of exploration make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're a fan of survival games or looking for a challenging and immersive experience, Stranded Deep is well worth your time.

[OLD REVIEW]
So guys, let's fix this:
- The maps need to allow you to "name" or "label" the islands you have been to. If you were able to make fabric in the game, build entire settlements, water sources and whatnot, you would also be able to make your own map. Now, if this IS in the game and I'm just not seeing it...make it a little more accessible.
-Sunburn progression is a bit fast. Some people do not burn that quickly and not having plants that respawn or regrow doesn't make a whole lot of sense.  I mean, what's the point of building a house on an island that has little to no resources left...yeah yeah "just go to another island"...but not having a map (like I mentioned above) can make island hopping a huge hassle. I have literally had to make arrows by manipulating objects on the island and using the label maker on items to explain to myself how to get back to my "home" island. Like....make this a SMIDGEN easier by allowing us to create our own maps. Please? 
-Not being able stack crates is just...well it's just dumb. If we have to navigate to other islands with our tiny little hands and backpack AND you've given us crates (which store very little), can we please be able to stack them on our rafts so that we can transport our crap back and forth? Like....we would totally do that if we were actually surviving, right? I would. Now, you CAN attempt to stack them but if the wind blows just right, they will literally "explode" and SINK (even though they are made of wood) and everything you just traversed across the expanse of the sea to collect for your little island is GONE, forever...including the crate. You can't just swim down there and get it, either.
-Some of the harder to make tools should last longer. Having to rinse and repeat all the above stuff just to make a sturdy knife, just to turn around and have to do it ten more times gets really tedious. More tedious than it actually would be in real life, because plants would grow back eventually, saplings would turn into adult trees, you can cut those down, thus spreading the seed and you'd think a new tree would start growing, right? 
Come on ya'll. This game has some serious potential. I'd pay twice what I paid for a game with like this with all the fixings.

Enjoyable survival game, nice game play loop. 

There are bugs/glitches, though they don't "significantly" detract from enjoying the game. Things like fish flying above the water, watching a boar render in the distance - 20 feet in the air, abruptly fall, then run circles in the air. Cutting down a tree to watch it go flying across the island. Re-arranging barrel scrap 50 times before the game allows you to build it in to your raft. You know, funny bugs/glitches - minor irritations at worst.
Navigating by compass and still getting lost.. feels bad. It's very fortunate that the "Cartographer" option is there to see where in the world the player is, but seeing that your base is due East, you go due East, then find you're on the bottom of the map... yeah.

All this being said, minor irritations aside, I still recommend this game. It's fun, picturesque, enjoyable and frankly (regardless of the annoying potato grind) - I am very much looking forward to flying the Gyrocopter! That being said, I've had my raft motor for ages but absolutely no fuel because finding potatoes was.. challenging (after the one on my starter island died before I knew how incredibly important it was).

OH! Don't step on purple star looking things! Lost my first game file that way because I couldn't level up fast enough to make poison Antidote.

Fluffy Jiggly Japanese Cheesecake

Ingredients
for 6 servings

7 tablespoons butter
4 oz cream cheese
½ cup milk
8 eggs, yolk
¼ cup flour
¼ cup cornstarch
13 large egg whites
⅔ cup granulated sugar
hot water, for baking
powdered sugar, for serving
1 pt Strawberries, for serving

Preparation
Preheat the oven to 320°F (160°C).
In a small pot over medium heat, whisk together the butter, cream cheese, and milk until melted and smooth. Remove from the heat and let cool.
In a large bowl, whisk the egg yolks until smooth, then slowly drizzle in the cream cheese mixture, stirring until evenly combined.
Sift in the flour and the cornstarch, whisking to make sure there are no lumps.
In another large bowl, beat the egg whites with a hand mixer until soft peaks form. Gradually add the sugar while continuing to beat until stiff peaks form.
Fold about ¼ of the egg whites and into the yolk mixture, then repeat with the remaining egg whites until the batter is evenly combined.
Grease the bottom of a 9 x 3-inch (23 x 7.5 cm) round cake pan, then line the bottom and sides with parchment paper. If using a spring form pan, make sure to wrap the bottom and sides completely in foil twice to prevent any leakage.
Pour the batter into the pan and shake to release any large air bubbles.
Place the pan into a larger baking dish lined with 2 paper towels at the bottom. The paper towels ensure that the heat is distributed evenly along the bottom of the pan. Fill the larger pan about 1-inch (2-cm) high with hot water.
Bake for 25 minutes, then reduce the heat to 285°F (140°C), and bake for another 55 minutes, until the cake has risen to almost double its original height.
Remove from oven, and carefully invert the cake onto your dominant hand and peel off the paper. Be extremely careful, the cake will be hot. You can also invert the cake onto a plate, but this will cause the cake to deflate more.
Dust the top of the cake with powdered sugar, then slice and serve with strawberries while still warm!
Enjoy!

Stranded Deep is a game which is difficult to recommend for a number of reasons, but ultimately over the time I spent with it I did have a lot of fun - your own experience will probably depend on how critically some of the flaws I'll point out below matter to you. There's also a bit of a balancing act when considering the game as it was almost entirely developed by just two people and in that respect is a very ambitious title, but on the other hand there are many issues which were tolerable when it was in early access but should not still be present now we essentially have the finished product. For context, my 125 hours of gameplay consists of several incomplete playthroughs where I got bored and didn't play for a few months at a time, and one complete playthrough which I eventually worked up the motivation for.

Graphically the game looks nice on first glance with a suitably colourful tropical environment, decent water textures and some nice lighting effects. Up close however everything is quite low res, and worse still the game suffers from the worst object and texture pop-in I've seen in a long time, it reminds me of an old PS1 game where large objects on the horizon suddenly appear out of nowhere and textures remain in super low resolution even at quite close distances. For a game which involves a lot of long distance exploration in an open world this isn't great.

The audio effects are perfectly fine overall. The music adds a bit of atmosphere and the sound effects are generally ok, although the very limited 'voice acting' (in quotations because it's really just the odd single word comment from your player character) gets repetitive quickly.

The UI is functional although the crafting menu isn't the best, it would be nice if it remembered where you last had it open so you didn't need to scroll through every single time. Also, while the game makes it quite clear what items are needed to craft various recipes, it doesn't always give a great indication of what the resulting product is actually used for. I had played for a very long time for example before I discovered that a meat smoker isn't actually exactly the same as a campfire for cooking food.

Gameplay wise, Stranded Deep suffers from the exact same issue that most survival games do - a rapidly diminishing difficulty in the survival aspect itself. The first few days in game definitely require a bit of careful thought with regard to gathering food and water and so on, but once you've crafted even just a basic encampment it becomes very unlikely you'll be in danger of dying of thirst or starvation or whatever. Another issue with the crafting is that a number of the objects you can make are actually pretty useless in the grand scheme of things. Now admittedly if you just treat the game like a sandbox and don't worry about the endgame (which is entirely optional to complete) being able to build houses and so on is quite fun, but there's hardly anything to furnish your creations with and from a survival point of view a massive house is really no more useful than the simple shelter you can build right from the start, other than perhaps providing a bit of storage space. Likewise you have things like toolbelts which you might imagine allow you to increase your inventory space but in reality just provide some quickslots for accessing items which isn't really worth bothering with.

Regarding the game world, once the survival aspect has been dealt to, which as I mentioned above will happen pretty quickly, the emphasis switches to exploring the game world. This is fun to begin with as the different islands will have different loot and resources to find, but it very quickly becomes apparent that there is very little variety in the randomly generated islands. They essentially just fall into two categories - big islands with pine trees and wild pigs, and small islands with palm trees and crabs. Once you've visited three or four islands close to your starting island you will have pretty much seen everything the game world has to offer. It is worth mentioning that player created maps and islands are readily downloadable and this is probably the best way to play from an exploration point of view but it's a shame the default content seems so limited in scope.

Finally, it's worth mentioning that the game world itself is still fairly glitchy - it's very common to see animals spawning in mid air, fish swimming through the air during storms, wild pigs running around underwater on the beach, and so on. None of these issues are game breaking for sure, but they do hurt immersion.

So with all the problems I've pointed out above it might be difficult to see why I'm giving this a recommendation, but ultimately if you're looking for a survival game which is just you against the environment this is probably one of the more complete games available. Buy it when it's on sale and you probably won't regret it, but expect to constantly feel like you're playing a game which is still in pretty early access.

This is an updated review after I replayed it early 2023. 
I would still avoid this game. It is visually appealing, but that is about as far as it goes. The game feels like it is still in early Alpha stage with so many bugs and glitches it just makes it a frustrating experience. From snagging on scenery and jarring transitions between water and land, it just breaks you out of the immersion the game tries to give you. Simple physics like jumping and climbing is just too strange a process. 

For example, to get on top of a boat, there is a ladder, but the ladder isn't usable. For some unknown reason you have to climb up the wall, which is a combination of running headlong into the wall while randomly mashing jump. Only occasionally will your character even jump. If you are in water, you will randomly find yourself unable to surface as you get snagged on a stray atom that means you have to WASD yourself like mad to get free.

Building is a nightmare. It goes white when you can build and red when intersecting with scenery. Makes sense. Except when it doesn't. Want to build a raft base on that flat bit of beach? No chance. There is a grain of sand that is too high. You have to wade out into chest-deep shark infested water and try to put some planks down. 

How about building a home? Nope. Same issue. That non-interactive leaf in the way means you will have to have a 2m x 2m hole in the floor where you cannot place that piece of floor. 

I can't believe the game still has these issues since 2015. I think they just got bored of it and decided to release it. 

There are mods out for the game, but they are so unsupported they often crash the game. 

Save your money.

EDIT: 2023... Still very much the same. Placing objects is still a very frustrating process. Leaves still hamper you putting down items. You have to hack the entire tree down and clean up the debris just because a single leaf is blocking your path. I am swearing at this games physics more than I am enjoying it. Avoid.

I have put more time into Stranded Deep on PS4 than I have here on Steam; but PC is definitely a better experience overall. 

I really enjoy the beautiful sunsets and sunrises on Stranded Deep. On day one, it is difficult to start up and it may take you some time before you ever feel like you’re thriving. Like any good survival game, it can be a very unforgiving environment; including features like sunburn, food poisoning, and finite materials on each island. 

Once you get established, you can enjoy your best island life. In the meantime watch out for the sharks, snakes, hogs… I won’t give too much away just watch your step!

Stranded Deep is a great desert island survival game that offers a thrilling and adventurous game that you can enjoy alone or with friends. The game lets you explore a vast and dangerous world full of sea animals and natural disasters that can surprise you at every turn.

One of the most interesting elements of the game is how over time you have to take care of your basic needs, such as hunger and thirst, as well as the state of your health. You have to learn how to make tools and weapons in order to secure food and survive in the wilderness.

Although there are some bugs in the game that can be frustrating, they are mostly funny rather than distracting. Plus, if you play with friends, you can laugh together at these funny moments and enjoy surviving on the island even more.

Overall, Stranded Deep is a very fun and engaging game that you can enjoy both alone and with friends. Although there are some bugs, they don't limit you from fully enjoying this desert island adventure game.

Stranded Deep is a game that drops you on a deserted island, as you struggle to survive and find a way back home. It's a game that's both challenging and relaxing, requiring strategic thinking and resource management. Let's take a closer look at the pros and cons of this unique game:

Pros:
[list]
[*]The game's concept is engaging and immersive, as you navigate your way through the island and its many challenges. It's a simple concept that's executed well.
[*]The game's customization options are extensive, allowing you to build and craft your own tools and shelters. From rafts to fire pits, there's a lot of room for creativity and customization.
[*]The game's survival mechanics are challenging and rewarding, requiring careful planning and management of your resources. It's a game that will keep you engaged and thinking throughout.
[*]The game's graphics are stunningly beautiful, with realistic and detailed environments that will take your breath away.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]The game's pacing can be slow at times, especially in the early stages of island exploration. It may take some time to see the full impact of your decisions.
[*]The game's difficulty level can be unbalanced, with some stages feeling too easy and others feeling nearly impossible. This can lead to frustration and a feeling of unfairness.
[*]The game's controls can be a bit clunky and unintuitive at times, especially when it comes to building and crafting. It may take some time to get used to.
[/list]

Overall, Stranded Deep is an immersive and relaxing game that's perfect for anyone who loves survival and exploration games. With its extensive customization options, challenging survival mechanics, and beautiful graphics, it's a game that's worth playing. Just be prepared for a slower pace and some learning curves.

--> play LITERALLY any other game instead!

The inventory system was somewhat realistic, but fairly annoying for actual fun. The starting area isn't abundant in resources so I couldn't really get past the water still in the tutorial because I didn't have enough fibers. You couldn't down grade palm fronds to make lashing, logic 0. So I sailed to a new island and it was plentiful......and then a wild boar took me to clunky physics town. I've requested a refund that I hope is easily granted. I'd give this another whirl maybe...but I don't see it getting too much better if it doesn't get some pretty hefty attention from the dev's. I get that resources should be scarce...but perhaps they should at least coach you into a semi-decent zone for resources or allow you to downgrade the palm fronds and it might've got me a few hours of play. Instead just frustration.

Stranded Deep is a survival game that  is set in a tropical archipelago where players must survive on a deserted island by gathering resources, crafting tools and weapons, and exploring the environment. Players must scavenge for resources such as food, water, and materials to build shelter, create tools, and defend themselves against wildlife. The game's world is procedural generated, offering a new and dynamic experience for each play through. One of the standout features of Stranded Deep is its attention to detail. The game's graphics and sound design are impressive, with detailed environments and realistic sound effects that make the game's world feel alive. The game's crafting system is also deep and intuitive, with a variety of items and components to discover and utilize. However, one potential downside of Stranded Deep is its repetitive game play. While the game's world is procedural generated, the game play loop of gathering resources, crafting tools, and exploring the environment can become monotonous over time. Additionally, the game's controls can feel clunky and not intuitive at times, especially when interacting with objects or combating wildlife.

The co-op in this game is the worst I have ever seen. It takes about 3 full minutes for someone to be able to join and the world to "sync." Then there is SO MUCH de-sync. I would place something down and my friend couldn't see it or use it. So he would have to relaunch and re-sync for 3 minutes. It happened maybe 3 times in 2 hours. Things would disappear from our inventories. Sometimes he wouldn't be able to eat or drink something in his hand. His character was stuck trying to place something on the ground and he had to reload, AGAIN. If your friend dies there is this horrible repetitive beeping that doesn't stop until you rescue them. Had to mute my game because my dogwater friend died in the ocean, and I didn't have a bandage so I had to listen to steady, loud beeping for about 5 minutes. I got poisoned early on and didn't have the skill to make an antidote. I had to listen to this beep every 15s or so for 2 full in-game days. What is with the god damn beeping?? Enough already with the beeping. Plus it only goes up to 2-players max which is pretty bogus. Don't buy.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

There is no way for me to possibly recommend this game to anyone even after it's been done for so long. I spent 3 hours playing it TODAY march 16, 2023 and it felt like the most unfinished boring product I've played. I honestly am surprised it got taken out of early access for how awful it is. Some of my reasons are just simple nit picks however some of these concerns are definitely valid. I have only played for about 3 hours since I didn't even bother finishing it because it didn't seem worth it.

- 2 players maximum for multiplayer ??? like at that point just make it solo player.
- Speaking of multiplayer, only way to revive your co-op partner is with a bandage. Which you only get 1 at the start. With no recipe or hint on how to get more.
- Give us the ability to turn off the annoying flashing during storms or at least make it not as bad. Don't need a csgo flashbang in my face every 5 minutes per storm.
- Can't skip the starting cutscene so you have to watch it every new save even tho there was no point in trying to have a bioshock-esque opening just to have us swim 2ft out of a plane.
- No proper tutorials or information by the way, how the hell am I supposed to know how to craft a coconut flask when no recipe or even a hint on how to make that??? 0 tutorial or information unless I go on a wiki or google which is crazy that it knows more about the game than the game itself.
- I wasn't starving, poisoned, bleeding, etc or anything but I couldn't tell what I was taking damage from then proceeded to get stuck on a rock and die instantly?? bro- how 
- Can only cook 1 item at a time on the fire pit so I thought maybe the stove will let me cook more ! I was super wrong when the food  (1 item btw) still went on the fire pit but this time it was under the stove and I was unable to cook more or even pick up my food.

It took me a couple false starts to really get into the game, but Stranded Deep is an excellent survival/crafting game with above average replay value.

Some people might be frustrated by effectively limited resources at the start of the game (hence my false starts) but after getting the hang of playing Stranded Deep like it's a unique and different game, and not a clone of ARK, Minecraft, Subnautica, etc, it quickly becomes a fun and engaging couple hours of hunting, learning, and getting the crap scared out of you by surprise visits from exceeding large and unnerving marine wildlife.  

A solid A game with decent replay value thanks to its randomly generated island chains.

The game good, but could be better.

"I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dinkum and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories."

I played this exclusively as a two player co-op game. While the game follows the proven formula (gather ressources, craft tools, use tools to gather other ressources, fend off predators, hunt prey) and has a pretty clear cut objective (it's in the trailer), Stranded Deep ultimately get's it wrong, unfortunately.

Navigating the seas is frustrating, as there is no map. I can live with that, provided there is some way to navigate between landmarks (which there isn`t - be prepared to reload if you get lost and don`t want to abandon what you've built).

Islands and wrecks basically all just have the same ressources, and exploration is absolutely NOT rewarding. Diving may tickle your Thalassophobia a little, though.

Inventory management is a hassle, although the crafting system is well implemented. A skill system is used, but I feel it is only there to lock out some vehicle crafting recipes until you've built enough structures on several islands.

There is much less pointless busywork (I`m looking at you, Raft!), but much of the time in game is spent watching the waves, as you search for the very few important landmarks while steering (good thing the wind magically changes to match the heading of your raft). This makes progress feel like a snail trying to crawl over sandpaper.

Lastly, we experienced connectivity issues at least once per hour in the game. The guest client is then immediately disconnected, and reconnecting forces both clients to fully sync the game world, which takes around four minutes staring at the loading screen.

In the end, we abandoned the game halfway through for feeling that the it was deliberately designed to waste our time.

[h1] Stranded Deep: An Exciting Open World Survival Adventure [/h1]

[b] Overview: [/b]
Stranded Deep is an enthralling open world survival game that offers players an unforgettable adventure. Developed by Beam Team Games, this game will test your survival skills as you find yourself stranded in the Pacific Ocean following a mysterious plane crash. With no means to call for help, you must craft, build, and hunt for resources to survive.

[b] Gameplay: [/b]
In Stranded Deep, players are tasked with exploring the vast expanse of the Pacific Ocean while collecting supplies, crafting tools and weapons, and building shelters to stay alive. You will need to manage your character's hunger, thirst, and exposure levels through an interactive survival watch. The game also allows you to level up skills such as harvesting, craftsmanship, cooking, physical, and hunting to increase efficiency and unlock new crafting combinations.

[b] Crafting: [/b]
The game features an interactive crafting menu that allows you to craft various tools and weapons such as spears, axes, bows, and spearguns. You can also quick-craft items from your inventory or the ground around you. The crafting system allows you to turn almost anything into something useful, making resource management a crucial aspect of the game.

[b] Building: [/b]
Players can build their own homes away from home with dozens of tiers and building pieces to choose from. You can start with a weak and flimsy palm frond shack and upgrade to a solid clay brick house. Customizing your raft with sails, canopies, storage, anchors, and boat motors, or constructing a gyrocopter, are also great ways to explore the vast expanse of the Pacific Ocean.

[b] Exploration: [/b]
The game's procedurally generated world ensures that no two islands are the same. Players can dive for sunken shipwrecks, search for abandoned shelters from previous survivors, or search for rare sea creatures like whales. Hunting, fishing, trapping, and skinning animals are other ways to collect food or assert your dominance over the Pacific islands. There are also three bosses to take on, which offer rewards upon defeating them.

[b] Multiplayer: [/b]
Stranded Deep allows for online or split-screen co-op modes, making the game even more enjoyable to play with friends. You can also customize your world through the map island editor, which allows you to manually place trees, rocks, and creatures to create your own adventure island to share with friends.

[b] Conclusion: [/b]
Overall, Stranded Deep is an excellent open-world survival game that offers players a unique and exciting experience. With its immersive gameplay, stunning graphics, and challenging survival mechanics, it's definitely worth playing. So if you're looking for a game that will test your survival skills and provide hours of entertainment, then Stranded Deep is the perfect choice.

I'll start with my opinion.

For a Survival Game, this one is actually pretty good. When you read about what survivors in the Pacific Ocean had to go through to survive; this game puts you right into that feeling.
You have to worry about food, sleep, and the elements; including the local hostile fauna. 
I do wish there was a bit more 'guidance' with how to procure certain things/items, or at least when to expect such things.
I understand why the Dev's have made some things ambiguous, as to leave it up to us to figure it out, but it would have made my first 15 hours a lot easier on the PC Windows Gamepass version a lot easier.

As for mechanics in Stranded Deep, there are some frustrating moments, when exploring a ship and the waves make it difficult. The water mechanics pass through the objects, walls-etc, without any effect on the water what-so-ever. It just rises and lowers, at a variable rate.
I haven't found too many 'glitches' or 'bugs' that are majorly game breaking.
MAIN BUG FOUND - Sometimes in Multiplayer, one player becomes desync'd and we have to 'SAVE-REHOST' to get them back sync'd up.
If you have patience to learn the game and the patience for that one bug in MP, give it a go.

Overall, after spending about 15/20 hours on a different platform and almost a day on here;
I'd give this game a solid 6/7-10. 
It *could* be better but it's good enough to pick up and have some fun with.

I really wanted to like this game; reminded me of a cross between the series lost and valheim. I thought it would be a challenge, but this is going too far. It is far too hard, and the progression isn't balanced. I don't suggest this game to anyone that might get fooled.

Plenty of long reviews on here to explain why, so I will keep it short-ISH

- Grinding with little to no reward for it
- They have added in skill levels, meaning things you need to SURVIVE are locked behind skills (which you can only gain by doing the action like cooking/crafting etc.) 
- Mechanics are still so janky i.e swimming in 2ft of water (but not all the time?), sometimes grabbing onto ladders/trees then sometimes not. Jumping is horrendous, it's an absolute chore to get over rocks or onto shipwrecks (we have arms but they are not used). 
- The shark AI is still so ***, I currently have a whale shark circling me? I think they have essentially copy/pasted the same AI for every large predator despite it being wrong for every species anyway. Great whites should stalk from a distance then attack at speed, hammer heads should be curious but ultimately interested in their usual prey (stingrays) and reef sharks should attack when you get too close or when you're hunting fish. But alas, they all want to kill you for some reason. 
- Islands are small dinky chunks of sand with similar resources and you find the more important items way too easily. Already have all the parts to build an engine and speargun after a couple of hours. 

Ultimately if they were trying to take ideas from other survival games i.e. the forest, they half***ed it and smacked a 20 dollar tag on it. Games should not feel like you're spending 5+ hours grinding for materials with little reward or achievement. For example, materials that are required in majority of items/builds should be easily obtain (LIKE trees/palms that regrow? having to island hop for STICKS is a joke. If anyone has not played the forest, you can essentially walk around your base and sticks/rocks that you previously picked up, will repawn. It sounds silly but it is not realistic to expect gamers to travel across multiple islands or land to collect materials that are required in everything) meanwhile items that SHOULD be difficult to obtain like engine parts, should be found in deeper ship wrecks or further from the starting island so it actually rewards you for going further and spending more time, risking your life a little more. 

P.S this is an updated review, my original review was too positive for what the game has NOT become over the years. Hopeless.. try out the forest, subnautica and Raft for survival games, if you just want games that involves sharks, try Maneater. Any of these games would be worth your coins over this one.

Though the idea of this game is quite interesting, the game needs a lot of work. It plays and feels like an early access game. It could have been so much more!

The good things:
+ lot's of things to explore on islands and in the water and lot's to build
+ realistic enough surroundings, with a nice variation of wild life
+ no/barely/limited UI, but a watch to keep track of your health and all other things you want to know
+ you can change the keybindings (but the hints in the game (like "press TAB to open") will keep saying the default keybinding instead of the one you set for it - it's confusing)

The bad things:
- no character creation (only a pick of gender)
- tutorial doesn't explain much so the learning curve is very steep (you'll end up googling stuff)
- the game won't tell you why you can't build something or how
- movement is stiff and unrealistic, your character will walk/run as if it's back is made out of a wooden plank for example. Funny, but it takes away from the attempted realistic feel of the game
- changing the tool or item in your hand is time consuming because you have to go into your inventory first and that's annoying in situations where you can't have that (scrolling through the tools would be a great way to solve that). There is a quickbar available after you crafted a couple of tool belts but as soon as you drop a tool/item or it breaks you have to add it to the quickbar again
- lot's of bugs in multiplayer that will require a reboot of the game
    * tools suddenly can't be used anymore and will be stuck in your backpack
    * SOMEbody's watch will keep beeping, but nobody knows who's it is and why it's beeping until it's too late
- the load/save option is very vague in multiplayer

Since there's still updates coming, I'm hoping for improvements in the (near) future.

Stranded on a lonely island, fighting for naked survival...... You've seen this in movies and want to experience it yourself without getting your [spoiler]lazy ass[/spoiler] out of your sweet home? You got it - this is the right game for you!

Yes, it is a bit older. Yes, the graphics are not up to date. But: The idea of survival on an island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean is really well transposed. The game has its quirks and is a bit "clunky" at times. That can be a bit exhausting and annoying. But you quickly come to terms with it. Collecting, crafting, base-building and traveling by raft (or gyrocopter) is intuitive and entertaining. The game-mechanics are interesting and the game-physics, apart from a few minor details, are based on reality. The fact that you can carry and throw around all sorts of objects regardless of their weight is really entertaining. The wildlife consists of a good amount of different animals and gives you the feeling of being in a lively world.

I played in single-player-mode without mods and had fun with the game. In co-op and with mods, you can certainly get a lot more out of the game. In standard-mode, however, it gets repetitive after a couple of hours of gameplay. After some hours I continued just for the grind of the Achievements.

Overall, a good game for a fair price.

Stranded Deep AKA stranded and deeply disappointed.

The premise of Stranded Deep is quite generic; you’re a plane crash survivor stranded somewhere in the ocean and you have to figure out how to survive. But regardless of how generic it seemed I still went into this game pretty open minded. Honestly, maybe I was just playing the game wrong but recent steam reviews show a mixed rating so I’m clearly not alone. In my opinion for this game being $20 and only going down to around $14 minimum you shouldn’t waste your time or money on it, just go play The Forest or something. 

You can see my first impressions as part of this video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9YEVbgKaTjw

I didn't end up enjoying this game. The controls are super clunky and everything seemed tedious rather than feeling like I'm surviving and exploring. It took WAY too long for me to figure out how to use the paddle and then I couldn't figure out how to grab/drag the boat. If those minor and essential actions are that clunky to do, then there are a lot of UX issues in the game.

I'm sure there are folks who really enjoy this game, but it doesn't have the intuitive controls something like Subnautica has. There are lots of other crafting/survival games out there and this one is a miss for me.

If you want to play this multi-player, it's great until the connection issues start, then it's 10-30 minutes of trying to get back in the same world again in my limited experience.  I've only played about 3 hours of co-op due to getting disconnected.

That said, this game is so much better co-op, but the connection issues are what kills it.  I played about 5 hours solo and it's a decent survival game with a slightly different take on the whole stranded at sea thing.  The graphics are great, at least on high settings.  With a R5 3600 and a 6700 XT I get 140-200 fps.  

The inventory system is frustrating though.  I would much prefer almost anything other than the radial wheel style.  You have to drop stuff on the ground if you don't have space, where it never despawns (afaik).  So managing storage boxes and organizing the wide array of stuff you collect is very annoying.  

The only (slightly) redeeming quality about the inventory issues is that crafting materials don't have to be in your inventory, they only have to be in your field of view, meaning they can be on the ground.  Though, the materials have to be close enough to you and be pretty much right in front of you, which can also be annoying given the amount of stuff and how much space it all takes up.

Combat is also a bit wonky, the spears don't really hit where you are aiming, even when not throwing them.  There's no way to heal yourself from the boars and giant crabs you mainly fight except for filling your food and water and waiting for your health to regenerate.  Haven't made it to the bigger bosses or killed a shark yet, not sure if i'll continue on with this game though.

Bottom Line:  If you want a solo, island hopping, grindy, but great looking survival game this could be for you.  If you are looking to play co-op, it's great until it isn't, then it's extremely frustrating not being able to reconnect unless the host restarts his game then go through syncing all over again to have a shot at getting back together.  Kinda feels like the game isn't quite full release yet.

This is not ready for release. I'm usually more forgiving with games, so I bought it despite the reviews. It seems like they just got tired of working on it and pulled the plug. Most games release 1.0 with a big capstone update, i.e. new content, completed story, etc. After 8 months of silence (from the last update), they release 1.0 with a very small handful of bugfixes. Thats it. They threw in the towel. Maybe with another two years of development, but if they stop here, then this is abandonware.

So many things wrong in just an hour of playtime, so lets start at the beginning.

-- Zero character customization outside of male or female. Everyone is a twin.
-- Starting a multiplayer game takes several minutes to sync. Ive never seen a game take that long. How could that be considered acceptable?
-- Poor/non-existent animations. Looking at my co op partner during the plane crash sequence and they are barely sitting in the chair. They are about a foot away from the back of the chair, and completely stiff. Dont allow the player to see things like that. Just hide it by putting the other players in different rows so they cant see each other. The first several times I climbed a tree there was no animation at all. You just slide up and down. Then suddenly they started working, so that was surprising. Rowing the raft is jarring, and you can see straight down your own neck.
-- Notifications are shared apparently. I was told I was bleeding while at full health. Found out later that my co op partner was dying somehow, even though we just barely started and were still trying to build our first shelter.
-- Terrible UI. Trying to move items from your backpack, that you apparently were just wearing during the plane crash for some reason, to another storage was just bizarre. Theres also no way to tell how much storage space a container has. You can also craft a toolbelt to unlock hotbar slots, but theres no way to put anything in those slots. If you have a full inventory with an item in your hand, you can drop the item and not be able to pick it back up due to a full inventory.
-- Poor design choices. You can only cook one tiny piece of meat on a fire at a time. And why exactly does a rain collector consume palm fronds to create water? It doesnt actually collect rain, because that would require rain. It just consumes fronds to generate water.
-- How exactly do you revive someone? My co op eventually died because he doesnt have a healthy fear of sharks, and his body just floats in the water, with no way to recover him and no respawn options.
-- The last straw. The watch. The sun came up, and the alarm on the watch starts screaming and never stops. After five minutes of listening to that, I gave up.

I bought this game when it originally came out on steam near a decade ago and put a considerable amount of time in it and enjoyed it alot and the updates where great to see the new content, but now coming back to it after a while the updates have made it near unplayable for me.

It feels like the game is focused more towards people playing with controllers or consoles for some reason the UI has become difficult to use the crafting is not intuitive and it's just a pain to play.  

Why is there a controller style Dpad selector (With a different sensitivity for some reason) for the crafting wheel when I have a mouse to select what I want?
Why is there a Tab to open, Click to transfer, E to pick up ... that should be one button the Interact button!
Why do I have to hold a key to open a door or activate or use?
Why when I am crafting it is unable to see all the ingredients on the floor but somethings it can see?
And so much more...

Online frequently crashes and 'disconnects' you (VERY) frequently, and randomly. 
All progress is lost after a disconnect. You can ONLY save after you craft a shelter and save manually. That means building a shelter on every island and never being too far away from one. 


Avoid this product AT ALL COSTS, if you want a good survival try Green Hell, Forest, Dark wood, anything other than this. 

The crafting is very grindy also, there's no tutorial and a very clunky character control system.
Very little inventory space will leave you constantly dropping items everywhere. 

Also poison = game over at the start as there is no way to heal it. 

Yeah...avoid, it has nice visuals and water effects but nothing much else.

This title is certainly one of my favorite survival games to date. Here's why:

- Simple yet difficult. No zombies or crazy enemies (for the most part). Just bad circumstances.

- Beautiful graphics which complement the environment greatly.

- The ability to make your own islands vastly increases my enjoyment of this game.

- When and how you reach your goals depends entirely on you.

- co-op if desired can be goofy and good fun.

Stranded Deep
This review unfortunately is a mixed bag of some good and some rather annoying aspects to a game with potential.

SYNOPSIS:
Stranded Deep aims to deliver the setting and atmosphere similar to the movie Cast Away from 2000, where you have to survive on your own after a plane crash over the ocean on an island(s) with the known struggles that come along, while trying to find a way back home. 

PROS:
While graphically appealing to the eye, the atmosphere of surviving alone on a remote island somewhere in the ocean, or sailing on a self-made raft through the high waves of a thunderstorm while second guessing if the raft you build is up for the task and if you might end up as a happy meal for the shark that is following your raft for quite a while now probing the rafts underside from time to time together with the well-executed storm and lightning sounds really make this in parts an interesting and immersive experience. 

Due to there is no specific storyline behind the obvious, the player is also free to explore the world around and is given the freedom to focus on what’s personally important e.g. build a base, craft, explore, which will be enjoyable for some players. 

CONS:
Besides various ingame bugs that reach from being annoying (singleplayer) to unplayable (especially multiplayer) the AI mechanics in general are quite easy to beat and soon become no challenge. The game also rarely leaves the player with an urgency to address negative status effects like poisoning, bleeding starvation etc. 

All islands look very similar to each other. This is either by design -to get the player lost- or due to some generic level design which greatly breaks the otherwise good immersion. After a very short time you know what to expect when visiting the next island(s) as -flora and fauna and potential loot- are literally the same.

Especially the last part of the final cutscene probably might leave a lot of players kind of unsatisfied at the end. I won`t get into specific details, but those of you who played the game The Forest might get a little hint here. ;-)

CONCLUSION:
Stranded Deep succeeds in bringing the cast away experience, and while the game is at times fun to play, there are aspects that will most likely be annoying and reduce the chance of playing the game more than once. There are other survival games like The Forest or Green Hell which in various parts are better executed. For those of you who still want to have a shot at Stranded Deep I would recommend buying it on sale as there are also clear downsides to the current version (v1.0.17.0.) of the game.

Neat little survival game that offers about 30 hours of unique gameplay.

Sound/Music: Average
Stability: Above average. No game crashes here.

Gameplay:
I particularly like the survival watch for checking and managing player stats.
A few minor glitches, but no gamebreakers, for example:[list]
[*]Physics leave a bit to be desired. Sometimes stuff will clip through the terrain and disappear, or collide with objects and be hurled all over the place. Particularly wood logs when cutting palm trees. 
[*]In stormy weather with big waves, marine life will sometimes float above the water.
[/list]
Game ending is rather anticlimactic.
[spoiler]You finally manage to escape, only to crash your plane again and start all over. VERY disappointing.[/spoiler]
Note: I haven't yet tried the multiplayer aspect of the game.

Honestly, the game is not awful, but it's not worth your time or money.
Mechanically, the game is.... fine. The controls are a bit janky, a bit unintuitive, but not deal breaking. The problem is that the game is just very insubstantial. I've started more than one game, so I think the map is set, but it feels randomly generated. There's just nothing to any of the locations. They all feel and look the same. Nothing interesting to discover, nothing to explore. If you're going to create a set map, why not design a more interesting environment?
The undersea graphics are nice, but if you want that, you're better off playing Subnautica. The building is OK, but there a dozens of games that do this better. If you want the survivor aesthetic, you're better off with the Forest or Green Hell. 
It feels like an early access game that the developers gave up on and didn't bother finishing, which is kind of borne out by how little was changed for version 1.0.

Overall a really disappointing game for something that was in development for so many years.

[h1]Unrealistic and obtuse...[/h1]
Pros: [b]#1.[/b] Haven't found any.

Cons: [b]#1.[/b] The inventory system is terrible and your inventory is tiny. 
[b]#2.[/b] The crafting interface is terrible. Navigating between your inventory and crafting screen is obtuse and slow.
[b]#3.[/b] When you enter the water, your field of vision is artificially limited by the devs, and they make it so that you can't even see 3meters ahead of you. This makes it so that the sharks can be literally within striking distance of you and you can't even see them. It's a completely fake and artificial level of difficulty that has been added to the game.
[b]#4.[/b] Even after more than 8 years of development, the game still has bugs and glitches. Items clipping through the ground or plain just falling through the ground; trees and other objects yeeting themselves up 5meters into the air; 
[b]#5.[/b] 'Fibrous leaves' are seemingly the rarest items in the game... there's fccking leaves on ALL of the trees, yet they don't drop the 'fibrous leaves' when you chop them down.... NOPE, only 1 type of tree in the entire damn game, drops 'fibrous leaves' and yet 'fibrous leaves' are used with a HUGE amount of recipes, so it's insanely difficult to get and yet it's one of the most used resources in the entire game.
[b]#6.[/b] The entire game is just tiny, tiny islands. This entire world has no land masses or islands bigger than 100m2. It's just several dozen tiny islands on a map, and that's it... no large islands to explore or anything like that.
[b]#7.[/b] The intro of the game is stupid. It's like 2minutes and it's incredibly stupid and doesn't give you ANY information about the character or what happened to them.
[b]#8.[/b] You can't activate V-sync if you set an fps cap, this results in MASSIVE screen tearing... I'm talking about GIGA CHAD screen tearing.
[b]#9.[/b] The tutorial is absolutely useless and doesn't teach you even 10% of the things you need to be taught.
[b]#10.[/b] Literally the ONLY source of water for the first few hours of the game, coconuts, can poison you, which results in you losing all your hydration.

One thing that really stood out to me in this game was the intense action when deep underwater foraging (yes, it's the shark). The sound design is also top-notch, with realistic sound effects that really bring the game to life. The survival gameplay is also challenging, as you must explore other islands and forage underwater to keep yourself alive and create new equipment. 

However, during my experience playing with friends, I encountered two bugs. The first one was that my character did not appear on my friend's monitor (or vice versa). The second bug was that we experienced a lot of disconnected problems and were unable to join the same room, resulting in us having to create a new room every time one of us was disconnected. 

Despite these issues, the game is still a lot of fun and offers a unique and exciting experience. Each player has their own seed map, resulting in a dynamic and ever-changing game world. This adds an element of surprise and discovery to the game, as you never know what you might encounter on your next journey between islands and foraging underwater. Additionally, you have to rely on a compass to navigate, as there is no detailed map available. This adds an element of uncertainty and exploration to the game, similar to the feeling of discovering new areas in Minecraft without the use of coordinates. 

Overall, if you're a fan of games that offer heart-pumping action and survival gameplay, this game is an excellent choice. Just be aware of the bugs that I encountered when playing with friends.

[b] BUILD TOGETHER [/b]

The amount of building you can do in this game was precisely shown in the trailer : you can build walls,roof,floor and a handful of furniture items.  Needless to say,this was a huge dissapointment.

[b] EXPLORE TOGETHER   [/b]

It takes around 5 to 10 minutes to reach a nearest island you can see; however as you get closer all the excitement evaporates completely : it is usually a tiny rock with 1-2 hostile boars 2-3 giant crabs and a tiny bit of resources. Searching the sunken ships is just boring : I usually got a 100th rocket flare or compass. But this isnt because i was simply being unlucky : there are not that many variations of resources or items in this game either.

[b] SURVIVE TOGETHER [/b]

This part was fun for few couple of hours.Then my friend accidentaly discovered a bug that allowed us to have unlimited coconuts and improved axes.You might think that this is a minor thing but it isnt : most of the time i spent in this game i was searching for water and chopping wood.After discovering this I mowed down every single tree on home and surrounding islands and we still didnt have enough wood to construct a simple bungalo.

[b]  ESCAPE TOGETHER    [/b]

Not going to happen for me because (besides the reasons stated above) I went insane of the constant inventory management. The crates can only hold 5 items and the stacks are so tiny that i had my entire base floor and shelves filled with boxes (half of which stored useless stuff,like the endless copies of compass or rocket flares that i talked about earlier).

Review updated on December 2022 - Same old issues.... Not impressed with this game at all. The graphics are beautiful but the crafting and inventory system/menus are HORRIBLE. After playing games like 7 days to Die, Minecraft, the long dark, and many others, this game is unplayable. For example, why not just allow players to harvest yucca with a click of the mouse? Instead you need to hack at the leaves as if you are cutting it down, then the leaves (which are tied with string??) fall on the ground. It's then very difficult to see where they are, you need to find the white outlines. Very bad. When picking something up it goes into your hands not into your inventory. When dropping something it automatically puts the next item in your inventory into your hands, like a tarp....WHY!? The game makes decisions for us when we play. When entering the crafting menu, you are left with a shopping list that goes off the screen with multiple lists, no tabs, and no search option. 2/3 of the crafting menu shows the background which is useless.  The more difficult a game is, the less likely people will play it. This game can have so much more potential, I hope the Dev's learn from other games that have a large following. Two frustrating thumbs down!

My friend and I purchased Stranded Deep in 2016. Since then, it seems like the game really hasn't received much attention by the developers. Little updates have been made and even less bugs have been patched. Originally, we both played singleplayer as there was no online multiplayer and we had a blast. While the game is difficult and can be very tedious, it is fairly well thought-out and can easily provide hours of fun if you're into it. Despite this, I feel as if the developers simply do not care about their game, which (in my opinion) was on track to being a polished and fully playable game. 

Since the beginning, the graphics have not changed at all. While the landscape and waves generally look pretty good, the player models are of low quality and many item models / icons clearly are not finished (like the placeholder seagull icon that is present in the game).

The main problems I encountered are to do with the co-op mode. Recently, we decided to revisit the game after hearing there has been a co-op mode for ~5 years that we were not aware of. We jump in but die quickly on our first run. After restarting, we spent our lashings on water collectors immediately and were able to survive more easily. Throughout our second playthrough, we have encountered many game-breaking bugs that forced us to save and restart the game. This was a major inconvenience, but we were still keen to play. 

Recently, we encountered a bug that would simply kick us to the menu without warning. The error code "Timeout: StayAlive" was present on the screen without any other explanation. We lost ~35 minutes of progress and farming to this.

Frankly, as much as I love this game, I cannot say it is deserving of the $30 AUD price tag. The developers seem to not care about the game's state, adding updates or patching bugs, and the co-op is a buggy mess and a huge waste of time. I am disappointed we couldn't come back to a more refined game after almost 6 years.

Crafting was my major issue in this game, and a lot of it was just no information given in what can be done and cannot be done it was like this, you had to save every step you can and test it until you learned these steps and Note if you get a world you like it will re spawn if you have it set at the start of the game.  Here is how to craft in this game.  Step one The Raft: needs to be six block at least to float and stay level, with this said.  Note Crafting tip the base level of the raft has to be done in the water but you do not have to do it all at once.  Big tip if you find enough good items to do a two block raft it will work to go get the others.  You can destroy a section but lose a lot of Material,  just to do a good base you like build it and later you can add to it. This game has so many bugs, it's ridiculous. 

The most annoying bugs involve the inventory. If the inventory is full, I cannot even switch to anything in the inventory as it gives me an error message that the inventory is full. Then sometimes it doesn't stack items, like fibrous leaves - just uses two different item slots. I then need to drop all of them and pick them back up to fix the issue. Also the inventory is comically small, you can carry 10 different items at maximum, and that includes all the tools. Even when you unlock the tool belt - you'd think that you can then move tools from the backpack to the tool belt, but no, this is just for hotkeys, the tools stay in your inventory and take up space! Wasted opportunity to make life a little easier for the player. So I have to carry only one tool at a time, and drop all the other tools (and there are many, they would take up the entire inventory) on the floor. The hotkeys feature thus is pointless since you lose the binding when dropping a tool - arrgh.

Also the game is german when you start it up, for some reason, and then switches to english (which is what's configured) in the menu. This is not a problem, but just shows how lazy or unskilled the developers are.

Unfortunately I checked out some mods on nexusmods to try to fix the inventory woes, but they are all broken. Seems this game has been abandoned by both the developers and the mod community. Not worth playing!
