[h1] IF YOU HAVE PLAYED RAFT, THE FOREST, GREEN HELL OR RUST, THIS GAME IS NOT WORTH IT. [/h1]

[list]
    [*] Bugs everywhere. 
    [*]If you lowered the audio and restarts the game, audio volume isnt being refreshed and will use the default audio settings. You actually have to go to the settings>audio first then it will remember the audio settings.
    [*]Frequent disconnection from the server and didnt tell the player what is the reason
[*]The UI was worse than a morning diarrhea. The crafting menu is so bad. No description provided and the player have to use their gamesense and figure out the game mechanics by themselves. Didnt know you can switch tabs in the crafting menu? tough shit. Didnt know what this item can do? tough shit. Didnt know what this building is for? tough shit. Didnt know how to use/interact with this item/building? tough shit. want to craft multiple of the same item at the same time? tough shit
[*] Story is shit. barely any dialogues. Didnt know what to do? tough shit. didnt know where to go? tough shit. didnt know how to get the necessary items for the end game? tough shit. "go figure it out yourself. imma enjoy the money brb" - dev. 
[*] The key items [spoiler] like the compass, binoculars, airplane parts [/spoiler] should stay with player instead of being droppable. 
[*]The loading screen takes longer time than taking a shit
[*]Inventory management is crap. Crafting toolbelts are more useless than crafting a knitted condom. Players' backpack can store more items than wooden boxes? 
[*]Usually in the main menu, its "Press any key" or "Press Enter". This one is "Press Returm"? . For those who know that the enter and return are the same, its not going to be a problem. but for those who doesnt, theyre gon be pressing everything on the keyboard.
[/list]

The game is definitely still in early development with its current state and as a survival game player, I dont recommend it.

Inventory management is a pain, crafting toolbelts for tools is useless because the tool will still take away a spot in your backpack. Strangely, my backpack can store more itms than the big wooden storage boxes I find, which leads to the floor around my basic shelter being littered with stuff, which becomes very annoying and it's easy to miss things.
The crafting menu is very unclear. There's something like tabs, but it's not apparent, so you'll miss whole categories of items until you figured that out. There's like 6 categories, and you can only see 3 on top. But even those 3 are so unremarkable, that it's very easy to miss that you can (and should) actually click there or hit the "crafting" hotkey several times to cicle through them. (The subcategories are also not very clearly recognizable, but still better than the categories for me.) An explanation in the tutorial might have helped a little, even though it's still not the best design.

I like that you can play on randomly generated maps. However, even then the islands are tiny and every single one seems to include everything you could need to survive. This makes the whole thing pretty easy and boring. Sure, it's nice if the starting island contains everything for survival, but the ones further away could be a bit more special. Exploring is done fast, because there's not a lot to explore. I wish there were more different plants and animals to make things more interesting and make me actually want to explore new islands.
Also, the game gives me no reason to build a base. You can construct houses, farm, etc., but you don't need it for anything. There are storms, but the only thing they do is filling the water still faster and making the ocean water dark, so I can barely see anything when diving. Would be nice if I'd get sick when out in the storm all the time for example. Which would then also provide a reason to actually build at least a small hut.

One thing I find a bit weird (spoiler): [spoiler]I haven't fought any of the bosses yet, so I can't say much about them, but I find the concept of bosses in a survival game (that otherwise seems mostly realistic) weird. Hunger, thirst etc., survival itself should be the bosses here. But that's maybe just me.[/spoiler]

To me the game still feels like early access, with quite some room for improvement and little content. I'll probably try again in another year or 2, but for now it's just boring.
it is a very good game and i would recommend to at least give it a try

Stranded Deep is a Well designed game, for the most part. Some of the multiplayer mechanics can get a bit finicky; overall, Stranded Deep is a fun game to play with friends and provides a definite challenge to those who accept it.

I really hate that I have to leave a negative review for this game since I've been a fan for a really long time, but it just isn't anywhere near finished. There is a staggering amount of bugs, even more so in multiplayer, that just make the game unplayable sometimes. Fallen trees will launch items into the ocean, rafts will suddenly flip, sink, or just stop working in general. I've had an experience where a boss died under my raft and made it completely unusable, so I had to quit without saving and lost a bunch of progress. The frame rate will randomly drop for no reason, multiplayer sometimes has atrocious sync errors (rafts will appear in different locations for different people, chests will be empty for one person and full for another), in co-op the other player will sometimes just randomly disconnect for no reason (at one point we figured out one of the causes was manually dragging our raft), and when trying to reconnect, the load time is abysmal (5-10 minutes). I've been following this game for a long time and I love it to death, but I just can't help but leave a negative review until a lot of this stuff is fixed. If you can somehow look past these egregious problems, it's a great game, but I'd suggest waiting until the game is actually playable before you buy it.

First off, I shouldn't have to google "how to add items to hot bar" but for some reason this game makes that a thing.

The inventory system is a pain, for starters I am playing on a PC with a mouse and keyboard and your inventory and quick crafts are radial menus, why? Your items will split into random stacks when you take something into your hands, lets say you have 1 open slot and you have a stack of 4 sticks, when you take one of those sticks into your hand you now have no empty slots, but you really wanna pick up that crab you just skinned. So, you drop the stick thinking it will free a slot, NOPE another stick is in your hand so you drop that as well as the 3 others your still holding. At least you have your crab now.  Sometimes when you make an item, even if it uses all the items in your hand, you will have to place it on the ground to then pick it back up because the game doesn't account for all the items you will be using.  Want to put something in a box? hope you're ready to go through an unintuitive multiple menu system to do so. 

I can't be bothered to put more time in when there are so many other survival games out there that are actually user friendly out of the box.

Sit back and relax, or if you prefer, get Stranded Deep, put your foot into the water, realize just about everything in the water looks poisonous, and often is, swim a bit more, and cue Shark MUSIC™ to let you know dinner is served.

It's Cast Away meets the Bermuda Triangle's Dumping grounds. Your airliner crashes, and lucky you, you are less than mercifully dumped into an island cluster in the Pacific, left to scavenge and survive on your nearby islands' resources. While you start with nature's resources and the few survival items you have (your raft, your trusty watch that monitors all your vitals), you relearn stone age and basic survival techniques to Stay Alive long enough to start exploring all the man-made underwater wrecks that have run aground or fallen from the sky, that might hold more valuable items to help you survive, and perhaps maybe even escape, if you wish.

Or you can find and create your own island paradise, living off of the land and harvesting the bounty of the sea, and watch the beauty of the sun rise and the sun set as you realize you could live here forever.


While Stranded Deep will not be the most faithful survival simulator one could wish for, and surely not entirely realistic ([spoiler]the overall setting requires some suspension of disbelief, when you find the X-teenth island with yet another few abandoned boat wrecks, that only a conspiracy theory can explain away; and the ending, well, will only leave you .... Stranded Deep with more questions and fewer answers about what you know about reality and of your sanity.[/spoiler]), and despite my reservations during its early access about what I perceived as flaws in feeling that it's not stranding you deep enough in its Pacific environmental and survival setting; it is, in the end in its completed state, a fun, beautiful, and overall a relaxing and enjoyable game.

Further, personal note: My recommendation as a vacation destination from The Long Dark.

Stranded Deep is a beautiful experience no matter if played in single player or co-op mode.
It has good implemented physics with a great atmo which makes this game very enjoyable.

Levels are procedually generated and can even be created using a level editor tool (included).

Hud and inventory mechanics are intuitive and inventory is easy to manage.

This game has had quite a few updates which include a lot of stuff to be constructed and seen and more things are added to it every few weeks. Cooking, diving, exploring, fighting is what you can expect to be able to do in this game as for now.

Structure building requires to add items to the construction one by one and the fact that you don't really have an inventory as usual in most survival games, in my opinion, gives the game an even more survival edge since it essencially makes the process a bit harder, but in general it's an easy, quite enjoyable game i would totally recommend to any of you who likes deserted islands or survival games.

Stranded Deep bears a striking resemblance to one of my all time favourite films Cast Away, which is why I took to it. The whole idea of surviving on a deserted and remote island has always appealed to me. Despite the praise, the game, as a survival one, has a handful of drawbacks. 

Upsides: 
[list][*]Appealing concept: a tropical island, an ocean, the sun, solitude, no humans
[*]Serene and soothing atmosphere which calms you and improves your mood when in distress
[*]Moderate difficulty which actually makes you chill rather than suffer, unlike other 'hardcore' survival games[/list]
Downsides:
[list][*]Islands are too tiny and often empty, which forces you to hop between other islands is search of supplies. However, the idea of island hopping seems ludicrous and may ruin the unique atmosphere of being stranded on an remote island
[*]Broken achievements which do not unlock upon completion
[*]Levelled crafting system. In order to create a simple tool you need to craft a dozen of identical rubbish items first
[*]Tool degradation system. Looks like artificial difficulty. A stone tool falls apart if you cut too many leaves with it
[*]Fruit spoil system. Even when left on a tree, a fruit will still spoil within a short period of time, just like a picked up one[/list]

In my view, Stranded Deep undoubtedly isn't the best survival game out there, but if you like such a setting as being stranded on a tropical island, you should definitely give this game a go. 

The concept of the game is great. You just immerse yourself in it and soak up this solitary tropical atmosphere.

[h1]This game has been through hell and back. Where are we now?[/h1]

I've bought this game on January [b]25th 2015[/b]. Twice. One copy for me, one for a good friend.
The game had just come out a few days prior and seemed challenging and interesting enough to check it out.
15€ invested and we started.

A few almost fading keyboard notes reached my headphones. A waving Stranded Deep logo appeared on my screen. [i]Minimalistic, quiet, peaceful. Wow.[/i]

As I sat out to start my new game I was crushed by how amazing it looked. It was 2015 and those fucking sun shafts and shaders still haunt me until this day.
The game looked amazing and it felt amazing. 
Yes, [b]YES[/b], the intro, I know. The Forest came out sometime in 2014 and this intro was basically a one point copy. But everything after the intro. [b]Not[/b].

You are flying to a unknown destination in your plane, private jet I guess, when you suddently crash. Stranded with only the emergency boat and your clothes, you arrive on a nearby island. A small, coconut rich island. From here on out, [i]the world is yours[/i].

[b]Pro's:[/b]
✓ Incredible visuals since 2015
✓ (Used to) Minimalistic design
✓ Easy crafting system (Now bound with a skill system)
✓ Fairly simple to get into and progress
✓ Generated islands with different sizes and stuff
✓ Sharks & other fish you can hunt & hunt you
✓ Now with animals on the islands you can hunt
✓ Old, rusty ruins of ships and other sunken buildings to explore
✓ Swimming and diving mechanics are really nice

[b]Con's:[/b]
✗ [b]I miss the old intro music! [/b]
✗ The new skill system breaks immersion for me
✗ Sometimes necessary things (Like a hammer) are hard to find
✗ Your items break [b]way too early[/b]
✗ [b]The new version makes everything so confusing...[/b]

I loved this game. I could always start it up and simply roam around my island with so much to do and so many more things to explore; every update. New gadgets, new animals, new weapons, more stuff to craft.
I used to put coconuts or just scrap I didn't need at the place I left my island, swam a straight line to the next island, planted stones and looked for loot. That way I could always find my way back.
[i]Sadly, that is not possible anymore. [/i]

In the last few updates the game has changed [b]dramatically[/b]. That's not always a bad thing.
The minimalistic swimming, diving and surviving game I once knew and loved has been replaced by a game that tries too hard to reach The Forest's state.
Don't, [i]please do not[/i] ruin this masterpiece. 

The menu has been massacred and the lovely tune of keyboard notes has vanished. 
Where did the minimalistic game from 2015 go? [i]What happened? [/i]

Don't get me wrong, the game is still incredible fun to play. But it's just not the same anymore. 
Back then I was able to play hours and hours, swim around islands, explore sunken ships and fight sharks. Now I have to skill up for ages before being able to build a base. That's not...no. That's not what we wanted.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I enjoy this game quite a bit since I enjoy the ability of just exploring the islands and after playing this game for numerous hours I only just realised that there is an end-game. I like the fact that you have to stumble onto things and that the game never really pushes you in any direction. Which means that there's a lot to do and no real rush to complete anything, you can focus on just exploration and then choose when you want to start finishing the objectives to finish the game. 

There are some issues though one of them being is that this game has been in early access for years and the development progress is very slow and clunky. There are also some bugs and glitches that have been there for sometime (1-2 years) and have yet to be removed. There is also the issue of if you place an item down you either have to like it or else destroy it and loose half of the resources used to make it. This can cause particular issues when it comes to crafting on the raft since placing objects on the raft has to be perfectly timed to have it in the correct position due to the current of the waves. Also the aiming system in the game is very hit or miss since an animal could be right in-front of you but somehow your unable to hit it due to the hit box being finicky. 

Another thing to add is that the game itself is visually stunning and quite relaxing. However, even with the graphics settings on normal my pc still heats up a lot so I wouldn't really recommend this game to someone that has a low-end pc. 

I wish there was a neutral option because I would recommend this game since I've enjoyed it quite a bit however there are quite a few problems with it that really affect the game play and overall experience so I would think about that before deciding whether to buy it or not. 

tdrl;
It's an enjoyable game but it has it's issues.

A solo survival, crafting adventure out on the high sea and tropical islands.
The game has all the elements you'd expect from any survival game just without the PVP or raiding bases.
You are standard in an area of small tropical Islands and you go from Island to Island scavenging for supplies and materials to build rafts, bases and the means to get food and water.

And that's about it...........no really that's it.
[Edit 9/11/22] Since writing this review the game has been updated to include an end game and a way to escape.

The game is visually very well done and feels pretty polished but it falls completely flat when you quickly realise there is no end goal, story or aim to any of it.
You can build a base using the same mechanics you'd see from any crafting game like Rust , Ark or Conan but why build a base at all? there is no point in it.
You grow food and hunt animals just to keep going as your hunger drops pretty quickly in the game but other than keeping yourself well fed and keeping your thirst down there isn't much you have to do so what happens is you end up going from Island to Island on a raft you've built to build up supplies to build a base you don't need just because there isn't anything else to do except maybe try to fight a shark or something.

While the lack of any real story or content lets the game down you can still gain a fair amount of fun from it just by being creative, build yourself the tropical Island paradise you've always wanted. make yourself a small pier from which you can chill on and do a spot of fishing as the afternoon sun sets. Make a hut on the beach and barbecue some fish or make yourself a huge Island hotel.

Item management is very well done, all the items drop on the ground as they are, other games you may drop a stack of 10 wood on the ground where's in Stranded deep you literally drop 10 wood sticks on the ground which will each stack up and interact with eachother so a fair amount of game time will be finding areas to keep all your stuff and stacking it together and trying to keep it all neat. It is very well done mechanic.

Worth picking up when cheap or on sale.

Although I find this to be a decent survival/base building game, and recommend the title, it has many flaws as well as positives. The biggest problems are the navigation, theres not many great ways to mark locations you've visited. Hunkering down on a single island is not the best strategy since venturing to other islands to discover more resources is a necessity, so building a large base requires many resources and they take quite a while to gather. Lumber, and metal scrap is used to make bases, but also required to build other crucial components so building an enormous base seems wasteful, it makes more sense to just make a small shack, since traveling between islands is vital. My final complaint is the combat tends to be very wonky, especially land combat, getting attacked usually bounces you back like 3ft so getting a counter hit becomes a nightmare to pull off, so just craft throwing weapons only, or just run away. Minus my complaints, the gameplay is enjoyable despite getting repetitive quicker than other survival games I've played, its fun for a few hours solo or with a friend.

Just like how Green Hell is inferior in every single way to The Forest, this game is somehow, in every way, an inferior Green Hell.  I never thought I'd say this but I have a new appreciation for Green Hell now.  All of the complaints about Green Hell's UI, clunky game play, tedium, and inability to use a good chunk of the flora are also present here but cranked up.

You'll put logging companies to shame by speeding up climate change faster than they ever could just to create a glass of water.  Your character will require 7 gallons of water every day.  

Don't play this game.  Play Green Hell.

I don't review games much, but for this one, I had too. Some tips...

1. The compass is on the raft, USE THE COMPASS! Your tiny island doesn't have enough resources so you will have to go scavenging and you WILL get lost very easily.

2. The UI is not intuitive, for example, when making leather or planks you stand next to the crafting station and then go into your crafting menu rather than selecting the crafting station. I find this annoying to say the least because you have to scroll through EVERYTHING to find the one thing you want to craft instead of selecting the crafting station and just getting that ONE THING you want to craft. Spend some time watching vids so you can figure this out before jumping into the game, it'll save you a lot of frustration.

3. EVERYTHING WANTS TO KILL YOU. The first island I went to, I died in like 3 seconds because I had 2 crabs and a boar thingy gang up on me. Also, the sharks are d*cks.

4. Use the wooden crates and keep them in your inventory, they each expand your carrying capacity by 5. DO NOT attempt to throw things into the raft, it's not going to work out the way you would like.

5. Craft, craft, craft, craft, and craft some more. Your skills only increase when you use them and you need the higher level stuff simply to survive.

6. Water and food are your first priority, yes you can get water from coconuts but you will run out fast and its a pain to get enough of them to keep up with your thirst. A simple spear will get you small crabs, but fish is the sustainable option longer term.

Despite the bugs (boar falling from the sky, fish swimming above the water, etc) this game is enjoyable. I've been waiting for a while before purchasing it because I wasn't sure it was worth it but I'm happy I got it. Some people have compared this game to Raft, I have Raft, and no they aren't the same thing. This game is more gritty and realistic, although both games are very unrealistic when it comes to the wildlife attacking you. I like this game because it's almost realistic enough to simulate an actual survival situation, more so than any other game I've seen out there.

Co-op is SUPER buggy, mouse stops working in game, game stops responding or disconnected. Constantly have to restart and re-sync worlds, end up staring at the loading screen most of the time unfortunately.

GReat game...  needs a bit more content tho.. more things to build with purposes..  higher level tech from salvaged parts like pipes and  electrical .. alcohol  for medicinal purposes and  shark cages.. or  partial boat hulls .. speedboat.. more big terrifying bos monsters that can  knock you off your raft..  a chair for the raft to control the rudder from and see above your shelves..   craftable scuba gear from parts  to go dive deep  .   and pontoons for your gyrocopter that you can eventually add some crates to but mostly to keep it afloat

So. As you can see, I have ALOT of hours in this game, probably too many. I have played this game since the start and have seen it come along way. Undoubtedly one of my favourite survival games that doesn't involve zombies. I bought the game knowing fully it was early access and had some growing to do. If this game was still in early access, it would be worth a purchase to help it grow. However, it is apparently "fully released" now, which means, I'd say let it sail by. It still has bugs that have been in game for years that have never been dealt with and I very much doubt they intend to fix them now. 

TL:DR it's good if you pretend it's still early access. But buy it on offer if you must.

This game got potential, but many bugs that needs to be fixed before it is a complete game.
For starter, I swam across the ocean without any lovebites given by the shark. On this new island I found a cool metal hammer, great for building with, since I had no other tool to build with.
I managed to gather a huge amount of resources, then swam back all the way to the first island, no lovebites given during the trip this time either 😒

Once back, I started building my first few platforms. I checked my watch and all my needs were fully met, so I continued.
Out of the sudden, my character falls to the ground for no reason. I couldn't move... This was bad... I tried swinging my hammer but saw no animation-effect, yet heard a wooshing sound that the hammer makes...
Days passed by, unable to respawn or get help from my online-companion, I had no choice but to give up and uninstall the game, to demonstrate my furious rage.

After a while in-game I cannot craft anything. Seems like the game has problem updating current time situations... 

Another annoying fact is that even though you choose to mute the music, it always turns on when you start the game 😒
There's more, but I am simply too disappointed to go on.

Okay For starters...

SINGLEPLAYER: It is good, it's fun and it does take up time. There is no way you can complete everything in one or two days, it takes weeks! personally it took me about a month to get everything and defeat the bosses + Escape. in general it is really fun and it's something relaxing yet challenging at the same time.

MULTIPLAYER: okay.. this is where things get sloppy. I get it Devs, We all been pestering you to release multiplayer for years now. but you all blindly made it multiplayer then released it. There is no effort in fixing bugs as simple as loading in. My friend had to disconnect and reconnect over 7 times within 2 hours!! over little things like Me being invisible, or there are flying sharks. If you are trying to buy this for multiplayer DO NOT until there is some sort of Bug fix update or something. I would love to play this game with my friend but we grew so frustrated it was a uninstall immediately after 2 hours of none stop restarting. NTM the load time is HORRENDOUS! Both my friend and I Have decent gaming computers and it takes literal 5-8 minutes of loading in, just for it to bug out within 10 minutes sometimes sooner.

OVERALL: It's a good singleplayer game. since it's been singleplayer for years. Multiplayer just released this year..So if it takes the Devs over 4 years to release multiplayer I can only imagine it's going to take 4 - 4+ Years to even release a bug fix. The Devs didn't give to turds about us having a good Multiplayer experience, they just wanted us to stop asking for it. Thanks for giving us a Multiplayer that cant even do Multiplayer

Although at the time of writing I'm only 22 hours in, I have found this game to be fun and challenging.  It took me several attempts to get further than 2-3 days because of learning where to step, what wild animals will kill me (hint: it's most of them), and setting priorities such as water, food, shelter instead of "hey, what's on that island over there?"  Followed immediately by, "Hey, which one of those islands was my home-base?"  Learning to make a map of my immediate are and using the compass are key to answering those two questions by the way.  LOL!!!  Things aren't immediately intuitive but once you get the hang of how the crafting menus and production of materials works, the game has been entertaining and quite a bit of fun.  Thus far, I haven't ran into any of the bugs or glitches that the other reviewers have been complaining about although I have seen an underwater swimming pig and a few flying crabs.  If that is the worst thing I can find to complain about, then I don't really have anything to complain about.  All in all, it's been a pretty good game so far.  I'll need to edit this review later.  After I've figured out how to escape or spend the rest of my life island hopping for resources and eating crab & fish three times a day washed down with coconut milk and the occasional sip of water from the still.

It is with regret that I have to give this a thumbs down, even after so much game time. Stranded Deep is fun for a little while but eventually loses it's charm due to boredom from repetition. The developers haven't done anything to improve gameplay with their 'releases'.

Issues that have persisted for years:

"flying" fish in rough water
Combat is simple and broken
Sharks pose 0 risk. They don't tip your boat
Storms pose 0 risk. They don't tip your boat
Only 1 material (bouys) is worth building with
Building structures is worthless and a waste of time
lack of story
1 strange ending with no base in reality
invisible walls in the ocean like the Truman Show

I loved the game for a while but the developers have let it rot. If these simple issues were fixed this would be a gem.

As of right now, I cannot say if the gameplay is worth it. I used to play it solo, prior to multiplayer being an option (I believe I quit playing just prior to the MP patch). I'd come back, get to maybe day 3, then quit again. Mostly, I'd get frustrated with building my raft due to lack of materials or finicky placement.

I started a multiplayer last night with my niece, she was hosting. It is also important to note that we live maybe 20 minutes apart, in a major metro US city.

Dear gods, the disconnections. The first time I got kicked (timed out / staying alive), I thought it was because she had died from thirst. Nope. It took about 6 attempts/restarts before I was able to rejoin. Just tonight, I have 6 different invite codes from her. We wound up having to move from US-West, to Auto, to Canada. In Canada is where I stopped getting kicked. She also started saving every time we got notice of another day of survival.

Desyncing is an issue, too. We were out at the Big Boat, and while she's looking around upstairs, I'm watching her flit all over the water like a dragonfly on drugs. Then I tried to build a small shelter. Got the foundation down, got one wall down. Next wall just never gives me an outline. So I decide to go put a flooring on the raft.

Boy did that bounce into the water. Somehow, I had managed to sink that second wall halfway into the raft, perpendicular, making it stand on end. I, of course, couldn't see this. She had to break it down. Repeatedly. I had her build the second wall, and it went up fine. I couldn't see it. I could jump through it. Third wall, I saw it go up. Roof? Nah.

By this point, we were streaming to one another. This helped her to understand that the random wooden wall outline, on the beach, was not something I could see. Nor explain. I have 2 sticks in my inventory I could not hold, could not drop, could not do anything with.

I've been poisoned by nothing, I've been bitten by nothing. It's exciting when your health is sitting at less than 50% of the first block, due to being negatived by...nothing. At all.

Also, we had a reload where I revived her underwater, and she proceeded to be stuck inside of a rock. I couldn't pull her out, nor do much of anything except, "might as well just reload the save."

I remember I enjoyed this, despite the frustrations, in the solo mode. "I gotta come back to that," I kept saying. Then she and I watched Neebs & Appsro (Neebs Gaming) do their playthrough. So we jumped into this.

What an exercise in frustration tonight.

Stranded Deep is a great game. An island survival game. Pitting you against the odds. Good crafting mechanics and great detail into real life. Needing to care for your food levels, hydration, sleep and even curing infections or wounds. The wild life is somewhat scarce but that can be expected when going from island to island. Co-op is now here, and it's better than I thought. While it is fun for short play-through I can't say it lasts more than 5 or so hours per play. More of an issue with me.
GREAT GAME

Played a bit of this game a some years ago, before multiplayer and the ability to play as male or female were introduced. Having been a fan of Cast Away, this game hit home. And indeed, it was the game that got me into the survival sim genre. I finally got it on Steam and started playing in ernest. It was nice to return to it and experience all the new stuff. I like the slow and silent mood of this game, even though the timescale is obviously accelerated.

A year or so into my buying the game, and the only significant update was the multiplayer and the island editor,  I think. Don't get me wrong, it's good to have custom islands and to play with your friends, and I get that the game is effectively being developed by just one guy (or a very small group of people, I'm not sure), but I just feel like there should have been more. 

The game needs optimization, there are framrate drops and meshes sometimes become grainy, or "pourous", after playing the game for too long. As others have mentioned, there's little reason to craft tier 2+ stuff, and the vanilla island layouts are very limited. Add to this that the game's been in development for around seven - if not more! - years now, and the endgame is still not implemented: you're supposed to find and fix an abandoned airplane, and fly back to civilization; or contact some passing ship\ plane and be rescued.

As of right now, it's all just an endless survival sandbox. Has been for years now, it seems. It's fun and good as one, but if you advertise your game as something more, then be kind and deliver, is what I think. At least fix the bugs and optimize everything.

I can't say anything about the multiplayer or local co-op, since I've not played them, but there are plenty of other reviews talking about that.

So, is it a good game? Yes and no. 
Yes, because it does what it's supposed to, mostly.
No, because it's bugged and unfinished.

Do I recommend it? It can be fun, and if you want a slow and quite experience hopping tropical island and hunting sharks, it's definitely good. But, as mentioned, there are bugs, there's no endgame, and it feels as though the dev(s) abandoned it.

If you want to get it, do so when it's on sale, and possibly leave a negative review, maybe that'll motivate the dev(s) to return, or at least say something about the game's development.

100% recommended. There are lots of nice details and the survival feel is real most of the time and amazing sceneries all over. Underwater is beautifully done, it's fun to just swim around and look at the fishys. Though in such a game there is never enough improvement with the level of detail so there can always be more. A few bugs did happen here and there but that's okay. The devs are obviously working on the game and doing a good job imo. There are a couple of things that sometimes annoy me if I pay too much attention; for example the footstep sounds are archaic, and obnoxiously loud. In fact most sound effects are very bad, that's something that the devs apparently don't care much about but it's an important factor in terms of immersiveness for me. Ambience is nice, the sound of the waves etc but it's everything else from the sound of axe hitting wood to sound of fruit being picked, just sounds like it's an early 2000's game. But overall if you're into survival games then this is a good one for sure.

A lot has been said about this game already so I'll keep my review short. While Stranded Deep undoubtedly has a lot of potential, its current state of development simply keeps it from fully tapping it. This is an Alpha release at best, which impacts the overall gaming experience. Few hours in, you start to realize just how limited the variety of items and materials really is. The different islands are not exactly that - different and you soon find yourself in a loop of having to do the same things over and over gain. Despite all this, what the game lacks most is a compelling story. Any story for that matter.  My recommendation: Go and play "Raft". Much better mechanics and a slow burning story that will glue you to your seat for many hours.

Played this game for probably 90 hours between my wife and I on the playstation4. It had a good amount of glitches like freezing up while sailing to another island, whish caused you to lose stuff you were carrying or making you fall off the boat and it sailing away. I got into saving it right when i arrived to a new island and right before I left a island. sometimes I would save in between doing significant things as well. The major downside was the game would error out ( A LOT), and pretty much only when you save the game then the save doesnt go through and your at the last save point when you restart the game. I always send  the crash reports but it hasnt helped. I would love to get a playstation update to get all the features that the computer version has. So far only 9 hours into the MAC-steam version of the game. I like it a lot more, has a ton of new items and features like the map editing where you can create islands from scratch item by item. The playstation version you just select what stuff you want on the map and size and it generats one for you, not a lot of customization there. The computer version hasnt crashed while saving but it did freeze once while building a wood wall and I had to reset the game for it to work again. My macbook is exactly what the minimum requirements list but I did have to change the graphical all to the lowest options to get a smooth playing experience. I had to order a full wireless controller for me to play the game easily on the computer, it wasnt a requirement but it was a lot easier than trying to remember the keyboard shortcut letters to do different things. It also has the creative mode feature on the computer so you are invincible which is pretty neat to learn the game without dying constantly. Overall I love the game, the computer version has a lot more to it than the playstation and it doesn't crash like the playstation. But I did fall in love with the playstation version first so thats where id start if you do not have a capable computer that meets the requirements. I paid for the computer version but I received the playstation version for free.

After following the development of this game, almost from day one, I feel it has to be said, that the game really havent moved forward much, the last couple of years. 

The things that made the game good are still good. The game play is solid and not too much in terms of bugs to mention, after release.

The modding and the custom mode seem to be what we have to settle for, from here on. 
And that COULD be a good thing. 

The game´s main problem is, that the game-play loop is just not that interesting. The mechanics are solid and functional, but you end up not bothering with much of it. Here is an example:
Its easier and better to keep your primitive sail, instead of having to set up a Fuel Still to feed the engine, if you make that for the Raft. So you end up not bothering with late game items.

The base building is not good enough to carry the rest. And the "story", is not really a story. Its a series of boss fights, that mostly remind me of how games played in 2004. And badly so. Hitboxes, AI and animations of the Boss fights are hilariously bad, in some cases. Which is a huge anticlimactic moment, in general.

If you look for a game thats cozy and has a good Tamaguchi-effect, this game is fine and I enjoyed the general feel of the game. 

But if you look for survival games with substance and quality of content, good level-design and a solid story, youre better off playing Raft, imo. 

But not a bad indie-title and there should be at least 40-50 hours in it, just to learn the mechanics and drifting around the pacific on tropical Islands, that are all the same, somehow.
Give it a gander on sale. 

I recommend because my bar for games is low. Not because it will please everyone.

i wouldve given this game a solid yes however, the amount of bugs and issues going on in the game is so horrendous that you cant really even enjoy the game. until these bugs are fixed (if ever) there is no potential nor future for this game. and personally it isnt worth $14 until these bugs are fixed. because right now its only playable to people who have a prolonged tolerance and has the patience to relog multiple times just to get something to work. some good things are worth noting, it does have great graphics, good music, a good starting scene, and it has all of these ideas in the game that gives it great potential. this COULD be a good game, and minimal (funny) bugs are great to have too. this however is a game with bugs that arent even funny, they just make the game straight up miserable to play. i want to enjoy this game but i cant when i have to relog everytime something goes wrong. im not telling you what to do with your money, you can very well enjoy this game and find that your money is well spent. but i hope that this review is of some use to the people who arent sure if they want to get this or doesnt know if the game is worth it or not.

hopping from a tiny island to another nearly identical tiny island time and time again is not much fun. Even less when those islands are positioned in some rigid grid system. Next island? look west, north east or south, you ll see it. If you dont see an island, you re probably already on the edge of the small grid. because of this there is absolutely no feeling of exploration. The building system is pretty basic but completely irrelevant anyway (there really is no reason to build any structure). Killing shark after shark is not really fun either. Only thing you really can do is go after some mythical bosses with your self built copter, which breaks the poor immersion completely. 

 At the release  the dev promised there would be no zombies, dinos or monsters in this game  and their moderators, when asked about this change in the forums flat out lies about the dev  promising there would be no monsters, blaming the customer for buying the game in the first place.

This feels like 2 guys who made more money then they imagined, cant keep up with expectations but dont wanna use any of THEIR (OUR) precious money, because - why should they?

This is an incredible oceanic survival game with superb graphic environments. Crashed in an area of many small islands called 'PACIFICA', you travel from island to island gathering resources to survive, raiding other shipwrecks and planes crashes for specialty items, or craft what you need as you go....
there are only a couple of downsides for me personally...
1. when playing co-op online, there is no chat function, either in voice or in text, to communicate with your partner.
2. there was no mention of any goal other than surviving and the hope of rescue.....i mean, you find flare guns and once i heard a plane and tried to signal but nothing......but later through looking online, i found out that there are bosses to beat and a plane to find and repair, but i had to look for that info to find it, otherwise i might have been stranded for eternity!
All thigns considered, I give this game a huge thumbs up and highly recommend for survival gaming enthusiasts! 9/10.

I really, really want to leave a good review for this game, but it has sadly just became too much of a buggy mess.  When they decided to add a half baked multiplayer system, they went back on code that was years old and tried to patch it together.  As a result, anyone wanting to actually play a game that doesn't get unplayable after a few hours.. has to go back to the .80 build that was before the multiplayer addition.  Thats the "fix" offered, even though the game is honestly released.  I love this style of game, really really got into the game a while back, but it is just way too many bugs for no good reasons.

Yet another survival game—one that suffers from the same idiotic limitations every other survival game I've played suffers from: the inability to drink rain water by simply cupping your hands during a storm (instead having to scour the environment for coconuts or tarps or a handy nuclear fission device), the inability to survive a day without eating two pigs and a small cow, and the inability to skin an animal without gagging. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. 

This one adds the inability to eat more than two coconuts without vomiting (This is not a thing.) and more sharks in the archipelago than probably exist in the entire Atlantic Ocean.

On the other hand, you don't have worms start erupting from your flesh if you eat without washing your hands. So that's nice. 

Overall, it's one of the better games I've played. The survival mechanics aren't too ridiculous and the environment is gorgeous. It really feels like you're on the ocean during a storm or diving in shipwrecks while sharks prowl around. I'd probably list it as my second favorite survival game under Green Hell.

With the full release of Stranded Deep, I have to say I am unfortunately not able to recommend it to many people. There is a subset out there that'd enjoy this game, but it strays a bit too far from what I like in a survival game for me to personally enjoy it.

Fair Warning: I did not complete the game, I know for a fact I only got partway through it but what I did play didn't feel like it justified the extra time I'd have to put in to make more progress. I bought this game years ago when it was first announced and it showed a LOT of promise, the fact that the early~mid game hasn't improved and is still buggy is upsetting and a letdown.

While it has, and seems to encourage, the building of some kind of a base/shelter doing so can end up feeling like a detriment more than a benefit. Yes, you will have a place to store your things and grow your crops but you then have to permanently strip away the resources of multiple nearby islands just to make yourself semi-self sufficient. You cannot regrow trees, so any logs/planks you need to use are permanently used and only one of the native plants naturally regrows requiring farming to reproduce anything of value. 

Your personal inventory is extremely limited as well, you can craft extra belt slots but those just turn into hotkeys and not extra inventory space. Also, when holding something in your hands that can stack more often than not you will not be able to swap out to a new item with hotkeys since it considers the item in your hand separate from the stack in your inventory as you grab one item at a time from it and your character is too dumb to put it back in the same slot without manual input. Considering we magically know how to make an antidote from a random plant and an empty coconut I find it surprising we don't know how to make a backpack or understand the concept of organization.

Then on the performance side of things, placing the game on ultra high causes a strange ghosting effect with every action that the player takes, this may be because of frame limitations and Vsync but those are both necessary as this is one of the games that will cause mid~high end graphics cards to burn themselves out without limiting their framerate/enabling Vsync. My RTX 3070 hit 100% usage and started hitting high heat the instant I turned off Vsync. Playing on high with Vsync/capped framerate removes the ghosting issue.

Again, I wish I could recommend this game, but it seems to have an identity crisis of what it wants to do. It allows and incentivizes building a farm and crafting stations but it also wants you to island hop great distances with a very limited storage capacity even after building storage containers on a raft.

It could use some work with co op but the idea of exploring the world so see what it has is very cool and to do so with others is even better. however the server gets desynchronized very often it becomes a hastle and hard to play long term. For single player it is perfect. Just be aware that the game was developed with single player first and then multiplayer was slapped in later with bugs. I guess that it can be smooth sailing for solo play right.
lots to do and so much fun especiall dev tools. fun.

Do I recommend this game?  Yes and No.

Yes)  Initially you may be impressed by the graphics.  It is beautifully made and the environment is very realistic, down to the ocean breeze and sound of waves softly washing up on the beach.  So next you look around your first Island getting some basic materials to craft some tools and such.  Building isn't complex, but it's neither intuitive or well thought out.  Build yourself a little shelter, then hop on your raft and check out a nearby Island for more materials.  Very fun and gives you high hopes at first.

No)  You quickly realize there is no content in the game, content is almost never added, and the feeling that you wasted your money on yet another EARLY RELEASE money scam.  Where is the game as of today (October 12th, 2016?)  About 2 updates away from where it was Oct 12th, 2015).  This is the stranded ocean version of DayZ... but with even less content and more bugs.

Edit:  Feb 28th, 2019.  Where is the game now?

Well I did my review almost 2 and a half years ago, so for an early access game, much should have been done to get it rolling to release, if not released already.  The sad truth is the developer completely lost it and couldn't stick to anything, and after 5 years in development, is less fun, more buggy and further away from completion due to so many changes that just keep messing things up and requiring more and more delays.  If this game ever leaves Early Access, it won't be because it's in a state to be released.  It'll be shoved out because... f*uck it.

This developer had a great idea... and no plan.  Stranded Deep is the result of that, and as it's name implies, is stranded deep in Early Access, never to be rescued or seen again.

Edit:  September, 2022.

So I decided to give the game another go after another 3 years.  Total 7 years in development now, so this should be a very finished and polished game by now.  There's a squid, a helicopter, some more building features, a multiplayer that barely works, and... yes... the bugs are still plentiful and sometimes game breaking.  Still looks beautiful, but at this point that doesn't even matter.

Stranded Deep hasn't seemed to do anything but strand itself deep.

I bought this game with my brother, expecting to experience a fun survival adventure in cooperation.
It's the first time I've been as disapointed with a video game. It is purely a scam to call this kind of product a "release" level game. 

TLDR: Game is broken. Run away while you can.

Some of the problems encountered in about 7h of coop gameplay:
- collision bug dragging a barrel, ended up flying away with my dead body stuck on the invisible sky roof, forced to relaunch game
- attacked by shark, got bump in the air flying over 5-6 islands, my brother spent half and hour searching my body floating in the middle of nowhere, forced to relaunch game
- impossible to reconnect to mate game (really often wished for, as a last hope to fix various bugs)
- impossible to open inventory, cannot be fixed with containers or raft, forced to relaunch game
- loading times when creating the game are reallyyyyy long (>5min, both computers are under 2 years old, 16gb ram or more, 4 cores or more, and both over fiber connections)
- ressources are sparse, as you would expect for a survival, but you cannot move/dismantle/unbuild some things like raft base, etc, it is often a real problem when for example a raft rudder is only in one direction but your sails are already built in another direction on the raft...
- when dead, character 3d models lose their hands and feet or get weirdly distorted, what is that?!
- french translation is a joke, inverted words, barely enough to understand items
- no setting to change language in game, randomly switched from french to english
- setting to set watch alarm (bipping non-stop with no control over it) sound level called "UI sound"??? did anyone try to name things properly?!
- crafting using close items on the ground work absolutely randomly, sometines detecting everything, sometime not detecting the cloth item you are basically standing on
- randomly stuck save because "someone was driving a vehicule" whereas the 2 players present in the game were in front of the shelter...
- putting objects in the raft completely breaks all physics, making floating ressource gathering a real nightmare when you try to recover a floating tire in the middle of the sea for example
- growing the raft base is almost impossible without a mate orienting the existing base upward to avoid clipping in the ground (I bet this must be really funny on single player games)

I'm sure I have forgotten quite a lot of bugs and problems we had but these are some of the kind you will encounter playing.

So we decided to simply stop playing, not even because of frustration, but because we cannot play more than a few minutes before encountering a game breaking bug stopping us from playing and requiring a whole game relaunch and rejoin, taking several minutes.
I guess that now we have spent some time playing, giving every excuses to the game we cannot get a refund because we tried more than 2 hours.

Purely a scam.

I liked this game. I bought it in Alpha and played it off and on while it was being developed over years, and that was before it had no ending. Is the game a AAA title? No its not. Its a survival game (there are no Zombies). Imagine you are in the movie Cast Away. That's what its like. You crash in a plane at night in the ocean and have to paddle to a small island. The rest is survival. Build things, explore and find things. Visit different islands. Be aware, you might get lost. Find a compass, it will be your best friend while exploring other islands. Write down what direction you traveled before you go there, then write the reverse down so you know how to get home. Avoid water at night, you cant see anything, its super scary and its death. There are adverse weather effects and day and night. Your goal is to survive and find a way back home.

Game feels really unfinished

I won't even say the game is bad, it's just really annoying to play.
The content and the concept are fine, but the execution is sub par.

1. Terrible inventory management system
You can only hold about 8 unique items (maximum stacks of 4 of an item), which seems alright, except the basic items you need to take with you at all times add up to over half of that space, leaving you only being able to hold a few extra items while you're out exploring to find new resources. Normally you would want to find somewhere to dump all of the extra things you come across to make room for more, but for some reason a large crate holds less than half as much as your "backpack" and your pockets do. I say backpack like that because your character doesn't even appear to have an actual backpack. This also leads you to having many of these boxes thrown around your campsite because of how few items they hold. Also you should keep in mind that you found these boxes, you didn't craft them because of how tedious it is to find enough items to craft the ingredients required to craft whatever it is you need.

Also the user interface for your inventory in general just kind of sucks

2. ZERO indication on what some controls are
Want to figure out how to drop an item? You've got to guess. Want to figure out how to bind a tool to a hotbar slot? Figure it out yourself (yes, I ended up having to search the internet to figure that one out). In most games there's a small UI in some corner of your display that shows your options for what you can do with an item in hand, but this game has nothing. The input controls menu in the settings doesn't help either.

3. Frequent crashes
The game just doesn't want to keep running for some reason. I'll be a mile away from home on my life raft collecting items about to head back, and the game just gives up and freezes. And before anyone reading this assumes that I'm using a poor-spec system, I'll list them off for you:

CPU: AMD R7 3700x (clocked at 4.4 GHz, liquid cooled)
MB: Asus Strix x570-e
Memory: 32GB (4 x 8GB) DDR4 @ 3600MHz
GPU: Asus Strix 3070 8G OC

The game, while showing some potential, is more than flawed. The combat is unresponsive and unfair, gameplay is barebones, lacks fun milestones or ways of significantly changing what you do(Throughout the game you gather the same resources, loot the same places and craft the same stuff, without real improvements or changes to the gameplay loop).
Crafting, while present, is no fun. New structures do not advance your progress by any meaningful degree, you can't customize your raft and there is no incentive to progress to the "higher tiers" of buildings.
The fact that you can't build any of the production stations on your vessel, yet the game requires constant island-hopping to gather new resources feels just wrong. The islands lack variation and seem to be always based on one of two blueprints you quickly learn to identify. The fact that you can tell what the resources, enemies and layout of every island is gonna be, before even setting a foot on shore kills any fun exploration might bring. 
The "story" adds 3 bosses but in combination with the unbelievably flawed combat system makes you dread every single encounter. 

And for every technical problem that the game has, the multiplayer makes it 10 times worse. It has everything: Absurd long loading times on high end systems, random disconnects, bugs, synchronization issues.

The game needs work. At times you can see the potential: General Gameplay idea, Nice graphic effects, the water behavior, atmosphere during thunderstorms, yet all of that pales in comparison to the issues.

I use this game as a form of Self Care for my mental health, believe it or not. The ambiance is relaxing and soothing, the work required to survive is difficult enough without being overbearing or overwhelming. The combat is very nice, as well. I recommend this game to my gamer friends all the time. Thank you for creating it! I hope to see new development over time.
My frames sink lower than Davy Jones Locker.

Bought this game several years ago, went back today. I'll be honest... it doesn't *feel* like a 1.0 release, and I think it's a bit over-rated. There's some basic things that need some work: movement controls are semi-intuitive (toggle sprint by default isn't my favorite) but clunky (jumping is horribly implemented and doesn't trigger every time you hit the spacebar, climbing has no separate animation, pathing issues for the player moving from land to foundation), items in the hand are held at painful angles sometimes (especially the Torch), and... this is probably the most annoying... the inventory is both too large and too small.

Expounding on the inventory issue a bit: it's too large to feel realistic (even ignoring the issue of "where'd you get that backpack?"), but so small it's annoying. It suffers from the Pokemon inventory meme of "I can't fit 1 small Item, but because I have this other large item, I can fit three more". Huge issue there. Now, you can craft items to wear that increase your hotbar, which is interesting, but I'm not really a fan. There's also no weight mechanic implemented, so you can just fill your inventory with logs no problem. Given the size of the logs... yeah... honestly probably not happening.

From a design perspective, it's not the worst progression... but it's also not good. There's some high-tier goals, and some low-tier goals, and it feels like a decent pacing. Unfortunately, there's not a lot of mid-game content. You get the basics handled, then it's grinding for the high-end stuff. And when you get there you avoid probably the best mechanic in the game: ocean travel.

This is actually something I had a lot of fun with. I need things my home island doesn't provide, so I go to another island to search for them. Early game, this is the life raft. Mid game, this is a custom raft (about the only mid-game goal you can have), and end-game, this is either a motorboat or a gyrocopter. What was fun was needing to travel with the wind, planning my direction based on that, as well as the waves (legitimately a worry) and avoiding storms. Night literally becomes a good time to travel to stay out of the sun (before installing a canopy). Also, watch out for sharks! The end-game item being a gyrocopter both largely invalidates your previous mid-game juggernaut of a good-sized ship. I'll grant that the motorboat is actually a legit end-game goal in its own right, so kudos there.

The sad part is that the gameplay loop is... better than most, but ultimately very simple. Go to new island, scavenge everything, take home. Cut trees, build fire, eat fish caught within 5' of the shore with tier 1 tool in less than 5 minutes. Not a whole lot of incentives to do... honestly, anything else, and the loot table is so small and the threat of drowning and sharks so real (that's fine, no issues with that being a thing) that except for the grind for engine parts... it's not worth the risk to dive.

If you're into pure exploration, and crazy danger, and a more relaxed survival game, this might be for you. It's beautiful, the ocean feels alive (could use a few more types of fish down there), and legitimately a solid game.

But "solid" doesn't mean "good". I love this type of game, but this one just doesn't capture my attention. My rating is a C+ at best. Doesn't fail in any particular area, but honestly... there's other games out there that scratch the same itch, and probably do it better.

3rd and most likely final Update: So after playing in the multiplayer save for a little while, my friend just stopped being able to interact with anything. Couldn't pick things up, operate rafts, clipped though structures. The entire save was trashed.

Fast forward while and 1.0 comes out. We were hopeful until we read the patch notes. It saddened us to realize that even after several months, the multiplayer issues were still present and they acknowledged them but released anyway. I am not willing to put more time in the game knowing it could at any moment break and ruin a save.

2nd Hopeful Update: A buddy of mine convinced me to reinstall after the co-op update came out and I'm happy to say that a large majority of the issues have been fixed. 

Some of the problems that still exist are mostly minor but can cause problems if you don't save often. Beware of spaces in wrecks that look just big enough to squeeze in, you will most likely get stuck in the ground and drown and not be able to be revived because your body isn't actually where it appears to be. Desync with structures and rafts when each player is far apart is minor issue that can cause some odd things to happen but it's usually fixed when you rejoin the game.

All in all they have made some great progress and with a few tweaks will have an even better game than they do now.

[TL/DR] Would not recommend this game for various reasons, including limited resources, boring grind, and awful intentory. Devs are barely supporting the game and has been in development for over 5 years. While technically there, there are bugs, and frustrating mechanics.

This game is hard to recommend, and suffers many problems. It's not terrible, but it needs some serious work, and frankly I have very high doubts that it will achieve a good game status.

The game play loop is as you would expect for a survival game. Gather resources, further your survival and take on harder challenges to make life easier. However, problems start to arise almost as soon as you start. Your "core" resources, the ones that are needed for almost all crafting recipes, are scarce and half of them are not even renewable. These resources are so scarce, that you will run out of stuff on the second day and are clueless as to what to do now. The goal then is to go to other islands to get more resources, but this starts to have problems as well and it has to do with your inventory.

The inventory of this game is the biggest offender. Your character's inventory is small and unintuitive. It's frustrating to manage, often making you drop things on the ground so you can pick up a different thing to put in your backpack and then picking up the thing you dropped because the game is not programmed to swap things in hand. But probably the most frustrating thing is storage. You can't make storage for some reason, despite being able to make a gyrocopter just from intuition. The only thing you can make is a container shelf. Keep in mind that the container shelf is not the same as a regular shelf. The container shelf can hold containers that you can find from shipwrecks. This is the only way to store things in this game, and the container has incredibly limited storage, only being able to hold 3 stacks of items. Your character can hold 8 + 1 items, the one being your hand. How is a container only able to hold 1/3 of what you can carry?

Certain things that look like they can store stuff are not what they appear. For example, you can craft a toolbelt. You might think, "cool, i can store my tools on this to free up my inventory," but that isn't the case. No, the toolbelt only unlocks a certain amount of hotkey slots to assign your tools. How the hell does that even make sense? It is not worth making this.

So because inventory is a major problem, it starts to affect the entire experience. You need to go to other islands to get resources, but you can only carry so many and it can take a while to get back to your home island. You can build a raft however, and you can place container shelves on the raft so you can take less trips, but even that leads into another issue.

On top of being starved for resources, building things in this game is very expensive. Making a building is barely worth your time, and it eats up resources for breakfast. Again, half of these resources are not even renewable. The only things that are renewable are palm saplings, used to get fibrous leaves to make rope, and certain food plants. That's it. Rocks to make tools? Nope. Wood? Nope. There are enough here to get through the game, but it becomes a tiring grind to keep going to different islands just to get that one stick or plank you needed.

Technically speaking, it works, at least for me. I have read reports on the game outright not running on other systems but at the time it works for my system. There are various bugs, at one point my character somehow clipped into the floor of a sunken ship and prevented me from being able to resurface, and subsequently drowned. The graphics in this game are passable, rough around the edges but it works.

I have little patience for games that are released into early access only to be seemingly forgotten or not cared for. This game has been out for over 5 years now and has gone nowhere. Updates come out very slowly and don't seem to push the game forward. The last update only increased the world size and made the islands no longer placed on a grid.

All-in-all, you have a rather disappointing game that is thick with problems. I refuse to give this game any slack, as over 5 years of development should have smoothed out these problems by now, but it appears like the devs just don't care. Maybe they do, but until they show that I stand by what I say. I would not recommend this game.

(Edit) After keeping tabs on the game and seeing that it is now "feature complete", I decided to take another look to see if anything was addressed and tried replaying it. I can safely say that virtually nothing has changed and is still miserable to play. The only way they addressed storage was making item piles on the ground, but this solved nothing as you could already do that anyway.

Online multiplayer was added, which is a nice addition but I wouldn't want to play this game with friends anyway. I also read reports that it is buggy even after the update, but I cannot confirm that. 

Aside from that, keeping an eye on the updates shows that they were largely pointless, as most if not all updates did almost nothing except address a few bugs per update. It shocks me that it would take several months to address a few bugs, but I guess when you don't really care for your game it can take a while to get around to do it.

I still would not suggest this game. You're money is better spent elsewhere.

This game has been in 'beta' since 2015 and it is still horribly full of glitches and game play problems. Container shelves that will only install 3 feet above your raft, passive mode that doesn't stay passive when you reload a save game, foundations that will not place in the open but will place in the middle of a bunch of rocks. Things that should not be happening at this stage in development. This game is great in concept just not very good on delivery. I would say wait and get this game when the developers have all the bugs worked out and it is out of beta, but it doesn't seem that will be happening any time soon. I would recommend you find a different survival game for the time being because this one is not really playable at this point.

Edit: Since the update to version 1.0 the game has vastly improved! All of the major bugs seem to have been fixed and what is left are minor and do not detract from the game. This is one of my favorite survival games and I would now recommend it to anyone who also enjoys survival games.

Good survival crafting game. Realistic enough to suspend disbelief. I've been lost among the islands more times than I'm comfortable admitting.  Great game.
Highly addictive survival based strategy game. It's a great way to unwind while helping you develop your skills of prioritization.

Overall very nicely done, yet still a little rough around the edges, e. g. some of the spawns for plants on the islands are not reachable, not all aquatic animals can be killed (reef shark anyone)? and [spoiler]endgame cutscene is the same as the beginning one (same plane)[/spoiler].
The story is quite forgettable, as there isn't much develop. Also the bosses seemed rather easy to me [spoiler](just have enough spears)[/spoiler] and the base building system is unnecessary.
Besides these flaws it is a beautiful survival game with nice graphics and a nice style. Probs go out to the Developers who did this as a team of two!!!

this game has so much potential but after 28 hours in-game, i realized that the crafting options were very limited. my plan to look for clay and build a cute little house, decorate it and all the comfy stuff got shattered. so instead of me being able to spend 1000+ hours on this game, restarting, making new ways of surviving and new homes - i guess i only have a few hours left of killing bosses and fixing the plane. 

so a little disappointed, but if you don't care about the crafting parts much, then this is great for you and i of course very much enjoy the game for what it is. just not very replayable.

In-game time passes too fast for my taste; in-game minute is only about 1 second so there's not much time to think and do  stuff untill daylight is gone. I wish this could be player adjustable!!! There is a console command to change time but... Not exactly ideal for immersion and overall enjoyment.

EDIT/UPDATE:
Nexus Mods has some promising mods for this game that may or may not work as intended.

Definitely still not as refined as some other survival games but it's still lots of fun with beautiful scenery both on land and under water - beautiful underwater wrecks! What I mean by "as refined"; there are some features missing, like quickly changing between 1st and 3rd person view, (you have to use the menu for that) some effect sounds are missing, such as no sound when you turn on/off a flashlight and movement feels abit 'clanky' or clumsy esp. in 3rd person mode but it's not a game breaker at all. It's also completely missing  a mechanic for climbing over obstacles which, again is not a game breaker but leaves something to be desired. There seems to be quite alot of content with many things to craft and explore while trying to survive... In fact, there's lots of work to be done in the game but if you like this survival stuff, it's not a terrible grind that gets old and boring, not for me anyway and there are different modes to play with that let you explore freely, free of all dangers that is and a map editor which is particularily satisfying.

This game has A LOT of issues! lets start with standard survivor mode - the watch (your health meter) will quickly become hated. It constantly goes off leaving you very little time to do anything other then figure out WHY your dying AGAIN! once your fed up with the beeping and switch to creative (passive) mode you will start to notice the other issues fairly quickly. so let me start by listing them off - 

1. saved games - its hard to figure out where and if your game has even saved as it doesnt show it. trying to simply load a saved game becomes a challenge fairly quickly. 

2. co-op anything - if you want just a local game best be sure you have controllers and that they are assigned (never actually explaining HOW to do this mind you). once you figure out you have to give the code to your friends then it becomes an issue trying to get them into the game (where a simple game invite would help a great deal!) 

3. trying to construct basic things - would or should be simple but alas in this game not so much. And trying to figure out how to craft a better raft will make you want to throw your computer! 

in general there is a laundry list of issues with this game from simple game mechanics to overall ease of play. 
i personally feel i wasted my money as this game is anything but enjoyable.
