I decided to download it again now that they have a 1.0 release. I remembered this game being trash, it still it. Everything from being unable to use tools to magically duplicating items. This game is as bad as We Happy Few when it comes to game shattering glitches.

So, having had this game since the beginning I am super hyped to say that the developers really truly listen to their followers and that the game has made some great strides. I made a minor suggestion and it was taken into consideration and implemented. I'm happy that the game has a "story line" considering that it is mainly a survival, and crafting game.

TLDR: meh

I saw lots of videos when it was just released onto steam in Early Access. I was actually really hyped about it - I think it was released some time after The Forest came out in EA. The idea was really cool - obviously it looked like The Forest in water, but still. I haven't played much yet, but I can already tell you that the UI (especially the crafting one) sucks, so does the inventory and all of that. It's not really intuitive. There are skills, wchich I have no clue what they give - the game does not say anything about it - only in the store description of the game you can read that "it gives you maximum efficiency" - whatever that means... But still - I haven't read the desc on the store cuz why would I. 

The only good thing I can think of is the integration of the workshop. (For the developers, of course [but for the players too. at least kind of]) 
Money, money, money... Must be funny when you don't give a frick about content and just let the players add it for ya. Makes the game less likely to be abandoned by players so quickly. 

Also - I loled at the 1.0 release so badly. I can't tell wheter Beam Team was running out of money and they needed attention ("hey look, Stranded Deep was just released", being on Steam Store frontpage defo gives some players [me, for example lol], even hates gives you attention [looking at the comment section under 1.0 release post]) or they are just tired of this project or they wanted to abandon it. 

Obviously this game is also just old. Don't be fooled by "Date of release" this game has been in Early Access for seven years, probably even more in development or even in the designing stage. The core of the game itself is a bit rotten. Some games can survive in Early Access for many, many years and still be good. (Software Inc. as an example, it just left the alpha stage [it was in it for 7 years]) But this type of genre, is not it. The video game scene has been developing really rapidly - new GTX, RTX and all that stuff. You constantly have to up not only your graphics to meet the today's standards, but also mechanics, new features, now content. But being a small studio, publishing a game on your own - does not give you many options...

I couldn't actually decide wheter I should give it a positive or a negative review... But I'm leaning more towards the second one. Maybe... just maybe I'll play it some more, maybe it'll hook me up with something... interesting. Or idk, anything actually. I'm not gonna refund it for now - But if you want to still buy it I'd actually advise you to at least wait for a sale (like 40%, maybe)

Tried playing this with a friend, and it was absolutely terrible. There's no objectives to start off with, and the game does not even show you a tutorial or anything in regards to your controls or how to do things. You have to either figure it out yourself, or dig through their ridiculous settings. And when we were finally able to understand how to even play and build, we couldn't even use half the items, let alone what the raft had. 

My friend got poked by a shark, and upon his death his character glitched and flew up in the air, and then t-posed. Even with the bandage from the raft, I couldn't even bring him back, even though it gave me the indication on his character that I would be able to. I had to quite literally go inside his character JUST to revive. And on-top of all this, when the watch started beeping, it did not stop. Ever. Even when we got all our stats halfway/almost full, the watch. Still. Kept. Beeping. Non stop. 

Overall, the idea that the creators had for this game was great. You're stranded on an island with only a raft that has a couple basic supplies, then you have to try and survive the island. It's a great and fun idea, IF IT WAS EVEN DONE RIGHT! There's so many bugs/glitches in this game, and it took so long to even be able to invite my friend to the lobby, let alone even get anywhere in the raft because, surprise, it glitched and almost didn't move. I had the paddle in my hand, and was in the position to where I should be able to operate, but 90% of the time, we were just sitting there with the raft drifting.
Look out for shaaks. They BITE

After a few restarts and MANY deaths later, I think I finally got a grasp on this game.

The first time, I spawned onto a freight car and couldn't get my raft off. The second attempt, no crabs were spawning and I couldn't complete the tutorial missions. The third time I was spawned onto an island with hostile pigs that killed me almost immediately.

This game isn't conducive to building. You can only place 1 item at a time before have to go back and select that same item again. Basebuilding takes 3x as long because of bad UI. You have to hammer a whole bunch just to build anything decent. EVERY SINGLE item.

The supply chain is too extreme. Rope is needed for a lot of things, but leaves/fibers to make the item are far and few between. It takes 4 leaves to make 1 rope. The yucca tree drops 5 leaves. Yet, the big trees don't drop leaves? That makes no sense.

If you like a lot of clicking. I say get it, but it's a no. A BIG no, for me.

I wanted to like this game. I really did. But unfortunately between the bugs and the poorly thought out game play I just have no interest in it.

For one, co-op mode is buggy. Several times we had to log out and log back in because he could see me but he was invisible to me. This was made even more inconvenient because the time it takes to sync back up to each other after logging back in is insane. 

As far as bugs go, solo or co-op, they're annoying to say the least. The raft will randomly flip you out and send you flying, or the raft itself will go flying 100's of feet away from you. Sometimes objects don't spawn until your right next to them. 

And the poorly thought out game play. There are many ways to desalinize water, but this game allows only one. You can build a gyro-copter, but you can't figure out any way to get fresh water other than a cloth and some dead leaves? The game mechanics themselves are rough and annoying. Jumping works, sometimes. Or sometimes not at all. 

And on top of all that, the visuals aren't that great either. The water is nice. Character animations are wonky. Just hard to get any immersion. 

After a few days I just couldn't see myself wanting to play this anymore. After playing games like Icarus, Dayz, Rust, Green Hell etc, this game feels buggy and outdated. And very limiting.

I do wish they had some FAQs and better tooltips on creatures/inventory/items.

It's a lot of fun with a friend. It needs more polishing and more content. It REALLY needs better co-op loading system because it takes as long as gta to load and has no drop-in option, it just loads the entire save for both the client and the host which is VERY inconvenient for both players. Once the co-op is fixed, it would be great to be able to have at least 4 players instead of just 2, as it is now. More options for building rafts and bases would be greatly appreciated as well. (and some reason to actually build a base, as of now there isn't one, you just travel in  your raft from island to island gathering resourses to build a better raft).Like I said, it's fun with a friend, but it could be so much better with some tweaks here and there. Improve inventory system, add some avatar personalizaition options so that we are not clones. As it stands now it's eiher man or female with only 1 model each. Also, more story elements. I've been playing for 40 hours and have yet to find anything regarding the story. The survival is good, but it needs more events, A MAP! Or at least a map that you can "complete/discover" as you go. As of now, there only is a compass and you have to map the isles on paper yourself. Add objecives, fix that the "tutorial" doesn't work on co-op, so if you start playing with a friend, you have to figure everything out on your own. Some things are not very intuitive/user friendly. Some things you can craft by interacting with the object but others (like planks and cloth) have to be crafted from within the crafting menu while being next to the device that allows you to craft it (Plank maker thing and the loom). It reminds me of The Forest, in what I think it could have been it's very, very, early stages. If you like survival games, give it a try, it's fun and will give you quite a few hours of entertainment. I hope the devs keep working on it, because it can be so much better.

This game is so much fun! I love the experience of surviving on a desert island. There is lots of islands and shipwrecks to explore. If you love collecting loot to craft, then this is the game for you. Surviving depends on crafting. All sorts can kill you in this game, animals, poison, and more. The game has storms as well. There are limited resources, so this keeps you exploring. Build a raft and head out to sea but make sure to pack essentials for the trip. Everything so far has been so enjoyable. 

This game could be better in terms of building houses. There doesn't seem to be much point other than to keep you from getting sunburnt (but you can go under a shady tree or under boat canopy to prevent this). Also if you disassemble a building, you won't get your materials back. It would be better if you could reuse some resources. Or even a function where you can move built structures would also be ideal. 

Other than that, this is a super fun game when you feel like something light- but also keeps you on the edge of your seat to keep your character surviving. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival games.

it has a few weaknesses, but none are completely game-breaking.

IMO They do still need to provide an in game benefit or incentive to build structures on islands aside from rp.

As other reviews mention, rafts get caught up on stuff pretty easily, but that is actually believable. Running aground is a real threat and isn't easily fixed IRL, so that is more of a feature than a bug to me.

We need a way to obtain more rocks long term. I understand why they're limited, but being a finite resource that can prevent long term play from being viable. Maybe have deep underwater nodes that respawn while the stuff on islands doesn't?

Concept is good, still needs some polish, but leaves me with a favorable impression.

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

Let me start by saying that I do enjoy this game. I find myself drawn to it over and over because I very much enjoy survival crafting games. I've given it a no, however, because despite being considered fully released (at the time of writing) it still feels like an early access title. There are bugs, especially with the creatures. They float, they disappear into the earth, they can be seen standing in the air in the distance. There is a lot of polishing this game STILL needs, which makes me sad. I can't say anything regarding the story, as I've not gotten far enough to truly give feedback on it. 

I know this is a weird gripe to have, but the shark ai bothers the hell out of me. I understand it's a game and realism isn't exactly the focus, but these heat-seeking tooth torpedo's always draw me out of my immersion. They're just too aggressive and I never really care for fear-mongering animals that don't really deserve it. That being said, they are well modeled and animated and it does feel rewarding to take one down, especially as someone who is terrified to go in the ocean. 

The Raft buoyancy thing drives me up the wall. Maybe I just don't completely understand it, but it feels wildly inconsistent. Maybe it's just the weight of the items/animals that are off, but it feels like you absolutely HAVE to have a large, unwieldy raft in order to cart any of the larger items. Which sucks because they feel necessary. My raft is 6x4 with some storage on it, but it can't carry a single barrel without sinking a little? My raft base is made up of 24 barrels, how is it not supporting the one? I can understand a large shark weighing the rafts down, they're heavier than you'd expect, but barrels and tires shouldn't be this difficult. I can only imagine how difficult it must be to transport the big metal storage panels, if not downright impossible. I get wanting things to be challenging, I really do. Challenging can absolutely be fun, but in this case it is more irritating than anything. The physics with the raft is wonky still too. Things jitter as the raft moves, sometimes an item you have placed on the raft won't sink it, but you'll lose all control of your raft until you get rid of it. I feel that this in particular is unacceptable for a game that claims to be fully released. The rafts are such a key feature of the game, they NEED to work. Moving items from island to island in order to survive is so important and you can't even do it properly.

Overall I say consider it heavily before you buy. If you really enjoy survival/crafting games then by all means pick it up. It's come a long way and can be worth the money and time you invest into it. It just needs some fixing. Once it's had some patches, assuming they are still working on the game, I'll consider giving it a thumb's up.

Dear potential buyer,

I was an early adopter of the game back in 2015 when it was very buggy at release...years later not much has changed I see. After about 10 hours of playing this "full release" 1.0 version, I was bitten by a shark that was missing a hitbox, it then flipped my big raft that was already sinking because there were boxes on it (because "physics"), I was bleeding and was not able to craft a bandage despite having the materials, so I reloaded a save...which was promptly corrupted/deleted. So thanks for that 'beam team'!

Though the game has interesting concepts, and makes the 'grind' a little less 'grindy'. The entire thing is ruined by poor execution, bad bugs that make the game almost unplayable: hit boxes are the worst I've seen in a game in 20 years, shadows and reflection mapping is terrible, screen tearing is awful, save game system is pretty craptastic, island creation mode is unusable, last but not least object manipulation...oh its hot GARBAGE!! By "hot garbage" I mean like manipulating-a-pile-of poop-with-a-backhoe-wearing-oven-mits bad! Its somewhat of a joke that the developer has opted for a full release of this game when it has so many obvious issues...its certainly a "full release" of something. 

If you want a great survival style game with better mechanics, try anything but this. Like 'DayZ' or 'Green Hell' or 'The Long Dark' or 'SubNautica' or 'The Forest'.  heck these guys basically copied the intro from 'The Forest' anyway, so you might as well play a good game after experiencing the same intro anyway. 

2/10 - >:( <--angry frowny mouth-full-of-vegimite face

TLDR: As is the case with far too many Early Access games, Stranded Deep's potential was never realized.

In its finished form, Stranded Deep is interesting on the surface, but ultimately empty. There is little to do here, sadly, because I don't have a lot of the same complaints that others do. The inventory, while clunky to manage, is not a nightmare. It works. The building works. The rafts work. At first, exploring wrecks and hauling up boxes of mystery loot is exciting, but after your fifth or sixth wreck, when you get the same stuff AGAIN, you will realize there isn't anything more to the game.

After 30 hours I have done everything there is to do, and then did it again. And again. And again. I kept wanting there to be more, but there just isn't. IF this game looks intriguing to you, and you haven't played RAFT, get RAFT instead. If you've finished RAFT and are looking for something new to scratch that itch, don't bother with Stranded Deep.

For the love of God, (and I'm an atheist), *do not* spend money on this game. You will not enjoy anything you do in Stranded Deep, even if you do it right, even if you're good at it, and even if you master every skill tree.

Wanna make a tool? You better have sticks. You better have lashing. You know how you get lashing? Repeatedly chopping down saplings and yucca trees which take TWO DAYS to respond, and you can plant them, but be prepared to make another construction tool that doesn't do anything else besides unlock a different crafting menu and waste space in your tiny inventory of only eight items, when the game expects you to be carrying an axe, knife, and weapon at all times. Crafting skill is also a rather irritating addition from the stable release (as far as I could tell), and while more realistic, it makes the game less enjoyable. Imagine if in Minecraft, you couldn't make an iron pickaxe until you made 7 stone pickaxes, on top of only having your hotbar for your inventory. That's how it feels to make and carry items in Stranded Deep. It's *awful*.

Oftentimes, you might come across certain conditions you can't really do anything about because they're only cured by certain things, and you have to travel between islands to get them (mind you, if you want to do that in a way that doesn't take forever, you have to build a raft, which is incredibly cumbersome and costly if you use anything besides default sticks as materials). The game revels in realism, yet it's the worst part of the game. Animals worth hunting cost immense resources to even kill, and you can only replenish your health by having full hunger and thirst. The only time you might use those bandages you get at the start of the game is if you're using them to revive dead players in multiplayer, and that's if anyone would want to waste their time on this for multiple hours on end.

Nothing in Stranded Deep is particularly fun, because you work so hard for so little. The game is time-consuming, to a fault, and only feels rewarding due to the immense effort required in obtaining even basic necessities such as food, water, tools, and better travel across water and islands to acquire more resources in which the player is always in desperate need of, such as rocks and leather for crafting more than basic tools.

Play any other better, more popular survival game and save your $15; you won't regret it.
For a 5$ game it might be worth it, but honestly, I don't feel the experience was worth 15$.

It's time I make a review on this game, and its a long one. It's been 7 years since I first watched a YouTube video on Stranded Deep and fell in love, then I played it on my first account back when you would make martinis in the plane. This is the one game that I have followed since it's beginning, and now it's finally released. Every update, every hiccup, and every announcement has led to this. And I have to say, as a core follower, I have mixed feelings. On one hand I am amazed that a team of two developers made something as big as this, and made their dream come true. On the other, I wish they had done things a bit differently. Since it became more popular, there has always been 2 large issues. 1) A lack of communication and compromise with the community, and 2) A lack of priority balance between bug-fixing, content creation, and timely updates. I know it's unfair to just complain about issues without explanation, so I propose some ideas that may help with future endeavors. The greatest detriment to the development of Stranded Deep was communication. In the future, more community posts detailing progress and plans will make the community feel like it hasn't been abandoned. Also, while it is important to put your dream into the world, if you want anyone to play it you need to compromise and let the community have input. Another complaint I've seen a lot is the very large number of bugs that have been around a long time remaining unfixed while content is being pushed. I would've recommended taking time to make the game stable before expanding it. I don't want to come off as a hater because as I said in the beginning, I've loved this game since it was created. But these are just some friendly critiques that I feel may help in your hopefully long and prosperous future. As far as a recommendation? If you're new, absolutely, give it a try. If you're a veteran like myself and you're thinking of giving it another go to see what has come of it, I don't think it's a good idea. To grow up with the game, and then see the potential and spark in the game's eye fade is rather heartbreaking. Feel free to reply to this and tell me how you feel and if there is another way to look at it. Until then, at long last I give my review and close this chapter.

[h1]My full review: [/h1]
Honestly, this game was fun for a bit. Playing with some friends is a blast for a while but that's all I could say about this game. This game had a surprising amount of potential with its awesome graphics and premise, the sheer amount and was the game that really popularise the raft survival genre for years to come. It was so popular that youtubers like Markiplier, jacksepticeye and even PewDiePie was playing this back in 2015. 

I bought this game back when this game shortly after close this game was first put up on steam back in 2015 and it was fun for about 6-7 hours. At the time, it was understandable that the game was bare bones but after playing it again after 7 years out of curiosity of the state of the game, I was surprised on how the game still felt the same bare bones feel to it but I was curious enough to play multiplayer with a friend and it was fun for a bit until me and my friend drop this game out of disinterest. This game looked awesome but didn't had the engaging content to continue playing and had a lot of bugs to the point where it was ridiculous like a shark colliding into our starting raft that it was sent flying to the stratosphere on our first day or frames dropping in for the second player whenever your massive raft is being dragged by a player. 

And when I saw news that 1.0 came out, I looked at the patch notes and it looked like they didn't even update a lot of things to warrant a complete product like building is just meaningless due to there still being no reason as animals and monsters are still buggy and just go through walls if they felt like it, there isn't a way that I know of to locate the direction of the 3 bosses needed to complete the game and monsters are somewhat buggy especially the wild boar where it tends to just get stuck sometimes or even just levitate and when you kill it with spears it tends to just spazzes out. 

The game probably came out of early access probably because a better survival raft game called 'Raft' came out nearly 2 months ago to great success, it felt like the devs didn't want to update this game which is more evident by the slow update pace back when it was in early access. I mean fair enough but it's a bit of a shame really. All I hope now is that if Beam Team makes a new game, it wouldn't repeat the same development process as this game both game wise and developers' feeling wise.

Should you buy this game?
Short answer: No
Long answer: Hell No

I wish there was a 50/50 recommendation, especially for this game as for me this game is kinda middle of the road for a survival game, the graphics are good, while they aren't the best and definitely show their age they still look good, especially the water, the water looks good, aside from that there has been a lot of issues with this game, I personally don't really care about some of that stuff and let it impact my opinion of a game. 

However one of the major issues I have with this game is a lack of content that is interesting outside of searching the same like 10-20 (if I'm being nice) copy pasted shipwrecks over and over again to find resources that are hard to get and some that can't even be crafted. The other issue I have is that there is a series of levels that prevent you from building certain items or tools because you don't have the right level, it really discourages you from getting a crop plot built so you can plant more food. Along with these problems is how the inventory works, it is terrible, you have 5, 6 slots, maybe, to put things in, you get a lot of things you need to carry with you, axe, knife, food, water, etc. on top of that you also need to have enough inventory to be able to carry whatever you find said shipwrecks which leads to you needing to drop everything so you can pick up almost everything of value from them.

In general this game could've been really good if it had more time to be fine tuned and if the devs added more content to explore and do, but alas it was not to be, but for that, I wouldn't recommend buying this game, as looks can't save something that is hollow at its core.

It's definitely a grind but it's pretty fun for a while. The survival elements on normal difficulty are very casual and combat elements are limited to hunting and fighting sharks. Just make sure to build a raft before you build a base; the good resources are all finite, and building costs can be pretty steep.

There's no practical application to building bases, but you can build some nice looking buildings to spruce up your home island. Raft building is absolutely barebones, so don't go into this expecting it to be like Raft. While there are a few different types of raft bases, there are only a handful of things that can be built above deck: motor, rudder, sail, anchor, canopy, storage container shelf, light post. No genuine customization of any kind.

The real selling point is the environment. The map is gorgeous and fun to explore, and the light survival elements keep you engaged enough for it to be immersive. That said, after 80+ hours, I'm starting to wonder what my end-goal is (the boss fights just look tedious, so I'm not going to bother). Unfortunately, it all starts to lose its charm once you've explored a few islands and realized they're all essentially the same. There's very little variability of animals, so hunting is limited to 2-5 aggressive land animals and 0-2 passive land animals per island. After exploring ~20 islands, I've found that most just have the two giant crabs, which sucks because I really enjoy the challenge of hunting snakes.

I wouldn't say that it's worth the full $15. You may want to wait for it to go on sale, since I don't see it having much replay value.

The concept for this game is pretty good. The graphics and the setting are okay. As someone who has dived in both Southeast Asia and Australia however, I can tell you that the developers put very little realism or attention to detail in this game. Sharks have been very demonised in this game. I have swam with sharks before and the only way to get attacked by sharks as often as you do in this game would be to wear a wet suit made from freshly caught fish meat. 

Other inconsistencies are:
   - Wild pigs may be aggressive if you approach them by surprise but they would not track a human all over an island to attack them.
   - Giant crabs don't spend a lot of time on land and when they are on land, they cannot run due to the weight of their shells.
   - In this game you can make a raft base out of tyres. TYRES?? They don't float. Their inner tubes might but the tyres don't.
   - Light from the sun can penetrate much deeper into clear Pacific waters than it does in this game. 

The developers have also released this game as the finished project but there are still some very noticeable glitches in it. UPDATE 17/12/2019
Despite me saying I wouldn't come back to this game I got really bored so I decided I was going to see what was different. I'll credit the devs with not giving up on this game but in all honesty this game still lacks purpose and I yet again got bored after surviving just 6 days (which is a few hours of gameplay... maybe 5 or so?)

Like there are things in this game that just feel simply pointless like building a base... why bother? you cant save in it, you cant even use items in it, you can build a shelf but that shelf doesnt even store objects on it... The storage and inventory management is still atrocious having about 20 boxes in your base that hold 3 items in each meaning you have stacks of them that are taller than small palm trees and bushes. You still cant carry a lot of them on your raft without it wigging the hell out and going berserk. Barrels and bouys etc and pretty much anything other than these storage boxes cant go on the raft either cos that will still cause it to go absolutely nuts.

I honestly couldn't tell you what the end game is or if there even is one because I loose interest in it way too damn quickly to work it out. Why is this important? because well at this stage this game is probably never going to get finished in a way that does it justice.

I know this is very negative and I really wish it didn't have to be, but being a lover of sharks this game caught my attention as soon as it popped into early access. It's made me sad to see that a game that was supposed to be out of early access in 2015 (the same year it went into early access) is still almost the same game 4 years later and like I said I will give credit to the devs for sticking with it. THE DEVS ARE NOT INCOMPETENT and a credit to them and the studio for sticking with this game. Who knows in a few more years maybe it will be the game that I was hoping for but for now its still the same old uncomplete stranded deep.

UPDATE 23/01/2018
To start off with this game has had so many damn "hotfix" updates its just ridiculous. It kinda sets off a big WARNING sign just by looking at the newsfeed for this game. Every "major" *Cough* update has about 4 hotfixes after it just to fix the problems with the update. this happens EVERY time... like... come on.

So it has been a year since I last played this game and I am content with saying that this game is done and dead for me. There are barely any noticeable changes to the game, the gameplay itself is just boring and after you play the first few hours you're just like... I am gonna go drown myself or jump into the water and see how many sharks I can kill before I die. I am not kidding. Seriously. It gets VERY boring VERY quickly. It feels like the game isn't even in the same direction anymore. I would have hoped for a wider playable area by now but NOPE still tiny AF, some more wildlife perhaps? nope. Still the same. Don't bother wasting your money. This game is going nowhere REAAAAAALLY slowly. The development is like its own survival story. 

I find it hard to really say anything positive about the game at this point so I am not going to even try. Sorry.

UPDATE 27/12/2016
after 6 months of not playing i decided to give the latest build a try.  I did notice some visual improvements specifically related to the player model and the islands. I also noticed the addition of a new inventory UI (which is pretty great) and the more pointless change of the crafting UI.  Tbh It seems like a lot of time is going into a lot of pointless changes in this game that should NOT sacrifice time from making the overal game experience. You barely see any other types of sharks or any real marine life. The sharks behave pretty much the same as they used to but dont get stuck in the ground.  Even a 3 man team should have had all of these "updates" done within a year.... not 2. 

So look. this game is worth getting if you get it on a steam sale, even if its just to play around with it for a few hours. BUT DO NOT EXPECT THIS GAME TO EVER LEAVE EARLY ACCESS AS A COMPLETE GAME THAT CONTATINS DAYS OF FUN!

I've seen a lot of mixed reviews and controversy surrounding this game, so I thought I'd offer my own thoughts. These are just my opinions, of course, but I honestly do stand by them, and I've thought about this a lot.

Stranded Deep is... well, interesting. I don't necessarily mean that in the conventional sense, as in terms of features, it's pretty basic and barren compared to many survival games. Still, it is... unique? I hesitate to call it that, as many similar titles do exist, but in fairness, a lot of them draw inspiration from this game. As such, I wouldn't call it unimaginative, just... well, unfinished, which I realize is an odd comment to make considering that it just saw its 1.0 release.

Sure, people have made some very legitimate criticisms of the developers, what with unmet goals, not listening to the community, and a number of other things. Honestly, I feel a bit uncomfortable bringing it up, as I haven't really been paying attention, but it's still worth mentioning.

Now then, content. The area that many people say this game is lacking in, and I would be inclined to agree. Many older games are still fun to play and conventionally good by modern standards because they make up for their aging appearances with diverse and varied gameplay that never truly gets old. Stranded Deep is sort of the opposite. Its beautiful visuals do their best to cover up that, at its core, the game is somewhat lacking in features. It's immersive to a point, don't get me wrong, but not necessarily all that engaging. 

Still, I feel that there's something here, and I haven't heard enough people bring it up. If you want a beautifully polished survival game with a decent story, go play Subnautica or The Forest. I have yet to try out Subnautica, but from what I've seen and heard, it speaks for itself. In that department, Stranded Deep doesn't hold a candle to other survival games.

Where it shines is the relaxing element. Video games don't all have to be super engaging. When I'm stressed out, I like to play games that take away some of my attention, but still allow me to decompress as opposed to switching all of my focus from one thing to another. The Forest, for instance, is an absolute masterpiece, and one that I highly recommend, but it certainly isn't relaxing. Stranded Deep just is, and while that might not be for everyone, I enjoy it.

To sum it up, a large number of the criticisms people make of this game are entirely justified. It's light on features, the devs have made a number of promises that they haven't kept, and the story is, to say the least, lacking. I certainly wouldn't call it a terrible game, but it's not an award winner either. At the end of the day, though, it's fifteen dollars, and considering all of the enjoyment I've gotten from it, I can't not recommend it.

This game needs some much needed love. There's a good base game here but so many mechanics need the code to be scoured for bugs and or adjustment. For instance, sleeping should always awaken you at dawn not when it's still the evening hours (you can't sleep again so soon).

And I've had so many items just vanish/drop from my inventory even when I haven't dropped anything unintentionally at all like axes, lost my compass a few times and countless knives.

Inventory needs a lot of love, there's just no space even the items that stack you can't carry more than a few in each given slot.  And Traveling on the life raft an hour after creating a character because there wasn't more than 4-5 rocks on the starting island is bad.

In addition you can build massive rafts which is very cool and does give you something to aim for but you cannot build walls, half walls, or any building structures on your massive raft. Even something so obvious as a bed, or in this games case a shelter cannot be placed on the surface of a raft.

Stranded Deep is about as generic a survival game as you can get these days. The overall feel of play-style sways towards simplicity, relying on resource shortage and brutal forward planning in order to hold up the game play mechanic. The world doesn't really feel like it wants to open up to the player, instead opting for a feeling of helplessness and an inevitable grind towards success.

Crafting is, at best, basic and, at its worst, frustrating. Creating a raft (your primary item of choice if you wish to survive) is simple, but also tricky to undertake because of physics collisions, weight distribution problems (placing a single vehicle tyre onto your raft can have the entire construction spinning out of control, or cause it to drown) and space restrictions. It's meant to be realistic, but the execution of it is glitchy and immersion-breaking, often adding frustration to your task. On top of that, there is very little you are allowed to add to the raft as a vehicle, ending up with your final creation being uninspiring and boring. Want to build a little sleep area that's enclosed, with maybe something to cook on - Nope! You can construct a shelf system for your crates, a sail, a rudder, a simple stone anchor and, if you're really feeling fancy, you can build an outboard engine. The latter of which requires a contrived, painfully slow process of farming potatoes (from limited resources) in order to distill them into fuel. It all feels a bit over-the-top., while also being incredibly underwhelming.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2839474907
Crafting on land is marginally more involved, with basic structures that you'd expect from a castaway survival situation. It's not terrible, but it's not particularly inspiring either. With resources being cruelly sparse, requiring plenty of island hopping to support any form of player home settlement, it soon becomes tiring to have to travel vast distances just to get some sticks or enough fiber for crafting [i]and[/i] water production. Some might enjoy the challenge - indeed I did at first - but it soon becomes a grind, taking away the thrill of exploration and discovery and replacing it with necessity. Not really good for anything but die-hard survivalist wannabe's.

As for the story - I honestly haven't come across anything so far that gives me a clue of what I am supposed to do to get home. It might be something added on final release, but as yet it's a big mystery to me. I see hints of what I can craft from the story (4 items) but there's no connection to them in any form so far in my 21 hours of this play-through (Day 32) that I am attempting in July of 2022. Hopefully that will change. People shouldn't have to look up spoiler guides and sift through forums just to find out what they should be doing. Short of that you will likely just float aimlessly around the game world until you bump into something, which could take little time for the bold explorer, or tens of hours for the cautious gamer.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2840476978
Now to the bugs; There's plenty! Physics causing catapulting of trees when cutting them down, physics glitches with your raft, instability issues and (for me) a flickering shadows problem that has existed for 7 years, with no progress made by the developers to fix it. I am not alone with this glitch. It's apparently quite common, especially the further you explore and on the larger islands. It's not the end of the World, but it breaks immersion considerably and is extremely uncomfortable on the eyes,

Visually (aside from technical bugs), the game is very pretty to look at. The water elements are quite beautiful and there's plenty of wildlife to make it feel alive and atmospheric. Colour use is decent, giving a truly tropical feel to the environment. Indeed, graphically it is a great showcase of what modern game engine technology can produce. Especially when it's designed by a fairly small team.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2840476961
My gripes: 
1) [b]Graphical glitches need to be prioritized by the developers.[/b] It's not good to have a screen output that's uncomfortable to look at or that ruins all the hard work that's gone into creating this beautiful environment.
2) [b]The islands are all far too small.[/b] There's too much emphasis on forcing players to island-hop for resources. Encouraging the player to explore can still be achieved without brute force. The island sizes never offer enough space for a player to get comfortable in the game and create something special as a home. It feels like the developers are keen for the player to simply keep moving until the end of the, erm... story?!?
3) [b]The story is too well hidden.[/b] I want at least some direction when I play games. It doesn't need to hold my hand, but zero information just makes it aimless and uncertain. Not a good way to design a story. This needs significant work.
4) [b]The grind - there's too much of it![/b] Making a player hop islands (taking up significant time, depending on distance) just to get a few logs to make planks, or resupply an island of wooden sticks for cooking and crafting, because there's nothing left to cut down on the island the player has decided to settle on, is contrived, boring and grindy. There's no need for this. Look at Green Hell or Subnautica for reference. There's an abundance of resources everywhere (for the most part) but it doesn't lock the player into position. Instead it makes preparation for exploration more enjoyable - heightening the excitement of discovering new places.
5) [b]Challenging survival frustrations.[/b] Staying alive is what this game is all about, but the grind added to make it fit into this genre is bordering on lazy design instead of thoughtful complexity. This is a tricky aspect that I also cover in my likes as well, but needs to be mentioned.
6) [b]Painfully slow game development for what is ultimately a very small game.[/b]

My likes:
1) [b]Gorgeous environmental effort.[/b] The world looks beautiful and the water is realistic feeling and immersive. The developers have done a great job with the overall visual and dynamic environment.
2) [b]Decent sound design.[/b] It sounds nice and there's plenty of atmosphere created around the player from the various audio elements.
3) [b]Fantastic colours.[/b] A truly tropical vibe. A lovely water pallet and a vibrant and inviting overall feel for the world space.
4) [b]Wonderful looking wildlife.[/b] With the exception of over-sized crabs, the overall look and feel of the wildlife is so good you'll likely want to spend time (especially under water) just drinking it in and experiencing the flora and fauna of a tropical dream holiday. It's not at all safe, but it's incredibly immersive. Enough that you don't really need a story if there was more space to explore on land and more emphasis on taking in the wonders of the tropics. Very nice indeed.
5) [b]Enough building for the simple craftsman.[/b] There's quite a selection of things to build, even if the game doesn't balance it well or give it purpose. It's not enough for impressive creativity, but it lends to the game enough to warrant a mention.
6) [b]Challenging survival.[/b] Staying alive is tough. You need to look where you are going and pay attention to your needs. it's what the game centers around and it, almost, works. I prefer thoughtful survival mechanics over brute force, lazy design. It's a bit of "love it and hate it" as far as this aspect goes.

I'd give this game a somewhat generous 7/10, but must warn of glitches that can potentially ruin your experience.

Oh God where to begin with this one...  another full whack £10.99 half baked game which has been described as the 'Castaway Simulator', only that it is waaayyy worse. Before the recent patch you were in a plane and you crash, the only survivor and you have to survive using the islands. Now I don't know if its just me but now I just spawn in the middle of the ocean in a raft without a paddle....whaaa! 
But enough about that.... on with the show! Just like The Forest, Stranded Deep is half complete; with no story what-so-ever (and I know its early access; but if you're asking that much money then you'd better be awesome!) and with that comes the boring tedious 'hack and slash that tree!' simulator. However this game is much worse than the competition for the following reasons: No multiplayer, No story and no land-based threats. Nothing washes up on shore to add anything interesting to this game and its one you cannot complete, as guess what; you don't have a story! 
The time has come... this Early access train has to stop, you can't just put up some half done product and get people to pay full whack, then take forever to release it as complete (I don't think this will ever leave early access) and for that I cannot reccommend this...3/10

TLDR: A great addition to the survival genre! Well worth your time if you enjoy games like Green Hell, The Forest, and Raft. Co-op works with some minor bugs.

When this game first came out, there were some pretty frustrating bugs. But the only bugs I've run into since the 01/2022 update is that the guest will sometimes be unable to see the host, or unable to see the smoker/grill. A simple relog will fix this. Riding on a raft is MUCH improved since launch, the one not-driving no longer has to battle the inertia of the raft, and can more or less AFK the ride without fear of falling off. 

Most audio bugs (so far) have been fixed. The one specifically I'm thinking of is that the game would enter a state when your partner would get low on food or water, but your watch would keep beeping long after the hunger/thirst was addressed. That hasn't happened yet, and fingers crossed it doesn't. 

OH! And plant fiber is much more abundant and seems to respawn while you're still on the island. Rocks seem to be the rare/limited resource now, so plan accordingly.

Stranded Deep is a realistic, adventurous survival game where you will encounter some of the most challenging and life threatening scenarios that keep you on the edge of your seat. You play as a survivor from a plane crash, somewhere in the pacific ocean, surrounded by distant deserted islands around you. As you navigate your way through dangers and hazards from man-eating sharks to diarrhoea, you will need both safety and patience in order to survive. This game also includes building all sorts of different things, that require different materials, and you are able to build a really futuristic looking base with the sun rays beaming through your windows at sunrise.


I've played this game with a friend, and we have truly loved it as some core memories were made as we survived the dangers of the Pacific Ocean. If your looking for a game that requires a bit of patience and also a really enjoyable survival, adventurous, and realistic game then this one ticks your boxes.

This game seems primitive in its own way, fighting bosses can feel janky at times, and you're incentivized to use safespot exploits to beat them. BUT, the grind and progression of this game is extremely satisfying. The graphics are absolutely gorgeous, exploring wrecks is very fun. The wildlife threats will keep you on your toes, and you're gonna die quite a few times, as there are venomous creatures akin to Green Hell which can end your run upon a misstep. But it does indeed require a misstep, and most of the time, if you're experienced, you can grow anti-venom long before you make the mistake of stepping on a venomous creature. Fighting sharks is difficult, but again, you can pull a Jaws and safespot them from a sunken ship or something, hurling spears at them.

The game has some good things like the OST,setting,sound design and few more things,but right now,this shit is unplayable (in coop at least). I've ignored the absurd amount of bugs me and my friend encountered while playing the game untill the game killed us while flipping our raft and basically,ending our run.

Just to name a few of the thousand bugs this game has:
1-Sometimes you drop something and it clipps in the ground and you lose it forever.
2-Sometimes a hammerhead shark can instakill you and send your body flying out of the world,meaning you cant be revived and you have to wait like 30-60 minutes to die.
3-940238523 different physics bugs.
4-Sometimes the game will do this: one of the players will get the annoying warning of a friend being dead (its like an alarm that never stops) while the friend is in fact,alive. And after 2-5 min that ally will simply die out of nowhere,and once you revive him,he will be 100% hp(my friend died 8 times because of this bug).
5-Rafts can literally flip themselves out of nowhere.
6-Character models break once you die.
7-Dead pigs are still shaking their heads non stop.
8-Some items will "duplicate" for no reason,but they are not 2 separate items,more like this: my friend has a hammer,I see the hammer on the ground,I can pick and I can try to use It,but It looks invisible to me while my friend can see and use It normally(this happened to us more than 10 times I believe).
9-I haven't played enough singleplayer to be 100% sure but seems like a huge amount of these bugs are from the coop play.

And now lets talk about flaws:
1-Trees respawn and wood consumption are badly balanced.
2-Seems like there's no way to stop ground animals from respawning in your base.
3-Some plants are useless and some of them are way too important (like Pipi,since 3 different animals can inflict poison on you).
4-Don't even bother building a bow,seriously.
5-Combat feels extremely clunky (except for the speargun).
6-5 years of development and there's a serious lack of content. A great amount of the content is building a huge raft,your base,etc,and that brings me to the 7th flaw.
7-Building is unintuitive and clunky,doesn't feel great.
8-Meat rottens way too fast,and becomes "unrottable" once you smoke it. A little bit unbalanced imo.
9-Campfires tend to bug your small meat (only if the meat is small and you put it in the stick slot) no letting you picking it up,and since the game doesn't let you destroy the campfire while there's something attached to it...you're fucked.
10-For some reason,your inventory has 10 slots,chests use the same inventory design,but they have only 5 slots and there's no way to expand neither their capacity nor yours.
11-Trying to control the raft without an engine or sails is quite peepo clown.

There are still more flaws/issues with the game but Im tired at this point,you get the idea. I hope this game improves A LOT in the future because It has potential and I actually liked it in many ways,but right now I feel that anyone who recommends this game is simply scamming people.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Good game for the most part. 

Crafting is pretty simple and straightforward but is horrible on a fresh save file. It's aggrivating to need to level up in order to craft something. Not exactly a bad idea but is something that should be able to be turned off in world creation settings.

The music is much more light hearted than it used to be. taking alot of inspiration from the castaway OST. It's pretty nice music but should not be played every 2 minutes. (Take the piano music from the old version for example. It wasnt constant and played occasionally when you actually need the comfort of music)

The graphics are pretty good but i cant be the only one that thinks that certain aspects have been downgraded such as the reflections almost being non existant.

Speaking of downgrades i do feel like there are parts of the old version (0.04.h2) that are better than the final version. 

The Tone
I feel that the tone of the old and final version are drastically different from eachother. The final version is more light hearted and filled with hope (even the shark music was made more light hearted) and the colors and music reflect this. However, the old original version from 2015 was grittier and hopeless feeling. The occasional music that played (which was really one piano piece unlike the final version's bigger variety of soundtracks.) was depressing (and matched the hopeless feeling of being stranded in the middle of the sea where you would likely die in) and was the only real comfort you would get. The colors were sort of bright as well but in a more realistic sense. The shark music had some bits kept in the final version but was much more different and scarier and included a slow reverb and background beat that made it feel like somthing out of a horror movie/game. 

World generation
While the final version had a big variety of structures and island types. The old version basically had the same feeling islands everytime as well as the ships. The only thing about the world generation that the old version does better is the fact that its infinite. What would improve the final version's world generation is if it you gave an option to turn on infinite islands. Although an upside to having limited islands is that your resources are actually limited which can make things harder later in the game and encouraging you to explore the islands more carefully rather than just loot real quick and find the next island.


In other words i still recommend buying this. The old version and final versions have aspects that are a bit better than eachother and both worth playing. I would definitely go for the final version because theres alot more content and polish to it plus the mod support. Hope to see this game improve more in the future.

I was inclined to write a negative review even though I think this game has better gameplay mechanics than Raft. It's really fun. It even has a cartographer feature where you can place custom island in your existing/new games. No other raft survivalgame offers that much. Combat is satisfying. The graphics are gorgeous. So is the music. And it's still early access so there's a world of possibilities to improve the game.

But... Well, did I mention the game is really really fun? It surely is. Until it isn't. The game has many game breaking bugs right now. Crates that misteriously disappear when you drop them, even in single player mode. So carry a bed with you and save often. Coop is a desync and disconnect mess and takes a lot of time for the client to rejoin and sometimes the client can't for some reason. This game still can be the best lost-at-sea survival game out there if they manage to clear the game breaking bugs.

I promise that I'll change my review to positive as soon as they patch the game. I just can't recommend it right now especially for coop mode because frustration is inevitable.

Survival games have stayed very popular in the last several years with the gaming community, letting players can craft items, maintain their thirst and hunger, and try to stay alive in harsh environments. Beam Team Games' Stranded Deep fits perfectly in this genre, finally releasing on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One after an early access run on PC. Stranded Deep is very difficult and stressful at times, and fans of the genre will have a lot of fun trying to make it off their island alive.

Stranded Deep begins with the player sitting on a plane, minding their own business, when all of a sudden the plane begins plummeting out of the sky. After falling unconscious, players come to just to realize that they are trapped on the airplane as it descends underwater. The very first challenge of Stranded Deep is to swim through the carcass of the sinking plane and discover a way to the surface. Once completing this task, players will find a lifeboat nearby that transports them to a nearby island with only a few rations and a compass to keep them alive. The opening of Stranded Deep is an incredible action oriented set piece that really sets the stage for something exciting.

Don't normally write game reviews but in this case I decided to make an exception. 

I want to say that this game is awesome. 
I want to tell you how much fun me and my son had playing this together (he's 5 and loves building games).
I want to tell you that it was worth the money. 

Unfortunately for the 20 or so hours that I've played this game, I've been either attempting to repair damage to save games via the admin console due to bugs, roaming around endlessly looking for that last rock I needed to make something (before getting eaten by a shark trying to swim to another island to get a rock...) or finding out that forgetting to hit save (in 2022..) before logging off after a 2 hour play session results in an unhappy 5 year old co-gamer.

On the face of it, the game is absolutely beautiful. The utmost effort has gone into making this game a visual masterpiece. The designers have attempted to make a somewhat seemless interface in order to promote immersion and to a point it does work. It breaks down when you need to do something complex like being able to switch items in your hand... because your inventory is inexplicably full (when it isn't) and the game doesn't offer any clues as to "why" it thinks it's full... so you just end up having to throw shit on the ground to make room.

The amount of actual content in the game is lacklustre at best, one island is the same as another and once you've succeeded in building your raft and arriving at pacific island number 473 there really isn't anything else to do. An argument could be made saying that it's a sandbox game where you build your own content but in that case, the "building blocks" you have access to are few and difficult to place in the world. The silhoutte of the block, be it the start of a raft or a building will turn inexplicably red and refuse to be placed, without any indication as to why. 

Instead of carefully crafting the start of your long range cruising raft with inbuilt storage, living quarters and fishing hole, you end up trying to figure out how to make something larger than 3 barrels and some string because nothing else can be attached if you don't jack up your boat so it's floating in the air...

The environment is gorgeous, you're surrounded by intricately detailed models of trees and rocks, cliffs, beautiful shorelines etc the VAST majority of which you can't interact with. You can be sorely in need of wood, surrounded by 100 ft trees, ship wrecks and the ruined huts of other lowly marooned mariners long dead and apparently... out of wood... 

You can be sorely in need of stone rocks, standing beside a 30 ft high stone cliff with an actual pick axe in your hand and yet unable to harvest any stone...


Bottom line? 

It's a beautiful game, but it's lazily done. 

It's like the devs said "eh.. it's good enough" and then wandered off to do something else. It's 2022, autosave is a thing and should be available at the very least as an option. 
Resources not respawning or in anyway size or form renewable? If you're unlucky you can "literally" end up in a situation where you lack the resources to build a shelter to save your game...

If you want a slow paced game with a low difficulty and simple but clunky inteface, this will suit you. If you want a game with some depth (see what I did there), look elsewhere.

I'm pretty sure I should have many more hours in this game than is recorded.  i started back when it was barely a beta, and I liked it better then.  The devs took in inordinate amount of time to release and in the meantime took away aspects that made the game interesting, added comical boss fights, limited play area, motorized vehicles, and some kind of co-op.   

The game looks great though, but I can't really recommend it.

Before I give this game a review, I would like to start off by saying that this is actually my first game on Steam. I have always been a big console gamer only. Sadly I never had the pleasure with owning a gaming PC of my own. The game was suggested to me, and I actually found it on my Switch but I was greatly disappointed with how it handled on that particular device. I loved the concept of the game, so my husband downloaded it on his system to see if it was any different. Needless to say I loved it so much that he built me a gaming computer of my own. After spending 62.1 hours last two weeks/ 204.2 hours on record I felt it was time to leave my review for the game.

If you're looking for a laid back, peaceful, single player game then this is the game for you! I enjoyed everything about it. You can craft, swim, fish, hunt and there are new islands (as well as the body of water around them) to explore. The graphics are amazing and I haven't found any bugs in the game so far. This game lets you have the option to use a controller (Which I prefer since I am quite slow playing the game using the keyboard). If you prefer using the keyboard to play, they do offer this option as well. I have to say the most fun I have been having on the game is building my place and raft (which is larger then the raft you begin the game with) and it allows me to bring more supplies back to my island. I do enjoy when it turns night fall, on the game, as much as it is when it is daylight. Unexpected storms roll in and really make the game feel realistic. You can play the game on a more difficult level but I enjoy playing the lighter version of this game personally, it just depends how much of a survivalist you want to be. As you can tell, I really enjoyed this game and everything it has to offer. If you haven't played it yet, and you like what I have described about the game, then I encourage you to take the time and try it out. Adventure is out there!

I've owned this game for a very long time and played it when it was early in development. Turns out, not much has changed.

I wish there was a neutral option instead of recommending a simple "Yes" or "No".

The truth about this game is that it is a great way to kill time, however, it has some massive drawbacks. You'll find yourself not enjoying the heinous grinding needed to even craft simple things once you get the tutorial and basic items out of the way. Traveling to other islands will more than likely get you killed or lost never to find your home again.

I've come across glitches that leave me unable to interact with items (including the bed / save system) forcing me to force quit and lose loads of progress to fix the bug.

The storyline is simple. You're stuck in the middle of the ocean after a plane crash with small islands around being your only hope of salvation. Left to your own devices and resourcefulness to escape the ocean.

The crafting is simple yet tedious and annoying at the same time. You don't need much to craft your items, but once your island is diminished of resources you might want to strap in and get ready to attempt to deplete every other island of their resources too just to craft a simple farming plot.

In short, buy this game if you're looking for a way to kill time for a little bit and explore a series of islands for a bit. Build a hut and hunt some fish or sharks.

I have hopes in my heart for this game to see full release and not be stuck in "Early Access Purgatory" but as it's going, that might be what it will be forever. It would be a fantastic game if the bugs and glitches were polished out and more content was added to the game.

EDIT :
I would not recommend running this game on any lower-end system as even higher-end systems struggle to have fun with this game.

A friend suggested we get this game and try it out in co-op as we both enjoy the survival genre. After seeing the mostly positive reviews and checking that it has fairly consistent updates for a 7 year old early access game we gave it a go. 
My friend lasted 20 minutes. He can't see the watch where all the stats like drinking level and the like are displayed, making the game unplayable since you can't check when to eat, drink etc. Its a bug the developers are aware of for over a year now related to the Mac M1 chip clashing with Unity, apparently.

Not having that issue, I soldiered on until I encountered a boss that makes Dark Souls a kids game.

[u] A f*****g ladder. [/u]

 At first I thought I was doing something wrong, but after some testing I realized the concept of climbing down is something completely foreign to this game. 
Climb a palm tree to grab that precious coconut? No problem. 
Climbing down? Not possible. You just fall down and break a leg. 
Climb that shipwreck watchtower? Of course, get a good view of your surroundings and maybe even find some good stuff in a container. Alright, lets head back with our loot and build that thing you have been harvesting for. 
Nope.
Fall down, drop to 1/4 health, slowly try to make it to shore just to get eaten by a shark.

For a game that's been in Early Access since 2015, I understand that there will be bugs, but 7 years is more than enough time to fix getting down a ladder, but if it hasn't been fixed by now, it probably never will.

Kind of a disappointment. I've owned this game for almost a decade. I loved the idea when it first dropped, and it horrified me, it played on my phobias so terribly bad, but nearly 10 years and still the game is in the early stages of early access. I understand that it's a pretty big responsibility to develop a game, but we see projects from single, lone developers that put out a superior, far more polished project in quite literally 1/10th the time. They don't really have a need for excuses at this point because it's so beyond the scope of saying anything other than they made a quick buck off of an entirely unfinished product and abandoned it. Maybe one day we'll see them decide to upkeep what they promised upon purchasing the game in early access, but I doubt it. I can't request a refund after 10 years, and when I bought this game steam didn't give refunds, it's been that long. I loved the idea, but man, you guys really really failed to deliver.

I point everyone to this game as a shining example of how to *not* do an Early Access game. Game's been in development for 8 years, has progressively got worse over time. I still maintain that the ~2015 build of this game is way more fun than the modern version lol.

Game's got progressively worse and more bloated over time. Systems like crafting were once super simple and intuitive, but were eventually replaced with an inferior version. Graphics looked solid in 2015, they no longer do.

If you're buying, understand that you're buying entirely as-is and you're not entitled to any future updates or support. I really do wonder why these guys haven't given up on this title, they still push content-devoid bugfix patches bi-annually.

Stranded Deep is an older game, and if you've been with it for a while. You'll see just how much this game has changed over the time. It is graphically gorgeous with beautiful scenery and vibrant underwater wildlife. But the game isn't just for looks, it offers you a pretty standard survival game. But, it does offer some charm, it has recently launched a Co-op, so if you wanted, you can play with your friends! It has standard survival aspects, hunt, gather food and plants, get safe-to-drink water and treat wounds. Craft, build, and fight back dangerous creatures. However, one thing that I do find fun, is that there are many things you can find as you explore the various islands and open seas. You'll find easter eggs, like a volleyball for example, and you will find different buoys, these buoys are the spawn locations for different bosses. But I'll let you find them for yourself. Good luck, and stay alive!

The multiplayer does not work, the mechanics are poorly implemented, the crafting is obtuse, and the game obfuscates character/tech progression without clear paths forward. None of it is [i]difficult[/i] but none of it feels satisfying to play either. For a game that's been "released" for seven years: the state of play is bad. It's more like a fancy tech demo than a full game.

Your mileage may vary and, if you buy it, you might have fun with it! For my money though there are many other survival / crafting games out there that do what Stranded Deep intends but... Way better.

I don't usually review games; especially leave a negative review. But this game is just bad (at least starting off)

You start with a fairly decent cut-scene and the graphics are actually good. The game looks pretty when you jump in. But then you meet the mechanics...

Swimming feels incredibly clunky. There's no "dive" button or anything, so you just have to look a direction and swim there, so swimming straight-forward feels wrong (which isn't always a bad thing, just my opinion), and when you try to jump on to something from the water, it only actually lets you when it feels like it, so you're probably just going to get eaten by a shark.

Next is the inventory management, and my god... it's bad. Each time you do a specific skill set, whether it be fishing, crafting, running etc.. your character levels up. But it never told me what my level was or what it even affected. And since your crafting is levelling up, you have to wait an odd amount of time to progress when starting off. So you're just left crafting things you don't need in order to progress, wasting materials and your inventory is VERY small. Sometimes things will stack, sometimes they won't. Sometimes it will let you pick up an item from your inventory, but sometimes it won't because your inventory is full. Makes sense, right? Not to mention your form of chests is a wooden box that most items aren't even allowed to go into, so I just ended up throwing everything onto the ground. I swear most of my play-through was just me hearing an "error" noise, telling me I'm putting things in the wrong place. It makes the entire Survival-craft portion of it (the entire game...?) feel like a constant inconsistent chore.

Bugs are also a big problem. I didn't go 10 minutes without seeing a tree lose most of its textures.

Apparently this game has been in development for at least 7 years, the PC and Console versions of the game are different and it feels like this game has been practically abandoned.

If the game was 5 bucks, I wouldn't have bothered for a refund. But since it was almost 20, I felt robbed.
