This could be a really cool/fun game to play with friends or even solo, but here is why it is not, There are way to many bugs some are even game breaking, for an example you can lose the ability to swing/attack im not sure what causes this to happen but when it does the only way to fix it is to reload the game, but if you are in the middle of fighting a boss or just away from where you have your save point you can not always do that unless you do not mind losing your progress. The game has way to harsh of a grind to get any kind of decent setup going and im not talking about a simple fire pit/hut. In order to build the better stuff like plank structures or anything better you have to find the things required to make it and that is not always an easy thing to do. I personally feel like there is way to high of a shark re spawn, what i mean is the moment you get in any water that is deep enough for a shark to be in BAM! there is a shark that just spawns right near you with in seconds, and it is not always just 1 shark either another can spawn too, i had like 3 sharks spawn in the water when i was trying to search a ship wreck and i did not have much to defend myself with yet just a crappy spear. I honestly feel like there should be a way to turn off shark re spawns this way there will still be sharks around but once you kill one it is gone for good and wont come back. I feel this would help make the waters feel less shark infested to the point you do not even want to attempt to make a short swim anywhere. ( yes im aware you can turn off wild life spawn but as far as im aware this removes sharks completely from the game and that's not what i want) Another thing i can not wrap my head around is how long this game has been in early access for! and still this game is lacking as far as content goes, i mean if you build furniture in this game you can not even interact with it, i mean whats the point of chairs if you can not sit in them, also why have shelves if there is no true way to store stuff on them. the game does have really cool things in it that you can build but some of it either has no function or is broken and wont work the right way, like the hobo stove, i made one put meat in it then when it was cooked i could not take the meet out the option never appeared for me, i ended up having to break the stove to get the cooked meat. I also feel the story to this game is very lacking the only story content is survive and find a way home, i mean they could have added in cool stuff you could find like maybe notes from other people who may have been stranded on the same islands/area as you, some notes could even get you cords to hidden stashes that these people left before they died or escaped. Over all for a game that has been out as long as this one has and still feels like it is in its first stages is just sad to me and makes me feel like the devs who made this have lost interest in their product. I can not recommend this game.

Rating : 3.5 / 5 - Decent game
(early access review)

The Setting:
Your plane crashes and you end up on island chain somewhere in the tropics. Now you must find a way to survive. You will be traveling from island to island on your raft to get resources. You will also be diving in the ocean to get extra resources. I don't really want to say too much more than that and give away the plot.

My Take:
I enjoyed this quite a bit. I also played through co-op mode. I really want to give it a higher rating because it definitely has a lot going for it, but it is held back by bugs and also the crashes in co-op mode. I also felt like there should be a bit more to do. It is early access still and I do feel the price is justified for what you currently get.

Pro:
++ Atmosphere : Absolutely nailed that one. Very relaxing at times for a survival game, but then interchanged with more stressful moments.
+ UI design : Inventory and crafting work well for the most part. Accessing containers feels a bit clunky at times though.
+ Environment : Different animals, different weather conditions, exploring under water, exploring on water
+ Graphics get the job done with some exceptions

Cons:
-- co-op is a hot mess. Frequent crashes and animals just leaping up into the air. Save often is what I would recommend. We got through it and I still enjoyed it, but I think many people will not have the same patience as I have :P
- Finding what you need for the end game can be bit frustrating
- I just wish there was a little bit more to do. It starts to feel repetitive rather quickly.
- Building shelters felt like huge waste of time.
- Low res texture popins
- Buggy animal behaviour
- Stuttering in co-op

Thanks for reading and I hope you found it helpful.

Stranded Deep was released on January 23, 2015, in Early Access. It is now May 5, 2022, and this game is still in Early Access. The latest update from the developers was January 10, 2022.

There are probably a number of reasons Stranded Deep is still in Early Access, 7 years later, but at least it has recently been updated. Hopefully they will continue to update this game in the near future, because it definitely needs fixes.

If you enjoy survival games or have never played a survival game, I highly recommend this game. This is my favorite survival game out of several. I enjoyed The Forest, (looking forward to Sons of the Forest), I enjoy playing Green Hell, and so far I enjoy Night of the Dead, which is also an Early Access game. Stranded Deep is at the top for me because I love the ocean, swimming, aquatic life, and long walks on the beach........ :D
*crickets* 
No? Ok. I'll just get my coat, but before I do that, let me explain this game a bit more. Think of the movie Cast Away, starring Tom Hanks and Helen Hunt. No iceskate and several islands to explore.

While playing Stranded Deep, it is not as difficult as Green Hell, in my opinion. Stranded Deep does not require as much from the player, as Green Hell does. Originally Stranded Deep required the player to sleep, in the first days upon its release, if I'm not mistaken. The developers removed the Sleep requirement and left the following Vitals: Health, Hunger, Thirst and Sunlight (SPF). The player will build their Hunting, Cooking, Harvesting, Physical, and Craftsmanship skills, throughout the game.

The player will be able to hunt on the different islands, as well as go swimming, and hunt aquatic life. There are flora and fauna on the islands and in the ocean, with Sharks being the main threat while swimming or traveling. Oh yes, you will be fighting off sharks! If you have a fear of the ocean, wide open bodies of water, or sharks, this game will test your fears. It is a good way to overcome them though. You just have to jump in and face the threats sometimes. As long as you are smart about how you do that, you can survive. After a while, it will be nothing for you to jump into the deep blue that is the ocean, and all you'll need to do is figure out how to not drown with the giant set of weights hanging between your legs.

One of the many fun parts about this game is the player can build their home about as much as they like, as long as they keep up with their health and resources. I have been pretty creative with the homes I have built on the islands. The player can also fish with a fishing rod or go spear fishing, in every sense of the activity. They can build tools, weapons, and other items to help hunt, fight off aggressive animals, and even provide shelters. The player can even create gardens on islands, and grow their own food or plants like Aloe, which can help with protection from the sun. The player can build rafts too, and dare I say, maybe even a flying machine. ;)

Another cool feature is the day and night cycle, and the storms that players can encounter while on islands, or even out on the ocean or while swimming. I just wish the day/night cycle could be manually adjusted, or at least make the daytime a bit longer. It always seemed like the nighttime in the game was longer.

The best part about this game is that players can now game online together (2 player cooperative). Originally the game was singleplayer or shared co-op, where two players could play split screen co-op. Last fall, the developers added online cooperative capability. My friend and I played through the game on co-op, and were able to complete the game. There is an ending in singleplayer and cooperative. Both modes' endings are the same, however, there are downsides to this. First, upon completion of the game in co-op mode, only the host will receive the achievement(s)/trophies for completing the game, as well as for not using the compasses throughout the entire game. I was the host and my friend was the co-op partner. He could not initiate the game ending, but I could. After I initiated the ending sequence, I was the only one out of both of us who received the achievements for completion of the game, and for not using compasses. However, I accidentally held one in my hand during movement of supplies, and we both used the Gyrocopter which also has a compass on it. I am uncertain if the 'Magnets, how do they work?' achievement/trophy is working properly or not. So, be aware that if you are the co-op partner who joined a game with a host, you may not get either of those two achievements/trophies. Hopefully the developers at Beam Team Games, as well as the Beam Team Publisher, will fix the listed issues soon enough.

The only real negative experience my friend and I encountered while playing co-op, was he would be disconnected quite often. I believe that the co-op partner is subject to client disconnection issues, regardless of where they are located, their PC or console, and internet connection. If you decide to watch any of my livestreams of our co-op adventures on Stranded Deep, you will see that he was disconnected more often than not. This was very irritating not only for him, but for me too, as this wasted a lot of time. Sometimes we would have to exit the game entirely and attempt joining again. DO NOT FORGET TO SAVE YOUR GAMES IF YOU ARE THE HOST. It is safe for both people to save their games, but the host especially needs to save the games. The disconnection issues were random. There did not appear to be any particular reason that would explain why he was disconnected. This issue is apparently quite common, as I have seen other people encounter it, while watching their gaming videos as well. So just be aware of the above issues. Singleplayer did not appear to have any online connection issues like that. Only while playing cooperative.

Even with the irritating co-op partner connection issues, I still recommend this survival game before others. I am still playing it to this day, but we will probably wait until the developers create a fix for the connection issues, before we play co-op on Stranded Deep again.

Also, if you like the music in the game, you can either purchase it through Steam, or get the soundtrack from Amazon Music. The music is fitting for the setting and I really enjoyed it. It has that sense of danger when sharks are around, but also adds a sense of happiness when fishing, swimming or building. It even has a sense of loneliness when it's dark outside, when you're alone, etc. but in a good way, as the music adds to the overall emotion of the game.

Overall, Stranded Deep is amazing and the price of $15.00 U.S. is worth it for what you receive, along with its Early Access issues. It's still an Early Access game, so give the developers credit and the benefit of the doubt. I understand making video games is no easy task, but if they're still updating it like they did back in January, we just need to be patient with them. I will not spoil anything but the ending was interesting. I am curious to know what made the developers go the direction they went with this game, and whether or not a Stranded Deep 2 will be in the works. Obviously they still have a lot of work to do to resolve bugs and glitches with this game, but I am not opposed to a sequel. :)
Buy this game and play it in singleplayer for a while, and then determine whether you enjoy it or not. I believe anyone would enjoy this game, if they give it a chance. I am glad I saw my friend had it on his wishlist, and that it was co-op. That is what made me purchase the game, even though at the time it was only shared/split screen co-op. This game is amazing and has a lot of potential to still be even better. Play it and record the issues you encounter, then report them to the developers. We can all work together to help make Stranded Deep even more awesome and adventurous. Lastly, don't forget your swimsuit. You're gonna need a bigger boat.

This is a solid early access survival game, but that's been the case for years now. I go back to it maybe once every 10-12 months because it's pretty and easy to spend some time in, but I haven't found any real goal to work towards. I'd like to explore the world more, but I spend most of my time worrying about thirst and hunger. Also, traveling between islands is very time consuming. My 2019 session ended today because the life raft flipped over and the game wouldn't let me stop sitting in it, so I drowned. I'd say it's definitely worth it for fans of the genre, but don't expect something close to a finished product.

2022 Update: I'm pretty good at this game nowadays. I've made significant progress several times in the past few years before abandoning my save and waiting for the next update. Not today, though. Just after the notification that I'd reached my tenth day of survival, I decided to explore the shipwrecks around my newest island. Once I collected all the first ship had to offer, I attempted to exit through the ship's hatch with about 60% of my oxygen remaining. Unfortunately, the doorway that had granted me access to this ships scraps had somehow been sealed with an invisible forcefield. No matter what angle I tried to swim through the wide open door, there would be no egress. My poor stranded survivor ran out of air and ragdolled into the ceiling of the sunken ship, suddenly incredibly buoyant in death. I was then told I had actually only survived for four days, despite being very sure I had just seen the notification for day 10. I'm bad at saving often, so I'm guessing it was using the in game day of my most recent save, even though that seems stupid. Anyway, I kinda wanna change my recommendation due to the long development and insane jank, but I've still had way too many cool moments in this game to say you shouldn't play it.

This game suffers the tragedy of devs who believe in "If you look good, you will be good," sacrificing quality game play for aesthetics.  The game looks good on the surface but the game play is terrible.  Combat is slow, clunky, target accuracy is a total joke, where everything you do to compensate seems to find mountains more problems.  Crafting is extremely rigid with next to no actual resource nodes.  What you can craft is very inflexible and cannot be remodeled.  Once it is made, it is made.  Expect to have to destroy things, not dismantle and recover materials.  Building houses and vehicles is very rigid, sacrificing customization for maintaining aesthetics.  This game is not made for playing, it is only made for taking screenshots and making videos.  If you get this game for the sake of enjoying "A GAME" you will be sorely disappointed. The devs are not making a game, they are making a Theater backdrop.

Game has been in the pre-release stages for years. I remember when Subnautica was released in early access near the same time this game started being played on YouTube. Back then it looked fun, building a base on an island, getting better gear through exploration of shipwrecks and survival was manageable, and it could be given the benefit of the doubt by it being quite new (note I did not play in the early stages but I watched quite a bit of gameplay of the early stages years ago). But it's around 7 years old, still in early access, and playing it's just monotonous, and i'll list some problems I had with the game here. You don't need a base, storage space is laughably small for containers, so many little status effects that just serve to slowly kill you overtime with zero direction on how to actually cure them, basically no enemies on the starting island but most of the surrounding islands have giant crabs which are basically invincible at that point in the game and boars that take away most of your health before you can kill them, no direction on where to actually go to progress, no sense of a tense survival situation whatsoever, if you do choose to build a base out of anything than just wood sticks the resources are incredibly hard to find large enough amounts of, and upgraded building materials are pointless for protection as nothing really attacks your base, especially on the starting island where your base is likely going to be, travelling is incredibly boring, as there are no real threats that can kill you (even sharks just bump the side of your raft without doing anything if you're operating it), good food sources are hard to come by (only really rations are good throughout the game, but can only be found in small supply at the start and in shipwrecks), game just takes too long to and doesn't feel worth it, and finally exploring wrecks would be fun if they weren't the same wreck copy pasted. Eventually had to just turn on the console and cheat to have any semblance of fun in this supposed 'survival' game, and there is no pushing force that compels you to even bother doing really anything.

You crash land in what is basically the Bermuda Triangle, many others have crashed and died here, Will you join them in silent observance, or will you take off and start someone else's journey anew in this watery hell?

This game is not for those who find Ark to be a challenge, who spend time on 7DTD holed up in a building on Horde Night, if this describes your Survival-crafting play style, do not play this game. It has bugs, but I've had no real game breaking bugs. You will spend a lot of time scavenging for supplies and food, you will be challenged to survive in a semi-realistic manner, no Solar Water machines, no easy start food gathering without risk, and your tools are not indestructible, or last any real length of time. The sun actually damages you and you have to seek shade/shelter from the scorching heat, something most SC games neglect, and there is no quick and easy way to island hop without using some mode of transport.

This game will challenge you, make you think outside the crate, and it will push you to give up nearly every day. Good luck.

This game has one of the most infuriating storage and inventory systems. Essentially you only have 10~15 inventory slots but you can craft crates which have 5 but take up only 1 of your inventory. To use the crates you have to equip them, drop them and open them. Trouble is they all look the same. Also, the game is jank as fuck and is prone to deleting or displacing your dropped items. This all lead to losing my entire crate full of all my vehicle parts to the game just deciding to delete that crate. If that sounds fun to you by all means get the game but that kind of fuckery isnt for me.

Also the games been in early access since Jan 2015 and is still a buggy mess.

I love the sunsets/sunrises on this game. Visually it's gorgeous. The thunderstorms are wow. I have a fear of fish and deep water that I can't see the bottom of, and this game certainly makes my hair stand on end because it features those two things the most. 

The ONLY thing I dislike, the trees do not regrow. No matter how long you wait, they will not come back. I find this to be a huge dislike to me, because I'd like to be able to visit an island across the map, use what I need, leave and come back say a few hours later real time and it be somewhat regrown. But this just isn't so. Once a tree is cut, you'll never get that back. You can't even replant them. It's a shame. 

That aside, I think the game is worth getting, and I personally am having fun just fishing from my little makeshift house with bed, and waiting out thunderstorms while my garden grows. It's peaceful, usually. I like that.

This is a revised recommendation. Originally, I gave the game a thumb down due to multiple issues; however, I decided to change my recommendation with qualifications. 

1. Graphics: 

The game is beautiful; however, if you purchase the game, be prepared for graphics related glitches that have been a feature of the game since it was first released. 

2. Game Play: 

If you enjoy base-building survival games, this one is nice. It becomes repetitive after a while, and once you have seen the two types of islands, you have seen them all. That said, I personally enjoy the farming aspect of this type of game so the repetitive nature of it isn't an issue for me. If you're into that, this game will be enjoyable. If you want a new experience around every corner, you won't find that in this game. 

3. Creativity: 

If you're into artistic/creative play, this may be one of the best games out there for that. The Cartographer feature allows you to create your own islands from "the ground up," and you don't have to be a mod creator to use it. That feature alone is worth several hundred hours of game play if you're into that. 

With a word of caution, I do recommend the game (7/10).
The main fun comes in when you start to build your own islands and figure out unique ways to make an awesome paradise, ... or death trap.

UPDATED REVIEW: 

Would I recommend Stranded Deep? It is the most awesome, the most outstanding and my number 1 ultimate survival game I have ever played. The immersion in regards to the concept from the movie "Cast Away" (if you ever saw that one) for solely survival purposes is unbeatable! The scenery and the outstanding view in the landscape is capturing something which I personally never thought was possible to experience in a game. My brain is ALMOST tricked in to believing some of these sunsets/sunrise's are real. It should tell you a whole lot. I have played many different survival games but nothing beats the feeling I get from Stranded Deep. 

Positive: 
- Challenging if you want it to be. 
- Realism.
- Ultimate Survival & Great Crafting System, user friendly compared to other survival games out there. I do think if you are new to survival game, Stranded Deep is probably the one I would recommend. 
- The Graphics & the scenery, how much the environment feels like second nature is one of a million. From how some may even get sick from travelling at seas in your raft on stormy weather. It is the only game I feel deserves a 10 of 10.
- The tempo and the game flow is very well done. 
- The satisfying feeling this game gives you after you have been grinding for hours and finally got a new paradise to dock-in to with your raft.. 
- Multiplayer
- Custom Island (Steam Workshop)

Negative:
- Lack of complexity in the metabolic/metabolism system. The nature should have way greater impact on the player, and lack of different types of vitamins and such should enforce bigger impact in form of a wider range of penalty. Dehydration is no joke!   
- There should be more risks & danger when you decide to take your raft overseas. ESPECIALLY EARLY ON  there should be risks in taking your primal & extremely vulnerable raft overseas. It should be so that there are huge risks with this at least you have those bigger fleets. That would make an significant impact on the survival elements of the game and actually a new level of realism would be born in to this game. 


I absolutely love everything about Stranded Deep. It's an ultimate survival game with a diverse range of ways to enjoy it. Either you're here for building and hard grind, or just simply for the arcade story; I do think either way this game has become to be a very special adventure. I would imagine that it could be great family entertainment, and there is lots of stuff to learn for kids. To me this game is as close to perfection as possible. Overall: 9 of 10. I would love to see the Developers at BEAMTEAM working with more dangers overseas though. That would likely make this game perfect.

Stranded Deep is a nice Early Access survival game.  The island environment is pleasant and fun.  

There's nothing surprising, other than a relatively low amount of resources on the starter island.  They don't want you to get too comfortable on the starter;  you have to move away to survive.  No enemies on the starter island for a nice, easy start.

The game came out in 2015, and has had consistent updates and fixes.  That said, my bug report went unanswered, and there are many unanswered posts on the Steam Forums.  There are a few recurring topics that players are repeatedly bringing up with no response or clear roadmap.  I have not tried multiplayer, but it seems there are issues.   

So, this is another EA project that plays more like crowdfunding; Your financial support is appreciated,  but there is no real interaction between players and the developers.  No worries, but every single EA game promises rich interaction on the Forums, but then retreats to social media sites like Discord, where the Dev can entertain some light conversation while never having to get too deep :)  or address specific questions and ideas.

Overall. the game plays well.  Buy it if you like the look and feel of the game, and you like to support projects without having to get involved.

I do this to myself, every single time they update this game. I think "oo, updates! Maybe they fixed things". 

Nope. 

I closed it after 10 minutes. Here is why:

1. The bushes are solid. Solid. Try cut down a palm tree that is stuck in one these "forever" bushes, watch it glitch through the universe. 

2. The graphics are outdated. The environment FX are great (lighting, water) but the actual landscape meshes are crap. The tree trunks are not round, the bushes are just a mish-mash of double-sided planes with some crappy texture.... it looks like the devs borrowed assets from My Summer Car (great game that)! Oh, and I play with my settings maxed out - same shit, different frame rate.

3. The UI? Omfg the pain! If you went outside your house, grabbed a stick and drew some boxes in the sand it would still be a better crafting UI than Stranded Deep's!  

I love the idea, and I have owned Stranded Deep since day 1, but there is only so much broken stuff I can take before I Alt+F4 my way out. 

This game needs a major UI/UX overhaul if it hopes to survive.

[h1]Fantastic atmospheric co-op gameplay, you can sink hours into the game without noticing.[/h1]

It has about 10 hours worth of solid content and then probably another 10 until you've exhausted every possibility worth pursuing. 

Eventually you'll get sick of the game for its flaws, mainly the speed of transportation and how long it takes to make something that used to be given to you in the first 30 minutes: fuel. Combat is also atrociously difficult and unfair with literally every enemy encounter in the game easily resulting in your death if unprepared or just damn unlucky. 

Crafting starts off really fun and will keep you engaged for many hours, but after a while it becomes a chore.

The graphics are GOTY material, easily top 5 best water graphics on the market, but the art direction kind of sucks for some of the in-game time such as dusk and dawn, where the water turns red. 

It's a really cool atmosphere all throughout and has huge Cast Away vibes.

[b]If playing alone I'd rate it a 7/10 experience that will last for 2-3 hours[/b], so maybe not worth the asking price unless you got money to splurge.

[b]If playing co-op I'd rate it a 10/10 experience that will last upwards of 15 hours[/b]. 

I've come to the point in the game now where I don't see myself picking it up again for another 2 years, as really not much has changed since I first started playing it 6+ years ago and most of the craft-able things are useless.

You can squeeze another 2-3 hours of gameplay out of it with cheats and hacks.

Another big bonus is the couch split screen, though I don't see it working well on anything smaller than a 32" screen as it still feels tight at 48". 

Wishlist for future:

[list]
    [*]Much much better crafting explanations
    [*]Drinking rain water, makes zero sense that you don't right now
    [*]Better combat, either just having stronger weapons or nerfing enemies especially pigs
    [*]Ability to sleep through day, this is literally a 3 second fix for the dev
    [*]Readily available fuel found in ships
    [*]More variations to islands, there are currently only 2. That's kind of pathetic for a 7 year old game. The only thing currently separating those 2 into a further 5-ish is the placement of ships around the islands. 
    [*]Faster transportation, either through multiplying sails, larger sails, more powered engines or just having 2 people paddle at once. In the beginning its fun how slow it takes to sail to another island but after 5-10 trips you just want to stop playing because it can take anywhere from 3 to 10 minutes to reach more land which more than half the time you've already been on.
    [*]Let bandages work on yourself, this is another 3 second fix for the dev
    [*]More underwater parts needed, but not too deep because this game is terrifying in those sections.
[/list]

I still think its a 10/10 despite those flaws mainly because of its co-op atmosphere that so far no other game has come even close to matching or beating. So there's definitely something special about this game and it will be a Steam classic.

Avoid!

One of the absolutely worst experiences I had recently with multiplayer games. There is this coop mode. We started playing with my wife a while back - all fun and games until we left the starting island.
Within 30 minutes span I got kicked out of her game 4 times, and had to rejoin with multiple times the game hanging either on my side or my wife's side while attempting to rejoin the game.
While we spent another hour and a half without issues, when we got to the home island, we dropped all the boxes with loot and gathered materials on the ground and guess what - the game froze. Since we were away from home island we weren't able to save the game. So literally, dropped the crates took 2 steps towards the shelter in order to save - BAM - the game crashes again and we decided that we are not going to waste any more time playing this game. First, the PC version is behind with the updates in comparison to console because BeamTeam is greedy, now we get a "finished" release of the game that can't even work properly with it's fundamental functionality.

I will skip to the part that the synchronisation of the game state is about 7 feet underground and pretty much doesn't exist - we are talking here about stuff like:
My Wife                                         Me
Fire on                                            Fire Off
Food cooked                                  Food Raw
Paddle in raft                                 Paddle missing in raft
Paddling with no item in hand      Paddling with actual paddle in hand
Spawning inside the raft               Spawning in the middle of the ocean being chomped on by a hammer shark
Pig running on the ground            Pig flying to the moon like an astronaut to hit me in the head seconds later
Resource state - exploited            Resource state - unexploited (like yukka trees or coconuts on the palm trees)
Deployed sea anchor                    No sea anchor deployed and the boat floats off to Jamaica because why the hell not

Hell, try to pick up the crate at the same time as the other player and most likely you will get two of them.

literally a buggy mess this game is. Multiplayer experience described above, however:
Single player when you deploy an anchor the game doesn't often register it and send your boat flying to oblivion (happened more than once)
Dissappearing stuff from chests happens occasionally on pickup
Game crashes for no reason on multiple pc's I tested it on, all with updated graphics drivers etc (3 different machines) - the screen freezes and what is visible looks similar to "deep fried" meme format.

Absolutely disgusting. If you are looking for a smooth multiplayer experience, try another game, like The Forest even. Less sea, more land, but doesn't crash as often and has a lot less issues than this piece of garbage. Good thing I bought it on a discount a while ago, because I'd never pay the full price on this now.

I'm still getting familiar with the game with almost 6 hours behind me.  So far, it's been relatively enjoyable and for the survival person, this is one to have in your library.

I've not found anything specifically unique about the game that I like or something that makes it stand out above other survival games I've played yet.  Again, I haven't had much time to get anywhere to see how high up I can build a house, or if I can place  a foundation at the top of a rock cliff.  Crazy things I like to do in a game.

One thing I've noticed that I'm not too excited about and that are the multiple small islands.  This sort of thing splits up valuable resources and forces you to either do a lot of sailing back and forth, or building/rebuilding the same items to harvest food and water on every island you go to.

If there was a main thriving island where you can have your main base at with the option of "satellite bases" on other islands you explore, I would be fine with that.  The beginner island is limited and so far by what I've read only some items will re-spawn, and not all items have seedlings you could plant and re-grow.

This theory (that may be fact) already stunts my desire to do much more on the beginner island.  However, if you decide to advance to another island too soon in the game, you will not last long for animals/creatures on the other islands pack a larger punch and if you don't have the best weapon in hand you won't last but a few minutes before you "kick the bucket".

This will be a challenge and I'm still debating on continuing to invest more time into this game while others capture my attention.

I absolutely love this game! One of the best survival games I have ever played! I'm pretty sure it's my #1 atm! It definitely still needs work. Some of the bugs can be SUPER annoying, but some are harmless, sometimes helpful, or just outrageously funny! For example: One moment you could be dropping items and an item just freezes in the air, and its not even the item you were supposed to be dropping. I've lost a few tools this way. Then there is one where, if you get a specific island that has a ship wreck in the perfect spot, you can lure sharks in between the island and the boat and they will bug out and just spin in circles providing you with simple and easy food that can restore a ton of your food bar. Then you have the funny bugs, like a random boar floating above the ocean or running around on a ship wreck under water, also had a funny one where the shark started to swim inside the island. It actually scared the shiz out of me sitting there and a shark just attacks me from under the sand. I'm now terrified of sand sharks xD But all together this is a fantastic survival game and i would completely recommend it! Just a little rough around the edges, but the principal and idea behind the game is just awesome! i love the water and fish physics this game has, other than a few bugs, the physics are almost spot on to real life! Great game to play with a buddy! so glad they added multiplayer co-op! Even though it's only up to 2 players, it's definitely a fun late night game with a buddy! Worth the purchase for sure! Can't wait to see what's in store for this games Official Release! 1.0 Here we come!

There is nothing to do in this game unless you like building and crafting stuff for no actual reason. People here for the survival will be sorely disappointed. The survival game is won the moment the player finds the 2 Cloth that are guaranteed to spawn on their very first island and builds a Water Still and a Smoker. This gives more or less infinite water and food, leaving the player to fart about travelling the islands for no particular reason (bosses aside ofc). There is no hostile environment as such, no cannibals, no zombies, no dinosaurs, not even the weather is particularly dangerous.The sharks are easily avoided or killed and the other hostile wildlife are simply a pain, but ultimately harmless.  There is no reason to tech up and build a better raft or elaborate base, and hence no reason to explore or gather resources. It's pushing it to call this a survival game.

That said, the game looks beautiful and island hopping in an increasingly pimped out raft can be fun for several hours, but there is no real survival challenge here, so buyer beware. I am going to thumbs up because it's worth the asking price, but it is borderline.

It's a very fun survival simulator that by limiting the amount of resources any one island has forces you to explore and move on to the next island to find your elusive twine.  The islands are really pretty and the random map builder makes it feel fresh. I LOVE the randomness of the weather and the terror of going into the water.  Now I'm not at all that far along- but I I'm really enjoying the ride.

The cons that I struggle with are because I play on a macbook (M1 Pro chip) and no matter your settings, you cannot see your watch to know what sort of stats you have.  The workaround for me is that if you hold a spear, you can refresh your watch and kinda see it if you look just the right way, but only the 'water, food, SPF, and health' bars.  I can't read if you are poisoned or not.  Also, I have a mac mouse and as far as I can tell, there is no way to use your weapons at range because the apple mouse will only click right or left, you can't alternate or change it quickly.  If they could ad an option to map the 'throw' button on to a keyboard that would fix it.
Not recommending this until they get with the program and fix multiplayer stuck at zero percent when trying to join with friends.  Been broken for several months now.

This game is super fun and pretty straight forward when it comes to your objective. The scenery is beautiful and the game play is smooth. The tutorial helps get you started and from there, it's easy to get going on the story line. The only issue I have had with the game play is jumping. Jumping onto rafts, boats, etc when in the water is extremely frustrating and can take a while if you do not position yourself right. Otherwise, if you enjoy Rust or similar games, I would recommend this one as well. Using the Cartographer map helps tell you your location and is a good way to keep track of where you have been.

It's pretty chill game. No pvp required, just you against nature at your own pace. If you like survival games and need a break from going toe-to-toe versus Rust players, for example, then definitely give this a shot.

When attempting to play this game co-op there are constant issues that plague the game to the point it is near unplayable. 

Spending over an hour receiving constant 'world synch' freezes with none of the online solutions working was a fantastic way to ruin the hype we had about this game. Even after searching for solutions (which this error has been an issue for people for a while), trying vpns, trying to reinstall and clearing caches as recommended we still remained stranded and unable to play. 

Finally after about two hours of even trying to get the game to play I was able to host the game for my friend and we got to play for an hour before we were randomly disconnected. Today we tried to host a game and had several 'world synch' freezes before random disconnect after an hour. 

if you are here to play with your friends, get ready for some headaches. Perhaps this error doesn't happen for everyone but be aware of it before putting your money down.

EDIT 25-02-2022

So I jumped back in this game after like 1.5 year. On the surface not much really changed. I tried to get into it more but after the initial start the game just feels like a grind. To build a good sizeable boat and base you need to hop from island to island so much and so many times. Each island has too little resources and your inventory is also pretty lacking. I get it that in the sense of being a survival game and all that you cannot have too big of an inventory, but at least make the island more resourcefull. 

Besides, all the island look the same. Why not make differences between small, medium and large islands? Now they are all small with nothing to do on it. 

Combat with animals is still piss poor. Most of the times you dont even hear the pig or crab charging at you. They hit when they have their backs to you and the whole combat just exists of hitting the mouse button till they are dead. Then you need to wait some time to get the health back (if you are well fed and hydrated, otherwise you wont heal at all)

So now with seven hours into my new game I am just facing a grind in increasing my skills, building up my base and boat till I have the tools and resources to fight the three bosses.

It is a shame though because I do really dig the Robinson Crusoe vibe this game gives. The music is good and atmosphere is great as well. Just the gameplay loop and the combat are bothering me.

====================================
The game is oke at best. Only played five hours but it already feels I have seen most of the things though. Will continue playing it and if I feel that my opinion changes, I will adjust the review.

Pros
- Game looks pretty
- The exploration is fun in the beginning
- Have not encountered any serious bugs, crashes or other issues

Neutral / pet peeves
- Animations and such feel a bit cheap from time to time. But then again, this is an indie game made by a small studio for a low price
- The controls of managing the inventory feel awkward
- Little inventory space makes managing the stuff you carry annoying. Mind you I was only carrying the bare essentials

Cons
- The combat against land animals is poor. They seem to hit from a bit too far and you get the feeling you do not even touch them. Also after throwing three spears into a boar it still was running like crazy
- The islands start to feel repetitive and dull after a while
- After a while you wonder what you should do. You just hop from island to island. All looking the same with also the same loot. There is some sort of endgame but so far I am just seeing copy paste islands

6/10
A bit clunky and has its flaws, but for 15€ it's worth it and is quite enjoyable

This game both annoys me and makes me laugh. To be honest, I would recommend buying it if u want to have some fun with your friend, because the game isn't very expensive. But i\ve played stranded deep for 62 hours now, and I am not very pleased about this game. 

First of all, there are A LOT of bugs in this game. The animation of your game characters is terrible. Holding a flashlight makes it look like your shoulder was involved in a car accident. And to climb up to boats, you have to hold down the SPACE-key, instead of just simply pressing it. Altough it\s not a bug, I think The game should give a hint or something, so I didn`t have to spam SPACE one hundred times to get up.

Also, it`s not possible to play this game for ever. Palms, rocks and sticks do not respawn, so after you`ve spent up all your wood, you`ll have to move to another island. Many people may think that you can survive without such materials. Believe me, it`s impossible. If you want fresh water, you`ll have to use the Water still, which is powered by sticks. Great. Now you'll die of thirst if you don't move. 

The reason I stopped playing this game, was because of the ending of the game. Not the ending sequel, but how to finish the game. To escape the pasific, you'll need to kill three bosses hidden in the middle of the ocean. Me and my friend were scouting for them, but returned home with no luck. The bosses used to be on small islands with huge iron-towers. Now their'e just on some random sunken boats, which are very hard to find because of the size. It could have been a bit easier, with for example a compass that pointed in the direction of the bosses, but no. Didn't finish the game. 

Don't buy the game if you're expecting some quality time on your desktop. Go touch some grass instead.

[i]Original Review at the Bottom[/i]

I recently decided to pick up this game again, after leaving it on the shelf for a few years, and while there's been a little improvement here and there I'm sorry to say that there are quite a bit of flaws still with the game.

First, I'm happy to say that Multiplayer has finally been added to the game.  That said, they've basically done it in a co-op format so it's limited to 2 players only.  I really don't get this, since there are other games that use the same story intro mechanic (like The Forest) and allow many more players.  One theory I have is that adding more than one additional player would make the game virtually impossible, due to...

Secondly, they still haven't resolved the most common player complaint. That being, major resources don't respawn.  I certainly understand that when you pick up a rock another rock shouldn't just pop into existence at that spot.  That said, coconuts don't regrow on trees?  You can't plant and regrow trees?  I mean, come on...  These are crops, and in the real world they're certainly renewable crops.  With each player required to craft the same objects to unlock more recipes, having these resources limited is quite a large problem, especially early game.

Third, the health system is still completely broken.  You can stand in complete shade and still be overheating and getting UV stroke.  You have to move around until you find one tiny little spot, sometimes not even in the shade, where the UV meter shows you're in the "shade".  You can step on an urchin and get poisoned, but it's a roll of the dice if you can even drink the antidote you craft from the rare flower you had to find, because sometimes it goes buggy and can't actually be drunk.  You're given a limited quantity of coconuts, as mentioned before they don't respawn.  That said, if you drink more than one within a certain amount of time you get sick from it.  Oh, and you'd probably still get more "hydration" by drinking sea water or beach sand.  Coconuts, in this game, are practically useless as a drink.

The inventory system is still fairly odd.  You get a limited number of slots, but what you can put in those slots sometimes doesn't make sense.  Some things stack, other things don't.  Thankfully some objects can be placed in "piles" now, however instead of the game just doing it you have to go through the crafting system to tell it you want to create a pile.  It's far from intuitive, and if you didn't already know you could do this you're not likely to realise you can.  In addition, piles are only for major resources and somewhat useless because, as said before, major resources are extremely limited and don't regenerate.  In this game, if you actually need to "pile" a major resource, you aren't working on survival.  It almost would have been better to give us a larger storage chest option.

All in all, this game is still missing pretty much everything that I'd require to give it my recommendation.  It needs regenerative resources, even if those resources take a long time to regenerate (10-20 days) and can be toggled on/off by the host.  It needs multiplayer that's more than just a 2 player co-op existence.  The survival and inventory systems also still need some fixes, because right now they feel broken.  I'm not saying make the game stupid easy, because survival shouldn't be that way, but at least make things follow some form of common sense.

[hr][/hr]
[b]Original Review[/b]
[hr][/hr]

I purchased this game early, back before there was even a half-decent crafting system.  Normally I write up well thought out reviews, but I simply can't here.  This game is so horrible.  

[list]
    [*]Inventory space makes absolutely no sense
    [*]There are practically no hit-boxes on anything you place down
    [*]No regrowth on major resources
    [*]You can stand in fire and not get burned yet sunburn in less than an hour
    [*]Apparently the juice of a coconut has the same amount of hydration as beach sand.
    [*]Can't catch a fish with a knife, even if you're swinging right through it.
    [*]Islands are so small and spread apart that building a home is absolutely pointless.
    [*]"skinned" a manta and it went flying off into the wild blue yonder.
    [*]No multiplayer.
    [*]Ripped off the "ending" from Subnautica, and it makes no sense here.
[/list]

This could be an excellent game, but there's just so much wrong with it that I simply can't recommend it.  It's a complete patchwork of ideas originating from other games.  That said, the ideas have been mashed together and executed so badly that it's not worth playing.

[code]
Note:

Yes, I know the gyroscope was put in Stranded Deep before Subnautica had the rocket ending.  That said, the rocket in Subnautica was available, through admin commands, a LONG time before the same ending appeared in Stranded Deep.
[/code]

“We don't want to work on Stranded Deep forever. If all goes well, we're hoping to have it completed by the end of 2015.

2015.

Got the game when it was still in pretty pretty early access.

Seeing the development overtime honestly was like stepping on lego, falling onto a nice soft pillow and then realising the pillow had long nails under it.

For a large period of time the game was kindof just stuck in a place of the devs adding stuff then removing it the next update and replacing it with something new.

Is that too big of an issue? Not really if the updates didn't bring 100 new bugs into the game.
I could prolly write a guide of every bug, but it would be so long I might aswell just write a damn book about it.

Besides planning is quite important and for a period of time it fellt like there wasn't much planning on the updates. More just like "Add this and see if it fits then change it later maybe"

They even removed ocean life. For a game where 90% of the map is ocean you would think they would add allot of ocean life, but no. They had quite allot of fish, but over time they just kept slowly removing them making the ocean quite less interesting.

Wouldn't be surprised if theres just as much birds and land creatures as there is aquatic creatures. I mean for land you got snakes, a very interesting looking hog, a boar, bats, seagulls and two types of crabs. Why am i counting the crabs as land and not aquatic? Because they are never underwater.

In the ocean? Sardine, Lionfish, Cod, Archer, Discus, Giant Grouper, Marlin, Tiger Shark, Hammerhead, Great white, Whale sharks and Goblin sharks.
Offcourse there are other sea creatures, but they are simply there for looks. You can't damage them or do anything to them.

There is a sea snake. It can kill you, but you can't kill it. Stingrays exists which you used to be able to kill and then for some reason they just made them invincible. Pilchards and around 4-5 other fish also used to exist, but got yeeted. Blacktip sharks and clownfish again just kinda exist, but not really.

The bosses, oh dear god. Ok two of them are alright, but my god do not get me started on the bootleg megalodon. When I first saw this boss man my expectations where high and what attacks me? Literally a great white shark. Not scaled up in size even slightly. It is just a generic great white shark with the name Megalodon.

Online Multiplayer for a long time was not added. I personally did not care too much about multiplayer, but still I find it funny that after so long with the community begging for online multiplayer. They added multiplayer in the name of "Couch-Coop" boii was that not a good idea.

Game does have online multiplayer now. It is very unstable, but it exists and I guess good job to the game for that.

Oh the game also has an ending-ish and holy moly I did not know it was possible to make such a horrible ending to a game. It made literally no sense and was just such a poor choice of an ending. They could have gone so creative with the ending and made it look so nice. Instead we get this bottom of the dumpster ending. Might aswell not have an ending.

I had high hopes for the game and man was I dissapointed.
I feel the game could have gone a different direction, had the devs not made such poor choices throughout its development.
good game.
VERY GOOD GAME

I really want to like this game, but I can't.

The game gets off to a rough start: the unskippable starting cut-scene. Fine for the first time, but when you're playing a SURVIVAL game, odds are you're going to die at least once or twice. Sometimes the starting island screws you over (more on that in a bit) and you need to reset back up, or maybe you're a permadeath player. Either way, sitting there waiting for the rather loud cut-scene to finish is tedious at best. 

Okay fine, you make it past that. The game has a straightforward tutorial that teaches you how the survival mechanics work-like any good game of this genre-but as I mentioned above, you could have a short lived attempt depending on your starting island. More than a few occasions did I have to restart the game simply because I didn't have enough vital resources to survive the time it takes for said resources to respawn. That alone is why I quit playing when I first got the game. 

When some friends brought the game up again, I figured I'd give it another shot. Imagine our surprise to discover a game this old still had a two player cap, despite the community clearly hoping for more. We decided no big deal and I attempted to play solo again for the first time in years.

Y'all, this is where I honestly can't even attempt to enjoy this game anymore. The physics are HORRIBLE! In a game where that surviving is the POINT OF THE GAME you'd think they would have refined this to be actually playable! Alas, it is not. From crafted rafts refusing to follow the laws of physics, to trees shooting off into the sea, to the annoyance of not being able to simply jump in a reasonable manner (once again, to SURVIVE and avoid danger), this alone is enough of a reason for me to uninstall, hide, and try my best to forget this game even exists. 

Thanks for reading if you stuck around! Even if this game was free I'd STRONGLY recommend against it.

This game has a pretty good survival aspect, but the way they destroyed it for me was the ending. In a survival game the whole point is to survive and try not to die right? Well, once you repair the plane and launch, 3 hours later the guy crashes into another plane, making for an extremely lazy and stupid ending and just a copy of the beginning cutscene. They have also screwed over a Youtuber by the name "Madd Vladd", otherwise known as "The Outer Middle Show", who was a Youtuber that got some of the most views on his LetsPlay of this game and didn't even put his name in the credits. Stranded Deep may have a good survival aspect to it, but it isn't worth 15 dollars. DO NOT BUY THIS.

Awesome survival game! Unlike most other survival games where you're fighting zombies the enemy here is your own mistakes and poor planning. Left your island and don't remember how to get back? Looks like you're starting over. Left your island with a storm on the way and lost your raft? Shark food. Forget to refill your water stills and used up all your leaves and palms for other things? The long slow death of dehydration. I've never died from anything in this game other than my own poor planning and small mistakes that compounded into large problems and that's what I love about this game, the enemy is mother nature and you're own ability. 

Graphics are good, though the textures could be higher resolution. 

Music and sound design fit the setting and add to the immersion

Game play can become repetitive but it is what you make of it. If you aren't into games that don't give you hard line directions on what to do or where to go then this might not be for you.

I haven't played the online multiplayer, (I would love if they could make it cross platform) but I have done the split screen co-op with steams remote play and it was a blast being able to play with friends in this game.

There are player made islands you can download online and there is an in game island editor if those thing tickle your fancy. I enjoy making my own islands, but I find the island editor can be a bit wonky at times. While you can drop your custom islands into your map you cannot earn achievements while on those islands so it is strictly for your enjoyment. (That being said there is a way to inject your islands into the game files so that the game can't tell the difference, but then its up to RNG as to whether or not you have that island appear on your map).

The devs are pretty consistent on keeping the game updated and fresh. The gameplay difference between when I bought the game and now is night and day. Bugs will pop up every now and then but I have never had anything game breaking, and the devs seem to try to get any bugs that may be game breaking ironed out fairly quickly.

Overall I love this game and recommend it whole heartedly! Can't wait to see what the future holds for content as well!

Rules of the Internet is a list of protocols and conventions, originally written to serve as a guide for those who identified themselves with the Internet group Anonymous. The list serves as a summation of popular catchphrases and axioms commonly associated with 4chan. Since there are numerous drafts and editions in circulation, the rules fluctuate in number and the validity of each rule remains debatable. Despite this, several of the rules including Rule 34 and Rule 63 are agreed upon across internet communities.

This is is riddled with bad design decisions.

(1) You can only save at tent/beds. This might be one of the worst ideas I've ever heard considering that this is a game about island hopping with slow navigation. You obviously can't save at sea cuz you need a bed, and if you wanna save when you reach a new island, you have to craft one. Not very well thought out.

(2) No map. In a game like this where exploration is the game, not having a map to start is fine, However, this game has no map at all. This makes it near impossible to keep note of what islands you've explored. It would be much better to have a blank map to start that reveals itself as you travel.

(3) Level based crafting. This is by far the game's biggest flaw. You have to be at a certain level to make specific items even if you have the ingredients to craft them This is especially bad considering that you can be poisoned rather easily in this game and you need to be level 3 to make the antidote to cure yourself. So, if you're poisoned in the early game, you may as well just start a new save.

(4) There's really no reason to play. There's no driving force behind your actions in this game. The main goal is sort of like The Long Dark (just to see how long you can last/survive). However, The Long Dark does this better because it's much more challenging. In Stranded Deep, I managed to survive on one island just by crafting a water still and fishing for several days, so, in theory, I could have just done that forever without issue. It also only took  me about half an hour to figure out how to do that.

Overall, it's not terrible for $15, it's not a ripoff. You can in theory make your own fun in Stranded Deep. But there are better survival games out there for that price or less.

Initially I loved the game and the crafting and leveling seemed amazing, buuuut then the bugs started... I played on hard and loves challenges, but when the most basic and most used resource is extremly limited and the raft is horrible to steer, it's too much. Also the inventory system is really wonky.

Despite all this I see huge potential in the game with good qualities, but this was released waaay to early.

I've had this game since it's early days on steam, and all these years later, it... hasn't changed. 

They've added a ton of stuff, made tweaks, done a lot. Even added a goal of getting free by plane... but what hasn't changed is the gameplay loop. 

You're able to make shelter, and in a few different materials, but there is no reason to. You spend your time on a raft, going island to island, trying not to lose stuff as you bring it to a central point to gather up the resources to leave. Making a  home bigger than maybe 1 or 2 foundations is pointless, and making it out of higher grade materials is also pointless. 

Fighting sharks is laughable still, as they are damage sponges, as are most creatures you find. Resources are finite and it forces you to explore, which is fine, but the inventory space is so limited, or clunky if you're hauling boxes around, that you just get bored of dealing with the loop instead of excited for the next island.

In the end, this game was a neat idea that Subnautica came along and did better somehow. 

I'll end on a positive note, though. This game does screw with you hard if you have a fear of the deep. Really good at inducing a sense of paranoia and dread while deep down.

The game definitely has an interesting concept and great graphics, however it has some real problems.
TL;DR No guide - you're on your own + badly balanced --> lots of waiting and cursing as to "wtf do I do now?"

First, the "tutorial mode" doesn't work at all. There's no intro or in-game guide on how to do things. I had no idea how to kill crabs or build anything. After smashing random button, I discovered that C is for crafting, Q drops items, holding a number puts stuff in your quick slot, F shows health and can be navigated with left+right click,, etc.
The items have no description as to why one would build it and what they are for.

The game also introduces a system of "levels" which seem arbitrary. One can see everything one can build, but has to level up and there's no indication as to how: just craft more stuff (TM).

There's a LOT of waiting because it's not balanced. Nearly everything you have to build requires these forsaken lashings, which require fibrous leaves, which are only available from 2 plants of which there are not nearly enough.

It's early access and I won't be asking for a refund in hopes that the game gets better.

Crafting system unlike any other game out there. Unique, challenging, and with it's own set of bugs and learning curves, it definitely places top in my list of Alpha/Beta open world survival games. You need patience to get through poisoning, and there is a huge lack of direction when it  comes to how to do things, or possibilities within the game. For instance, I just discovered potatoes, and I just realized you don't need to "Clear" the farm plot every-time you harvest a plant from it. It also appears you don't actually need to water the farm plots.. they just fill up on their own over time? I have only made metal corrugated and plank farm plots. I don't know how to use "Container Walls" to build houses.. there's no explanation, and holding a hammer and trying to build one on a wood foundation doesn't seem to work. If you can get through these challenges, which I have, and focus on the food and water game, and not losing your island as you sail away, you can enjoy the game. I have yet to plunge into the deep ocean to fight anything bigger than a hammer head and a great white.. although I have seen whale sharks, and blue whales and Goblin sharks, which are all terrifying. I do wish trees would regrow on the island, perhaps if you don't pick the Palm sprouts, in 3-5 days they grow into small palm trees, which if left alone, will grow over the course of another week to full size 4 log palm trees... or give the ability to plant wood bearing trees.. because once you deforest an island... you are dependent on gathering wood from other islands. Since there is no way to build any work stations, or shelter on a raft, you start trying to figure out where you actually settle down. Knowing an island has a finite amount of resources (except for fibrous leaves) makes it challenging to spend any resources there. At this point, on day 34, I have decided I will pillage all the surrounding islands for my island's sake.. but after I get through the hundred or so trees, amounting to about 400-500 wood, I will be out.. and I will have to completely relocate, wasting all the resources I spent building a shelter, farm plots, water stills, etc. Also, the only reason to build a house is as a landmark, at this point. There doesn't seem to be any other reason to. Nothing blows away, and you can leave it in piles on the ground, or neat piles on the ground. In fact the only benefit, is being able to place storage chest shelves on a floor so the boxes are more organized.. but it should offer more than just that. Again, unless I'm missing something because it wasn't explained, and I haven't been able to find any good videos walking through the most recent updates (closest I can find is like 2018/2019)  it's been all hit or miss. Again though, it's a fun game to generate the most efficient food and water, and the fishing is fun. Smoking fish/meat keeps them forever - that was a game changer to find out. Bringing corpses onto the beach, or leaving them in a pile also ensures you have a fresh supply of meat, as they do not deteriorate, so harvest as you need. Or just smoke everything, which is what I do. Food levels are super easy to maintain, but water levels are contrastly way harder. You can only use palm branches to generate the water in a still, and that is a very limited resource on an island. You will run out of water if you don't go get more palm branches.. which means that I will have to be travelling so far to get palm branches to survive, that I will just need to leave my island permanently. There will be no reason to stay. If there was more ways to put things on the raft, it would make the game better, and if trees regrew over short/long periods of time, it would make the game better. Those are the two major issues I am finding; but I definitely recommend and think it's a fun game to play overall!

Mary Berry's Banoffee Pie:
Ingredients

For the base

150g/5½ oz digestive biscuits (about 10)
75g/2¾oz butter
For the toffee filling
75g/2¾oz butter
75g/2¾oz light muscovado sugar
1 x 397g/14oz full-fat condensed milk (see tip)
1 tsp vanilla extract
For the topping
300ml/10fl oz double cream
3 small just-ripe bananas, sliced
50g/1¾oz dark chocolate, melted or cocoa powder

Method

Line the base of a deep 20cm/8in spring form tin with baking paper.

To make the base, crush the biscuits to fine crumbs and melt the butter over a low heat. Pour into a bowl and mix to combine. Spoon into the base of the tin and press down with the back of a spoon until level. Place in the fridge for 15 minutes.

To make the filling, heat the butter and sugar in a small non-stick saucepan and stir over a low heat until combined. Add the condensed milk and bring to the boil, stirring for 2–3 minutes – do not over-boil or it will become grainy and fudge-like. Add the vanilla and pour into the tin. Place in the fridge for at least 1 hour.

Whip the cream in a bowl until soft peaks form.

Arrange the banana slices in neat rounds on top of the toffee. Spoon or pipe the cream on top and level. Set in the fridge for an hour.

Remove from the tin, and zig zag the melted chocolate over the top or dust with cocoa powder.

Gardening Hoe- Get rid of it, having to craft, and manage another tool in a game that has abysmal storage is ridiculous, you don't even have to have it equipped to make farm plots, and it has no VFX tied to it
Sails- FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, Fix it's text, when a sail is up, it should say "Press to lower" and when a sail is down, it should say "Press to raise" but it does the OPPOSITE right now, and it drives me up a wall.
Allow players to craft Storage shelves to put storage crates on ON THEIR FUCKING RAFT, you can't do anything with the rafts besides slowly move from island to island, let us do SOMETHING to Rafts. 
Barrel Scrap, Tyre Scrap- Make them carry-able, there is a reason a vast majority of your player base uses buoy balls, take note, and yes, you can right click drag them, but only 1 at a time. 

There is so much more, honestly, if you like survival, this game is worth it, sort of, but expect too be annoyed.

Vacation Simulator.  I was swimming in the pacific in 2019 and got cut up on the coral.  My wife screamed 'get out of the water!!' my level of self preservation was zero as I'm an awful swimmer to begin with, but I recall everyone clearing off the beach at that point.  It was then that I saw it, a shadow deeply concealed in the depths of the cascading ocean - A man eater, a seadog, the king of the sea, nearly three meters long! - it swam very casually toward me and spoke thus 'you're a long way from home land dweller, and you smell like Alberta.' With that it turned about and swam back into the depths.  I resurfaced, spewing seawater with my exhalation, and immediately realized that I had been taken away some distance by the tide.  My wife was screaming all the while from the distant shoreline, and panic struck me as firmly as an iron ballast.  I swam back to the beach like a lead weight, always with the sensation that something was nipping at my feet.  Panic only encouraged my entire submersion beneath the saline, choking and gasping as I paddled my way through the choppy water.  No sooner did I reach the shore that I slipped upon an outgrowth of coral and split open my shin.  I would later learn that this bled profusely, but at that moment, a giant killer whale sprang out of the ocean and pounced upon my man-eating assailant, spattering my wife and I with ocean water and blood in its descent back into the murky depths.  10/10, would vacation again.

I mean... its a survival game.. your plane crashes.. and now you're surviving..

What here is decently fleshed out, the game hand holds you for the first couple of steps but then you're left to your own devices. The tech tree isn't complicated and it doesnt take terribly long to get going. After about three hours I had pretty much exhausted my starting island of resources and had reliable food and water supplies. Fish seem to be endless and are easy to catch.. so I just brought what I could on my raft and moved on.. there are various little wrecks and POIs you can inspect that have plenty of loot and crafting materials.

The actual survival mechanics in play here are pretty light, your food and water doesn't go down very quickly and any ailments you come across are easily taken care of.. 

Its a neat little game and if you enjoy the genre you will like this one for a bit, it lacks alot of the needed depth to keep most folks attention beyond about 20 hours or so I'd guess. I've put in about 5 and did some research and can see that im not really missing out on much by stopping at this point. Hopefully they keep plugging away at it, it will be nice to come and drop by to visit it again every now and again as its showing some decent promise.

If you like survival games go ahead and pick it up, if you don't this one wont change your mind.

Came back to SD after seeing a surplus of Youtubers get back into it, and its so fun, but some things make me sad about it. Here's the list.

PROS:
- the water in this game looks awesome, all the vibrant colors and coral really pop like real tropical waters.
- pretty sun rays inbetween foliage.
- lots of crafting capabilities. 
- the environmental sounds like wildlife, the tide, or storms is pretty immersive.
- you can play with friends.
- whales!

CONS:
- for me, and others, shadow flickering and lighting issues have been prevalent, as well as a very short draw distance even on max making things like trees and shipwrecks look pixelated. 
- the islands and shipwrecks get repetitive
- if you dont want to beat the game and just wanna play, you can run out of stuff to do.
- the game was never completely finished, I dont even know how so many people have bought this game, it has an immense amount of potential, but its hit a dead end, if you can deal with my cons listed, its an awesome game but its just sad to see it lose so much potential.
Fun with friends, water is a hard thing to constantly have to get though

This is one of my favorite games in my library right now. I mostly play it on Xbox, but sometimes on PC also. The games are different enough on each system that its worth mentioning (specifically how the inventory systems work). It's a decent game from a small team, the graphics and game play is good (especially for how small the dev team is). This is a game where there's a tiny bit of grind at the beginning (stats boost pretty fast) but you don't really notice it because your stats unlock things at pretty much exactly the time you need them. My favorite part of this game is gathering up my resources and building my base and my raft(s) so I don't pay the story much attention and treat it more like a sandbox. There is a story, bosses, and an ending too, but I just have more fun playing around instead. You aren't forced to do any of that and can just sail around to your hearts content if you want. I haven't tried it yet, but Co-op has also been added (not cross platform though, unfortunately). Overall, really good game for a fairly low price.

I can see that after all this time away (3 yrs) this game is still c**p! Sure, they added multi-player but they still have not fixed some of the OLDEST annoying bugs! 7 years of EARLY ACCESS, it has become very apparent that this game was never meant to see it's completion! The STEAM requirements for Early Access is far less restrictive towards the developers, which is WHY they've kept it in this state.

They have completely destroyed the build mechanics now, to the point where even the work-arounds no longer work. It took me 30 attempts, 2 broken legs and a stuck gyro-copter trying to get the roof of my building finished... I gave up! Too much BS to do a simple thing. It use to be you could just close yourself in the door and it would put you on the roof, but they destroyed that glitch too... Why is it games restrict a players "Playability"? Like allowing them to build "right there" or "like that" breaks some international game building law!!?? The point (and goal) of any good developer is to provide an escape for the player, through immersion mechanics, and flexibility. Letting the player play the way they like and enjoy. Satisfactory is a great example of this mindset! They have even lifted some functional constraints because users couldn't do the things they wanted... In short, they made the PLAYER their baseline. But not this developer. Money has been theirs from day one, while users get little content and a bag of excuses. Which is why they chose to port to console even before THIS version was functioning good. 

They're in it for the cash and nothing more.. they have done just enough to keep sales coming... and once this game no longer generates the revenue they crave, it will die a long miserable death... Which may be why all the very old bugs, poor mechanics, and 7 year Early Access state are still around.

This game has been in development so long, you'd think it was Star Citizen. So, I will uninstall it for the last time and relinquish this title back to Steam. It's NEVER going to be finished, fixed, or playable for any length of time. I'll wait until another game studio comes along and blows this game out of existence with a GOOD ocean survival game (hopefully done in UE5!).

The moment I saw the trailer for this game, I bought it. Cast away was my favortie movie when I was younger, and I would almost fantasize about living through the same ordeal. This game is awesome. It is pretty simple, but has a huge open world with a decent number of different items and craftable materials. A good number of marine animals as well. All I can say is I can easily spend a couple hours on this game at a time. If this game were to continue being worked on, it could become truly amazing.

It's 2022 now and the game has come along nicely. More animals, crafting, and items. Better graphics. Loving it all over again. Just wish there was some sort of in game mapping system.

Though not quite as polished as some of the bigger commercial games, this is a top notch effort from such a small outfit. Nice building/survival mechanics, an actual story, gorgeous scenery - it was a pleasure to spend so many hours here, and still be able to finish the game. Recommended for those with little else to do.

Waiting for a major storm, then swam across to another island figuring no sharks would attack me during such a major surface storms (I was right on that part). however, other island had less resources than first.
