This absolutely has to be the greatest looking survival game graphics wish i have every played but the absolutely most worst survival game I have every played and I would not suggest purchasing this game.

One will die of thrust very quickly and if you manage to work through that you will shortly after die of hunger and the food you do gets gives very little on your health bar when consuming so you need a lot of food but there isn't much food to be found and when you do work you lose your health very quickly and find yourself in a losing cycle of all you do is try to find food and water that isn't available and doesn't Respawn. You can find a few crabs along the beaches but it seems after you kill, skin and consume them they never respawn and that food source is gone and your left with coconuts which do respawn but take many many days and your dead by then.

You need endless palm leaves from the palm trees to add to the water still and get very little water in return. There are not many trees on the small island and the trees don't grow back so if you cut them down you lose the food from the coconuts and if you don't you can't make water, so your screwed no matter what you do and there is no other way to get water.

I have tried a play through on normal settings at least a dozen times going into it with an open mind and it's always the same results. You scramble to make a few tools and a water still and get some food all of which depletes quick and all your energy is water trying to find more food and water which doesn't exist and you eventually die.

The mechanics of the raft are so screwed up I can never get off the island even to the sunken boat which is only like 50 feet off shore. I walked out to the sunken boat and there is no way to get in or on it you need to use the raft. You need the raft to get on the boat yet i can't get off the island because when I pull the raft off shore away from the beach and swim all around it i can't get in the raft, all i see is text that says Life Raft but no indicator that allow me to hit the E button and get inside the raft. The raft just quickly gets pushed back to shore. If i get in the raft near shore the game is so stupid it always puts me sitting in the raft facing the shore and when I try to paddle and turn to go out it will only allow me to go straight towards the shore which means you go no where, the raft should turn yet it doesn't. I tried grabbing the raft and turning it around based on where is was sitting when it faced me towards the shore, got back in and sat down and I am still facing the shore, the raft simply sucks.

After gathering the few items I found on the beach like stones and wood and small saplings for making rope the only thing that repawned was the saplings. I only found 1 blue tarp to make the water still and nothing else. Many bad storms came yet nothing new ever washed up on shore. I needed stone and there was large rocks i could have broken up yet i could not craft a pick due to the way the crafting is set up. You get access to new tools and for the most part anything you can craft as you craft items, crafting more opens new items yet you need to manage your resources because you have next to no resources and you need to save them to craft only the items you absolutely need. yet the game is wanting you to craft multiple items to open new recipes, this system causes you to die and every survival game I have played gives you the basics or at least the recipes to craft the basics like a knife, pick and ax, this system sucks.

So for example there are many different plants you can get and plant in a farm crop box and you would want to do that very quickly so you had a source of food. I see the crop plot in crafting but can't make it due to not having access to it because I didn't craft X amount of stuff, so I starve and die. Instead the game is instructing me and fourcing me into making stuff I really don't need like foundations. I do not really need to make foundations because I have already made a shelter where i can take cover, sleep and save. I should be focused on water and food and making that crop plot first thing should be priority seeing I already have shelter yet the developers have me wasting matts, time, water and food to build something I don't need at this point of the game, so I starve. It's a survival game and I should be able to craft what I feel I need based on my situation yet the developer is forcing my hand to do other things I feel I should not be focused on. 

I think the whole leveling structure and access to recipes and how it works in this game sucks for the fact that your stuck on this tiny tiny island with next to no resources and 99.5% of it doesn't respawn and or wash up on shore, it's not like having access to these recipes would allow me to just craft everything because you would never have enough matts to craft much of anything. It's not like ARK Survival where you have endless forest and resources available which has the same leveling structure but it's understandable due to the access and amount of resources readily available and the fact that you can be killed at any point. So you have a leveling system that slowly gives you the blueprints to craft items.

Pros
- Slow paced survival
- Great fun co-op
- Fun crafting system
- Great Visuals
- Island editor is an awesome inclusion
- Story? Im not to keen, just prefer sandbox games.

Cons
- Can get stuck on rocks, steps, vegitation hitboxes.
- Slow pickup, detection & animation delay not allowing for fast precise looting like other games.
- Crafting menus mixed with with in game crafting not very intuitive.
- inventory controls need uniformity & QoL tweaks.
- In game items can knock each others hitboxes sending your loot far far away....
- Gamemode for survival with passive animals would be great.

Lol i've been waiting 6 years for this game to get better, in the past 6 years it seems all they've added is a tool belt and storms but the storms are non-hazardous and the only thing "Scary" is running out of the coconuts that you have to drink and eat every 30 seconds to help distract you from the fact that there's literally nothing fun to do after building a twig hut and a camp fire, all the islands are roughly the same size, (uselessly small) and the devs mentioned doing this to force you to have to go to sea and explore, yet, the ocean being so god damn non-hazardous, and the islands being so tiny and barren, just makes the game forever feel boring as fuck, and again, i've been waiting 6 years for the game to get good, im becoming to suspect that the devs actually think that it already is good xD It's a game with a concept of a $40 game, but the quality and attention retention of a $7 experience, and that's a hard line, anything over $7 is a scam. $5 is fair. (Most of my play time is from re-playing over the years to re-test updates, SPOILER: Most "Amazing spectacular" new updates, were shit like adjusting your inventory, or debugging some random af scenario, which leads me to believe that the devs think this POS game is actually done. I say it's only worth $5 cause in all honesty its a $15 game, but its only 1/3 of the way done, and will always be only 1/3 of the way done.

I find the controls non-intuitive and frustrating. I need to constantly go to the control options to try and find out how to do things. Just trying to get to a weapon to use while being attacked will get me killed. Having to constantly hit TAB and select items multiple times just to do something simple, like light a fire and cook some meat, is so irritating. The small inventory also means I need to drop and pick up items constantly to do anything...... Please! if I shouldn't do something, like eat uncooked meat, Don't let me do it!!!! Just say something like "You don't want to eat uncooked meat!" and not do it! It's so easy to do it by accident with these controls.
Then I need to find guides just to know basic things like how health is regained. Maybe someday I'll even find out how to put an item in the hotbar opened by the tool belt, so my weapon isn't constantly put away every time I need another item, and not automatically or easily re-equipped.
 I kept trying to get on the low end of a ship in water by using space bar... it worked on another ship before, but it just kept doing the opposite and dunking me under the water..... There was no indication on how I should climb up on the boat, and all trying to do it repeatably got me was an attack from a shark.... Very frustrating when you are trying to figure out how to do things.
This might be a good game eventually, but I doubt I'll be able to deal with the clunky basics long enough to find out.

Review December 2017 />

“We don't want to work on Stranded Deep forever. If all goes well, we're hoping to have it completed by the end of 2015."

Coming back after a year since I played, I'm a little disappointed to see it is still EA, as this game has a huge potential. 
There is a lot to improve, and the devs are certainly taking their time, or simply have given up on the game. 
What the game could improve on:

- Bigger, more interesting islands. For instance it would be cool with a beach cove or small caves (with clay deposits). Volcano islands or underwater volcanoes. 

- More wildlife. Could be simple thing as poisonous spiders, scorpions, chameleons, mosquito swarms - or bigger ones like iguanas. Including underwater life like whale sharks, groups of dolphins spotted in the distance etc. 

- Less coconuts - More varied sources of food. Bananas. Berries (including poisonous ones), papayas, other exotic fruits etc. In its current state it is too easy going from island to island and replenish on food and water from coconuts.

- Different sound effects. Example: Hacking trees or paddling in the life raft should have 3 or 4 sound effects each. Yeah, it does actually make a difference when you do it a whole day.

- Cutting out the cheesy voice lines saying "Eww, gross" when skinning a crab and trying to survive. Add more random dialogue that could occur from time to time, like how he's hoping he will be rescued soon, how he's curious about the new island he's arriving on, how he hopes there are no sharks around when he goes for that shipwreck etc.

- Random drops; Traces of previous ancestors, history relics, ancient ruins, message in a bottle etc. Maybe some personal belongings from the people on the plane. 

- Less frequent shark encounters. So that you actually have the guts to take a swim but will get more freaked out when you meet a shark. Not having them swimming around your island constantly. 

- More objectives/ quests: Would be awesome finding a treasure map / key belonging to another island (in the same island group) that you have to seek out. Maybe a bigger island, having to fight a panther boss or something.



They have indeed made a few new improvements, like adding storms with huge waves. But all in all the process is too slow. I'm sure if they pick up the pace and make some new features and more varied content, this will be a 50+ hour game (add multiplayer on top and it's 150+), rather than its current state where you get more or less bored after 10 hours. 

Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad game, and with great graphics. I'm just disappointed seeing the progress with just a couple new features since I last played, over a year ago. For me personally, there was no replay value, which I usually have with most games. If it was a FULL release when buying, it would be something different. But I bought it in EA, thinking a lot more content would come. 

I'm not at all expecting them to make all the ideas above, but it's just some suggestions to make the game less repetitive. I hope they continue in the right direction and will be more than happy to change this review later on. Like mentioned this game has potential, and could possibly be among the best games in 2018 if done right!

Review December 2021 />

They have done some things since I last played this four years ago! More wildlife, more objects to make, I can recommend this now. Though they could work on the audio and turn down the shark frequency (constantly being followed by my new pet, hammerhead fella :)

What they really need to do is get inspired by Raft; as you can only stay on an island a certain amount of time before it depletes, you should be able to build more stuff on the raft. Also you need like 10 shots of the harpoon to kill a shark, which is too much. You should either reduce it or give the ability to make leather armour for extra protection.

Its such are good concept & I do recommend it, for those with patience.
But!... yes there is a but, there's quiet a few bugs, a fair bit of lag at times.  Granted I don't have the strongest internet speed, but if I can play games like Battlefield V or Rust, I can't really blame my ISP.  The game can get boring, but so much more immersive and fun with co-op, would be even better if there could be up to 4 players. 
I do hope the developers keep updating and fixing stuff, because it really is a good idea.  Perhaps the crafting interface and the general interaction with the environment could be more fluid. But hey, I'm not a gaming programmer and I have no understanding of the difficulties of programming such suggestions, but perhaps others can identify and articulate constructive advice much better than me.

This game is great if you only have one friend to play with, but even then the connection can be awful. On another note, the UI/crafting menus are incredibly difficult on PC, and aren't well explained in game. 

Multiplayer needs to be enhanced, additional players would be great, but just fixing the connectivity/syncing problems would be appreciated. 

The menu should be explained in the tutorial missions, so as to avoid a complete dependence on player guides elsewhere online. Having items that can't be picked up and stored, namely tires and barrels used to craft raft bases is redundant and more annoying than "creative" on the dev's part.

The game is in alpha, but that's been a while to keep saying that's the reason it's still unstable. Decent game with potential, personally worth buying and investing some time into, but it still has a long way to go.

A really fun, somewhat lite survival game. With the true potential realized with the multiplayer coop option.

I originally got this as a free game on PSN, and it gave me some really fun hours of entertainment. When i seen it appear here on steam with the option to play multiplayer, the purchase was a no brainer, i knew exactly what i was getting and its easily worth the price.

The exploration part is just so fun, with the risk/reward element just so satisfying. Its not a game you can spend years on like ARK. But for a couple of fun filled days with friends, i really do reccomend this game.

And kudos to the devs in the business practices, making this game free made me notice it, and then by noticing it i certainly wanted to contribute, i purchased this game again here and a copy for a friend, now thats business acumen and i think a lot of gaming devs thesedays ignore this marketing part. TY so much for this wonderful adventure! If part 2 is in the roadmap i will definatly be looking to purchase it.

I am giving this game a thumbs up. I think Beam Team did an incredible job with this game. It's not perfect, but it really has progressed and it is very fun. The exploration is enjoyable, although I wish there was more variety. But once I finished the game, I did replay it and knocked off over 40 days in time trying to escape. My record is 25 days, try and beat it suckers :) I was running a tiny crafted boat and had a real difficult time with inventory until I checked the internet and learned how to combine the base together. I lately have a barge, which has a storage area, two outboard motors (just so I can hold more fuel), a sail and two anchors. It's quite the improvement on my tiny boat. I hope you enjoy the game as much as I have. It's definitely worth the purchase. Peace!
*Edit: Just finished the game on day 19. I could maybe get it down one day, but that is about as fast as it can be done. Kind of a fun challenge trying to beat the game as fast as possible.

I love this game: 7 to 8 out of 10. To be fair, you have to cut the game some slack since they don't have that publishing money, and indie games that don't need that slack are all the better. I don't really know why it's still in early access since the game's complete and 6 years old. There's nothing to care about lore-wise really, but for those of you who can't afford a triple game or don't have an rtx 9020, it's a good game for you.

stranded-deep.fandom.com
Overall, it's worth the 10 bucks.

After 71 hours i have completed this game.  I think this is an all around good game to play if you are into the survival genre. It´s a great survival game
I startet playing at version 0.90.08 in Singleplayer.
The only Survivalgames i´ve played so far are Subnautica and Below Zero
On Stranded Deep I like the more realistic setting compared to the Sci-Fi Setting in Subnautica.

For me, being in the water or being surround by it is a great setting for a survival game.
On my first attempt I stepped into a poisonous plant on Day1 and died on Day2.
On my secont attempt I knew the basics, what to do, what to focus on and been playing for 8 hours until Day10 so far.

Until now it is really fun exploring the surrounding islands, crafting new stuff and organize my home.
I like that there is no map. Why should there be a map in such a setting anyway?
It kills the tension. When you leave your home island there is a litte fear and pressure to not get lost 
and to hopefully find a way back without getting cought by a storm.

I hope that there is a lot more to explore and that it stays beeing fun like it is now.

The only disturbing object I saw in the carfting menu is the helicopter.
It´s not fitting into the "sticks and stones" scenario at all in my opinion.

You will probably die and get coconut induced diarrhea.

HOWEVER that is part of the fun of Stranded Deep. Let's sum up all the mistakes I made because that's what this game is, learning from your mistakes. 1. Diarrhea from eating too many coconuts too soon 2. Stepping on poisonous starfish 3. Not crafting an antidote after being poisoned 4. Leaving life raft (YOUR KEY TO SALVATION) not anchored and not pulling it up to shore so it doesn't get carried away by the tides 5. Realizing you lost said raft because you were in such a hurry searching this island for pipi plants (used for antidotes) 6. Getting poisoned AGAIN by a snake after freaking out about losing your raft 7. Crafting a seaworthy vessel made of sticks and putting a sail on it with NO RUDDER 8. Trying desperately to stay on makeshift raft that is going where where the h*** it pleases because you forgot to craft a rudder to steer the doomed vessel 9. Flipping said doomed makeshift stick vessel in shark infested waters and being eaten alive. 

If you're contemplating purchasing this horrifying island castaway adventure than you should be asking yourself "Do I have what it takes to survive coconut-induced diarrhea, poisonous snakes, man-eating sharks, poisonous fish, angry boars, poisonous sea snakes, annoying seagulls, poisonous starfish, more man-eating sharks, poisonous sea urchins, and terrifying bats. And on top of all that you have to make sure as all humans do stay on top of water and calorie intake.

I've played for nearly 24 hours now, and I think I can safely say I've barely scratched the surface of what this game has to offer. 

I play through exploration games pretty slowly, and I don't typically watch other people play games first, in order to keep things interesting. I'm sure many players would have come across much more content than myself so far - but I spent a few hours getting comfortable in the first world I spawned in... Then restarted with the skills I learned, in a different map. I have just recently started exploring other islands and realized how much danger is out there! 

The crafting menus are huge, I have only crafted and built from probably 4 or 5 categories, and have so much more to explore. I feel confident at the time of writing this review that I have many, many more hours of entertainment from this game to come.

Do not buy.

Let me elaborate:

I spent days building a raft, going from island to island, searching desperately as daylight bled away into night. Not one single coca plant anywhere. Each moment i felt as my strength ebbed from my body, my demise coming closer and closer to me as if another survivor had washed ashore with me and unseen, began choking me in my sleep, choking me in my wake, choking me with an ever tightening grip. By day 6 i had resorted to snorting a crushed snail shell as if it would provide me with some form of relief. It did not.

By day 7 i realised that i needed real help. 
In hospital, hooked up to an iv of heightened valium, prescribed by a doctor who's name seemed to rhyme with *sshole judging by how many times i belligerently yelled it at him, i began my healing process.

I was told by another patient in the hospital that Stranded deep was a great game to escape reality with. So i bought it and tried it.

It has been exactly 62 hours since i last snorted a sweet sweet line of dried angel c*m and i regret every second of it. I need to find more coca leaves. I need the coca leaves to grow.

There are no coca leaves in Stranded deep.
There is no cocaine production in Stranded deep.

DO NOT LISTEN TO THEM.
COCAINE IS YOUR FRIEND.

I enjoyed this game in the beginning. I enjoyed the survival mode my brain went into as I was playing and felt immersed in the environment. What i do not like is that there is no map!!!!!!!! It is so frustrating. I know if you were to be stranded on an island you would obviously have no map, but it drives f***ing crazy trying to figure out what island I have been to or not. I bet 12 of the 18 hours of game play were just me going to different islands wondering if I had been there already. It was very frustrating. why take the time to craft a bunch of cool items if you can't even remember where they are. For that reason, I do not recommend this game. I do suggest playing The Long Dark instead. It is a much better game and does not drive me crazy wondering where my last shelter was :)

Notes: this game has a beautiful underwater environment and sunrise. Being in the water is always stressful and dangerous, with sea snakes, lion fish, and sharks at every turn, You can get your adrenaline pumping by exploring old abandoned ships. Its one of those games where many of the rarer resources must be found, not crafted. This game is stressful with many responsibilities for you to remember. whether it be bringing the amount of supplies with you to another island, deciding what to bring back with your limited space on your raft. navigating your way home, remembering to tend to your crops, keeping the endurance of your weapons high, especially when you are poisoned and searching frantically around the map for 2 green flowers to heal you up. When I played, I had to create a real map on a piece of paper with all the islands I traveled too, the resources they had, the directions. etc, and even with all this I was stranded on another island, far from my base, sailing the open ocean, till I eventually found my way back after like 15 hours of gameplay. Stressful game, but a good one. There isnt many building options unfortunantly, with no sets of furniture. not a very creative game, but a great survival game.

I played this game for 3 days straight, the concept is AMAZING, the crafting is great, the building is great, the combat is great and absolutely love the fact you added split screen just that alone is the main reason I bought this game because no one offers split screen anymore and these are the types of games my fiance and I look for.. Here is what I feel is missing, mind you I have played 7 days to die, DayZ, Ark survival, All the fallouts, I have spent countless hours playing survival games. With all thet being said, here's my honest opinion. The graphics are SPECTACULAR, and everything I previously mentioned above BUT I got bored after the first day and here's why, pretty much every island is the same, same resources, same creatures, some islands are a bit bigger then others and some have a FEW different resources then others but not by much. The sea creatures are awesome looking but most dont do anything like the turtles have no purpose the stingrays have no purpose, the coral has no purpose, there's plenty of trees but you cant cut alot of them down for some reason, and same for the boulders/rocks they are just there...when I play split screen I feel there isn't enough resources between the 2 of us we find ourselves having to search for hours just to find stone...kinda boring...ALSO the compass does'nt quit work like i thought it would and have lost my island SO MANY TIMES and I know how to read a compass....please add a map of some sort. Also, I do think it's a cool idea that you do all this to get off the island BUT I also would like a continuous game that you can continue to play...once I found out thats the sole purpose is to just build up the plane and leave I found myself not wanting to play anymore....I haven't played since then because It's boring and wish there was SO MUCH MORE to utilize, the clay took us over a entire day (real life time) to find....kinda crazy. We do really enjoy the game but just bored with it. Kinda pointless to do all that just to leave...PLEASE ADD MORE CONTENT <3 I purchased this game on both steam and xbox cause I thought we could join eachother, come to find out I wasted money ): damn. Still an awesome game just striving for more, MORE, MORE!!! Thanks for reading and hearing me out. (:  (the reason for me not recommending is because there's not much to do)

I usually don't like to review games when it's this early, but this review is pretty important to put out early as the stuff I will be talking about is... well, early in the game.

This game is exceptionally more entertaining than I originally thought it would be, and I loved how the tutorial didn't literally hold your hand and baby you through it. But there are some problems I'd like to see addressed.

The game never actually tells you how to throw spears for example, or how to use the toolbelt, which are both pretty vital aspects to know about. I literally looked on a wiki to find out how to use a toolbelt, and was completely shocked at how there's no way I could've guessed something so random is what bound items to the hotbar. It should either be obvious, or told in the tutorial how you do basic controls in the game, and even now I'm not sure if the container inventory system is just really awkward, or I just don't have a clue what the proper controls are. 

A HUGE issue that even ruins a lot of my enjoyment of the game is just that the toolbelt and hotbar system is the absolute worst I have ever seen. I tried using the toolbelt, by binding some tools to it, and I STILL had to have them in my inventory, and on top of that, if I dropped the tool, it got unbound! This is absolutely unacceptable and would take off at least 4 out of 10 points on this game instantly, if I were rating it 1-10.

I am genuinely extremely angry and frustrated about just how bad the hotbar system is. If you're gonna have me have to rebind an item EVERY TIME I drop it, then you have to make it be STORED in the hotbar slot, and not wasting my precious inventory slots! And if you're gonna have it the other way around, where it isn't stored in my hotbar, then don't make it EVER get unbound unless I PERSONALLY unbind it or bind something else to that slot. You can't have it be literally BOTH of the negatives of each side, it completely ruins almost every part of the gameplay and any chance of being efficient without jumping through so many hoops. 
This mega issue is literally something I would talk to a friend about like "imagine if the developers made it like this, that would be so stupid", and laugh about, so the fact that it's actually done like this is almost too painful for me to even put into words. Until this absolute roadblock of horrifying pain is fixed, I won't enjoy this game even a third as much as I would if it was done correctly, and will mostly avoid using the hotbar (or toolbelt) at all.

So then the other thing I just now noticed that seriously needs to be addressed for obvious reasons, is that multiplayer needs to have chat. I get if you want a game to have the kind of multiplayer where you are in a call with a friend or something, but you can't just not have a proper form of chat in the public multiplayer gameplay. 

I do recommend trying this game's singleplayer, but the multiplayer should be limited to playing with people via a discord call for example, or you get quite the risk of who you're playing with getting upset at you because there's literally no communication and misunderstandings are born easily. 

This is less of a gameplay review and more of a critical review. I do very much enjoy this game and there's a lot to love about it, but I'm not much good at writing reviews about the things that are already good in a game. So I'll just say it's pretty dang good for the most part, but needs a touch up on the tutorial, a total overhaul on the hotbar system, and chat for public multiplayer games.

I wanted to give Stranded Deep a try for the longest time. The introduction of Coop then finally made us test it out. In it's current state however, i can not recommend it. There are tons of flaws with the game: from little imperfections, over questionable game design choices, to crippling bugs.

This is a full-length review. You can heavily shorten the read by stopping after the personal gameplay story i put at the top, as it should be enough to deliver the message. If you are still interrested, you can afterwards read up on the other topics making this game unenjoyable to play, which cant be delivered in such a story.

[b]Gameplay Introduction[/b]:
The game starts with your plane crashing. You end up in the ocean with nothing more but a rubber raft. You paddle your way to the next island and start foraging for ressources. You can pick up ressources, craft tools to harvest some more, and build workbenches to help you cook, collect water, or craft more [i]complex[/i] items, like wooden planks. Most ressources are finite per island, so you eventually have to build a raft and move on. So what went wrong with the game?

[b]A true Story about Space Travel[/b]:
One true story is all it takes to perfectly summarize what it feels like to play this game. 
We headed out to another island. Well prepared with a raft, food, water, tools, crates and all. We found a large ship with quite a few rooms underwater. Drowning in this game starts once your O2 bar depleates, at which point your screen slowly turns black, giving you some more time. I lost orientation underwater and drowned. Happens. My mate set out to rescue me. Shortly before arriving at my position, he died. He had still half of his O2. He did not drown, he simply died. There was also no wildlife. As both of us were dead, we had to reload.
Same journey again. This time we build a shelter on the island and frequently saved. Similar to the above, while exploring an empy underwater corridor, i suddenly got poisoned. As antidote was one of the only things we did not bring, i was now flagged for eventual death. That takes some time tho, so we continued. 
Eventually we collected all the crates from all the ships. We saved. I farmed trees, while my mate sorted crates to create some additional space. As we were just done with all of that, the game crashed. Half an island of chopped trees and 10 sorted chests, gone. We loaded back in and.. another crash while still loading. Third time is the charm. We chopped wood, sorted crates, saved and were finally ready to sail back to our main island. 

This is not where the story ends. This is where it begins.
As we load up the raft, i eventually die to the poison. We were prepared for that, so my mate already carried a bandage to help me back up. While getting revived, my body launched into the raft, instantly killing me again and flipping the raft upside down. The crate with clothes and ropes was in my inventory, so we had no good way to revive me again. Cant really plan for [b]that[/b] to happen, right? Furthermore, there is no good way to flip a raft. He eventually managed using a log from our chests. He then sailed back to our main island, got a bandage, and sailed all the way back to me. Meanwhile, ironically, a shark started circling my lifeless body, making the rescue a bit harder than usual. Once done, you guessed it, my body launched into his player model, ricochet into the raft, which flipped again, and then flew off into space. I literally saw the border of the world.. or rather the end of my maxed view distance. We would have still attempted to resolve this without reloading, if the game did not suddenly decide that something was not right, freezing my character in place. Which meant i was stuck in space, without any hope for a rescue operation. 

[b]This[/b] is [b]the[/b] Stranded Deep experience.

[b]Inventory Management[/b]:
Your inventory has 10 slots. Since there is an empty-hand slot and a current-item slot, make that 8. Crates have 3 slots. A slot can take a stack of one item. Some items, like logs, take a full slot, most items can be stacked to 4, and then there are some exceptions. It is worth mentioning that the current-item slot holds one item only, not a stack. This causes problems, but more on that later. 
Besides items you might want to carry a spear, axe, pick, light, knife, air tank, or many other things with you, depending on the situation. This further limits your free space by a lot. Some crafts also take huge amounts of items. A raft base made of sticks, for example, takes 14 sticks and a rope. That is half your inventory for one crafted item. Carrying around, sorting, and generally managing items thus makes an uncomfortably large part of the game. As for storage, you can attempt to store most things in chests. Chests are rather expensive to craft, but plenty are found in shipwrecks. You will however likely be tempted to skip the inventory management and just drop piles of items on the ground. Which is fine, but tells you a lot about the alternative.

[b]Game Design Flaws[/b]:
A lot of little things quickly add up here. The Coop lobby menu works by sharing a generated code. Closing the steam overlay with escape then also closes the lobby menu tho, making you do it all over again. 
The UI is pretty horrid. You do not see both inventories when transfering items. Instead you see your usual inventory item wheel, except the other inventory is added as another slot with a backpack/crate symbol you can click on. This was confusing at first and is also inconsistant to how the other slots behave. 
To interact with items in the world, you need to get them highlighted. Which doesnt work well. You can literally stand on top of a chopped palm tree and not hit its leaves with your axe sometimes. Combat works the same, meaning badly. There is also little feedback for hitting stuff, or how the fight is going in general.
The crafting menu is a nightmare. There is categories inside categories. The inner ones are easily identifiable using icons. The outer ones are accessed by clicking the text above the crafting menu, which took us some time to even notice. 
When you craft an item, the menu closes itself. You want another one, you gotta reopen it again. If you hold a hammer, it tries to be smart and directly opens the building category. Except you also use the hammer for vehicle stuff. Making it less smart and more detrimental.
You dont interact with workbenches to see what they can craft. Instead the distance to them is like an item requirement, enabling you to use recipes from your usual crafting menu. Not only does this unnecessarily clutter the menu, it also causes problems since the whole thing works increadibly poorly. You can sometimes stand on top of workbenches or items, with them not registering for the recipe. 
Remember the current-item inventory slot which can only hold one item? Makes sense on paper, but causes a ton of problems in practice. Imagine you hold an axe there and fill your inventory with sticks. Now you want to drop your sticks on a pile. You cant do that. Why? Because that would require you to put your axe into a free inventory slot, but taking a stick out of it does not free up a whole slot. So despite already carrying all those items, you get the "inventory full" message and are forced to first drop your tool. 

There is so many inconvenient or badly designed things in the game that playing it becomes a chore. Reinventing the wheel is usually a bad idea. Especially so, if the result does not roll anymore. 

[b]Bugs, Performance, Other[/b]:
Whenever someone joins, the world needs to be synchronized. This takes quite some time, but that's to be expected as Coop was an afterthought. The real problem is that clients commonly disconnect (~2h). Even i as the host once did.. from my own lobby.
Rejoining means everybody is stuck in the sync world screen again. The game also likes to crash sometimes. Same story.

A great survival game for beginners to the Genre. The music type and tropical ambiance will please and cheer you up if you are down! The sights are lovely and the ocean, islands, and sealife look very much alive.

However! This is certainly not a game for Hardcore Survivalists as it is very light on ACTUAL Survival. Food is aplenty, water can easily be accessed once you build one water collector, and animals are easy enough to avoid/kill. 

Compared to Green Hell, this game is hardly worth the challenge and more of a passing of time. The Devs have a surprisingly small amount of items that can be found to benefit you, and there's no true sickness or exposure enough that would kill you. All-in-all, it's very soft on the pains it delivers. Item-wise, it's pretty basic and only the most surface level of survival things can be made/found, and you can live without 99% of them.

They have a weather system that goes according to a Calendar system, which is pretty cool, but really doesn't do enough to make the game replayable as much as it could. If overheating/freezing were added, however. . And if the storms ACTUALLY threatened you in any way, or harmed your raft, or any shelter you might have built, it would be quite impressive. -- But it's not. Feels quite empty infact.

Here's hoping the Devs will continue their efforts to make this game harder, seem more alive, for Pacific Storms to be frightening and enough to wreck damage on you, your raft, shelter, then it'll be a good 10/10. At the moment, it's rather more like 6-7/10.  Also, the current ending is really. . bad. They should work on a real one. .

The abstract: 
+Nice setting
+coop
+some good ideas on the crafting/survival part
-gets a bit repetitive,
-a lot of Bugs and glitches that will frustrate the hell out of you

The longer version:
As a fan of survival/crafting games that are coop-enabled, I really like the concept of the game. Who doesn't love an island setting anyway? Playing with a friend makes it even better.

The game does many things quite well, but it fails in a few places and is extremely unpolished:
- Island hopping is exciting in the beginning, but after maybe your 3rd or 4th island, the gameplay gets extremely repetitive. After a very hours of playing, you quickly start doing the same things over and over again, which gets even more tedious due to the fact that most islands and shipwrecks are almost exactly the same. Only a few layouts that are copy pasted
- No real story, just a way to "escape" the place. That would be ok, but I guess most players would never find that this exists, because of the very rough way of navigating and keeping track of where you are, except if they look at online hints about that escape. This also means that if you do like the feeling of having some kind of plot like in "the Forest" or "green Hell", you're going to be disappointed
- It has so many bugs and glitches that it hurts. This is ultimately the reason why I cannot recommend this game. It starts with minor to medium annoyances (raft and environment clipping errors, keyboard keys stop working until you reload the game, random disconnects that reset you to your last save point, item placement glitches, and stuff like this). Those you could live with. But what is really annoying is the fact, that BAAD stuff tends to happen to your Raft. For example: Sometimes it gets flipped over for no reason or flies through the air as if thrown by catapult because of weird physics. This is absurd. But the worst thing that happened to us (after about 30-40 hours of gameplay) was that our large raft completely disappeared all of sudden, along with all of our stuff, even as it was parked right next to the island beach. And the game does not keep backup saves! Because we did not immediately notice the raft was gone (was on other side of the island), we accidentally saved this corrupted state and were stuck like this. We lost so many hours of gameplay because of this now corrupted save, that we quit playing the game altogether, even with only one more "boss" remaining. It was just so frustrating. Putting all the stuff and Raft together again would literally take many hours. After searching the forums, this seems to be a very common bug.

So, if you decide to play this game: Always keep a manual backup savegame in case you end up with a corrupt state.

This game's UI gave me cancer and killed my dog. And the worse part is, I envy the dog for at least being put out of its misery sooner.

Just one example: Want to pick up a rock into your backpack? You pick it up and it ends up as the active item in your hands like a tool--even though you can't really use it like a tool--*then* you have to go into your backpack and select your *empty hands*(!) (from within your backpack!?) to actually put the rock away into your backpack and give you your hands back. Yes really. Also, radial menus.

Another example?: If you pick a coconut off a tree, you have to drop it on the ground and attack it with your knife to shuck it, then you can pick it back up to drink it--but then to harvest/eat it you drop it back on the ground and attack it again to open it, then pick it up and eat it. (Grab off tree -> drop -> attack -> pick up -> drink -> drop again -> attack -> pick up -> eat. Congrats you have fully consumed a single coconut, and it only took you 9[!] actions.) Ok, but then does a picked up crab at least work the same way for consistency?--of course not. You drop it on the ground, but then instead of attacking it (like the coconut) you hold *pickup* on it--but only if you have your knife selected--to harvest the meat from it. Yep. I couldn't make this sh1t up.

Also, if you see a hotbar in any screenshots (like every other survival-crafting game in history), you have to craft/unlock *every spot on your hotbar one at a time*--and they don't give you any extra inventory/carrying capacity, you're just crafting/unlocking each slot solely for the privilege to be able to use number keys to switch weapons/tools and avoid the god-forsaken radial menus.

It's like the devs have never seen a survival-crafting game before. And the UI they invented out of nowhere belongs exactly where it came from: nowhere--it belongs nowhere--no survival-crafting game UI in the history of UIs should ever exist or work like this, ever.

The only difficulty I had with this game was curing poison from a snake bite. Turns out, the pipi plant can be hard to find sometimes. I thoroughly enjoyed it for about 75 hours! I think it's definitely worth $15. So realistic. You actually feel like the crafting makes sense. My favorite survival game so far. Reminds me of Don't Starve but realistic, no fantasy here. If you've ever wanted to know what it's like to be stranded on a deserted island, this is the best representation of that.

I was expecting an "infinitely procedural generated" world, like the devs promised, but it's not even that cool. You spawn into a random world, but that's it, there's 16 -25 islands and they are all tiny and not THAT different. If you go outside the boundaries, you reach a fishing net bobber-line, with NOTHING outside of it (Don't bother looking lol). There are a few cool surprises though. I really enjoyed trying to make a map for myself, based on the features of the islands. Sharks are always terrifying!

After 75 hours it got super boring, as there's really not much to do, other than survive. They added an "end game" update recently, and fixed seagulls (I guess?) a couple little things like that, but I'm already over it and that's not enough to bring me back in.

Way better on PC (I originally bought on Xbox One, it's okay, but they really need to update that version, it runs super choppy). 

Here's what updates I'd like to see, if anyone is paying attention:

A larger, way more dangerous island in the middle, with more creature types and items, or a "mainland" to try to get to, that you have to save up food and water to reach, and then the hard part begins? Perhaps more than one way to "beat" the game? Like getting rescued, or travelling far enough?! Perhaps procedural generation of extra islands, if you go outside the boundaries...?

 So much potential, if you would just FINISH what you started here, it sort of feels abandoned and unfinished. I still really enjoyed it!

This was surprisingly unfun. It's very similar to games like Raft and Ark that I have enjoyed a lot more, and it looks really good, but it does everything in a way that is just constantly irritating. I've never played a game with a more aggravating inventory system. It's difficult to switch between items and you frequently end up having to drop items from your inventory just to switch between objects already in your inventory. The crafting system is also incredibly annoying to use, more so than almost any crafting system I've dealt with. Even Fallout 4's crafting wasn't more annoying. 

The game constantly forces you to go through tedious and repetitive steps to do simple tasks, mostly involving popping in and out of the menus multiple times to perform simple things like cooking a fish. Steering the raft is one of the most unresponsive and frustrating things I've done in a video game. Having to constantly rebuild structures on new islands because they can't be moved or built on the raft is just a needless annoyance. All survival games have a degree of busywork involved in just staying alive, but the busywork in this game is more aggravating to figure out and more aggravating to repeat than in most.

The underwater stuff does look great, but as far as the actual gameplay it's just a buggier, less fun version of other games I've already played, with nothing special to make it work putting up with.

I never write reviews but I had to for this game. I just finished up after 5 straight days of hard gaming..  It has SO much potential. I love that it is tough however, I do not like that you run out of resources and things do not re spawn/regrow such as coconuts. Trees. These NEVER grow back people.  You run out of items quickly when each island only has for instance, roughly 15 stones on it, or 30 pieces of wood and it runs out. Forever. 

 The other flaw is that I want to build everything on boat but it will not allow for that. Most games reward you for your efforts whereas this one punishes you because you will run out of items and cannot place items which you need to live on your raft/houseboat. I wanted to put my fire on my raft, I built the floor with corrugated steel yet when I tried to put the wood for the fire on top of it, the game doesn't let you do that. So you would eventually be forced to island hop and keep rebuilding fires, water filter systems just to live and there is nothing able to re spawn there. Please please let some wood regrow and let us build sustainable boats?? Island hopping only to have to build the same things over and over are less fun. 

The game feels like it kinda cheats ya, by not growing normal things and not allowing you to place items on your raft.

The other issue was that I keep killing sardines for food when I can see mussels and clams on the ocean floor, and turtles swim by and the game will not allow me to kill or harvest these other food sources...I lived off sardines 99.9.% of my life...PLEASE add variation and other skills would be fun too, like salting food so we can preserve it longer or make jerky or something.

This game has so much potential if not for all the glitches.  Even with all the glitches it's still really fun, which is why I recommend it.  Sometimes creatures sink under the ground, sometimes you can't interact with your items or structures, sometimes the physics of the game do weird things like launch you really high into the air (for no obvious reason), and sometimes the multiplayer games have duplication errors that cause the game to be border-line unplayable.  All of this stuff is really frustrating and yet, I'm not exaggerating when I say this is probably the most fun survival game I've ever played.  I hope the devs fix all the various glitches because this could be one of the all time great survival games if I didn't have to start my games over so much do to all the glitches. I give it 3 of 5 stars due to the glitches alone.  If not for those, this game is better than Valheim and both Subnauticas - which are my other favorite survival games - and way better than Raft, which is a poor substitute for Stranded deep, but at least everything works correctly.

I love this game. The look, weather, lighting, sounds, wildlife. all of it. Megalohydrothalassophobia and thalassophobia make this game all the more addicting. 

I do wish the game was a bit more full. There are some obvious crafting solutions that would make this game even more enjoyable. Such as:

- Coconuts float. They should should be considered as a raft building material. 
- I want to build structures on rafts. The fun of this game is going from island to island looking for resources. That fun is lost when you have to leave a well established fort on an island (the risk of getting lost, not being able to find your favorite island again). I want a mobile home raft. A house boat. 
- More edibles/recipes. Soups, salads, burritos. The game has enough depth to allow for pack-able meals for long trips. 
- Better tools. 
- Salvageable boat wrecks. 
- Generators/Solar Panels: Electric lighting. 
- 4 player co-op. 

I hope the developers continue add and update.

What can I say about Stranded Deep that hasn't already been said about the wheel, penicillin, or the iPhone.... this is one of the greatest games of all time. My husband and I would argue constantly over who had to cut the day's coconuts. It's one of those chores NO ONE wants to do! You know, the old "I spent the entire day fighting sharks and drowning, maybe YOU can pitch in a little and cut these coconuts?" and of course, "You think I have the energy to slave over your damn coconuts? I chop down 12 palm trees all day just to come home to THIS?!" These are the things that can destroy an entire relationship. It got to the point where the crabs could sense the tension. The minute I heard the seagulls calling, parroting the coconut fight with their obnoxious voices, I knew we had to make a change. That's when I found the refined axe. Our marriage has never been healthier, AND we've even incorporated it into our lovemaking. :D THANKS Stranded Deep! ♥

Quite surprised about the amount of positive votes on this game.
Potential and theme are really good however after 6 years of "Early Access" there is still only about 15 hours of game play at best. Most features are either pointless or poorly utilised. Unbalanced resource harvesting/spawning make the game either stupid easy or stupid hard depending on your choice of play style.
For example they implemented a base building element that is not only completely pointless (weather/shelter is not a threat) but it sucks at limited resources (not everything re-spawns) 
They implement a RAFT feature (good feature in similar game) yet you can't build/store/sleep/cook...live? on it... it's just another form of transport.
Buoyancy physics are completely up sh*t creek. On a game where it's 90% water and flotation device.
...Apart from that, I don't mind it too much... but recommend it? I don't think so.

Picked up coconut. Could not put down coconut. That was my first minute of playing.

Seems really fun, will look again when it is better developed.

Bought this way back when it was in Early Access but it seemed to be in such a poor state that I held off installing it. Now I wish I hadn't bought it to begin with. Can't even finish the "tutorial" because the water still requires a "coconut flask"; I have a coconut with a hole in it but it doesn't qualify as a "flask" (it's marked in red) and I have no recipe for making one either. On the next run I was unlucky and got too few leaf thingies from the yucca bushes, my knife fell apart and so I couldn't even make a damned shelter so I could save my progress before venturing off to another island. Containers have apparently been completely reworked in the last update but it's impossible to put things INTO containers; you can only take stuff OUT of them, and even that is done in the least intuitive way possible. All of these issues were obvious within 1.1 hours of trying to play. This is what happens when devs only ever playtest their own product in godmode and never actually test it from a new player's perspective.

I seriously want to like this game.  It checks many boxes that I love, but the inventory management for the game is one of the most frustrating I have ever encountered.  I absolutely HATE it.  I cannot ask for it to be 'fixed' as I'm sure it works as designed, but I am asking that it be changed to a more traditional inventory system.  I'm not asking for you to be able to carry an infinite number of items, but you NEED to be able to carry more.  And what you are carrying should NEVER conflict with what's in your hand.  Getting to a point where you literally have to drop something because you cannot even change what's in your hand is absolutely maddening.  Please don't tell me about using boxes to extend your inventory; that is just addressing a symptom and not a root issue.  If the inventory system is adjusted, I'll will be back.  If not, I think I'm done with this game.

It is still a really fun experience for the game though. Hope that helps!!
